paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ORSINO, CURIO, and other lords; Musicians playing$NEWLINE$ORSINO$NEWLINE$CURIO
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO, CURIO, and other lords enter with musicians playing for them.$NEWLINE$ORSINO$NEWLINE$CURIO

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$If music be the food of love, play on.$NEWLINE$Give me excess of it that, surfeiting,$NEWLINE$The appetite may sicken, and so die.$NEWLINE$That strain again, it had a dying fall.$NEWLINE$Oh, it came o'er my ear like the sweet sound,$NEWLINE$That breathes upon a bank of violets,$NEWLINE$Stealing and giving odor. Enough, no more.$NEWLINE$'Tis not so sweet now as it was before.$NEWLINE$O spirit of love, how quick and fresh art thou,$NEWLINE$That, notwithstanding thy capacity$NEWLINE$Receiveth as the sea, nought enters there,$NEWLINE$Of what validity and pitch soe'er,$NEWLINE$But falls into abatement and low price$NEWLINE$Even in a minute. So full of shapes is fancy$NEWLINE$That it alone is high fantastical.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$If it’s true that music makes people more in love, keep playing. Give me too much of it, so I’ll get sick of it and stop loving. Play that part again! It sounded sad. Oh, it sounded like a sweet breeze blowing gently over a bank of violets, taking their scent with it. That’s enough. Stop. It doesn’t sound as sweet as it did before. Oh, love is so restless! It makes you want everything, but it makes you sick of things a minute later, no matter how good they are. Love is so vivid and fantastical that nothing compares to it.

paragraphs.original: CURIO$NEWLINE$Will you go hunt, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: CURIO$NEWLINE$Do you want to go hunting, my lord?

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$What, Curio?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Hunting what, Curio?

paragraphs.original: CURIO$NEWLINE$The hart.
paragraphs.translated:
CURIO$NEWLINE$The
hart.$NEWLINE$hart$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Why, so I do, the noblest that I have.$NEWLINE$Oh, when mine eyes did see Olivia first,$NEWLINE$Methought she purged the air of pestilence.$NEWLINE$That instant was I turned into a hart,$NEWLINE$And my desires, like fell and cruel hounds,$NEWLINE$E'er since pursue me.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$That’s what I’m doing—only it’s my heart that’s being hunted. Oh, when I first saw Olivia, it seemed like she made the air around her sweeter and purer. In that instant I was transformed into a hart, and my desire for her has hounded me like a pack of vicious dogs.$NEWLINE$my

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter VALENTINE$NEWLINE$VALENTINE
paragraphs.translated: VALENTINE enters.$NEWLINE$VALENTINE

paragraphs.original: How now! What news from her?
paragraphs.translated: What’s going on? What have you heard from her?

paragraphs.original: VALENTINE$NEWLINE$So please my lord, I might not be admitted,$NEWLINE$But from her handmaid do return this answer:$NEWLINE$The element itself, till seven years' heat,$NEWLINE$Shall not behold her face at ample view,$NEWLINE$But like a cloistress, she will veiled walk$NEWLINE$And water once a day her chamber round$NEWLINE$With eye-offending brine—all this to season$NEWLINE$A brother’s dead love, which she would keep fresh$NEWLINE$And lasting in her sad remembrance.
paragraphs.translated: VALENTINE$NEWLINE$I’m sorry, but they wouldn’t let me in. But I got the following answer from her handmaid. Olivia’s not going to show her face for the next seven years—not even to the sky itself. Instead, she’ll go around veiled like a nun, and once a day she’ll water her room with tears. She’s doing this out of love for her dead brother, whom she wants to keep fresh in her memory forever.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$O, she that hath a heart of that fine frame$NEWLINE$To pay this debt of love but to a brother,$NEWLINE$How will she love, when the rich golden shaft$NEWLINE$Hath killed the flock of all affections else$NEWLINE$That live in her, when liver, brain, and heart,$NEWLINE$These sovereign thrones, are all supplied, and filled$NEWLINE$Her sweet perfections with one self king!$NEWLINE$Away before me to sweet beds of flowers.$NEWLINE$Love thoughts lie rich when canopied with bowers.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Oh, if she loves her brother this much, think how she’ll love me when I finally win her over and make her forget all her other attachments! Her mind and heart will be ruled by one man alone—me! Take me to the garden. I need a beautiful place to sit and think about love.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter VIOLA, a CAPTAIN, and sailors$NEWLINE$VIOLA$NEWLINE$CAPTAIN
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA, a CAPTAIN, and sailors enter.$NEWLINE$VIOLA$NEWLINE$CAPTAIN

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$What country, friends, is this?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$What country is this, friends?

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$This is Illyria, lady.
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$This is Illyria, lady.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$And what should I do in Illyria?$NEWLINE$My brother he is in Elysium.$NEWLINE$Perchance he is not drown’d.—What think you, sailors?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$And what am I supposed to do in Illyria? My brother is in heaven. Or maybe there’s a chance he didn’t drown.—What do you think, sailors?

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$It is perchance that you yourself were saved.
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$It was a total fluke that you yourself were saved.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$O, my poor brother! And so perchance may he be.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Oh, my poor brother! But maybe by some fluke he was saved too.

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$True, madam. And, to comfort you with chance,$NEWLINE$Assure yourself, after our ship did split,$NEWLINE$When you and those poor number saved with you$NEWLINE$Hung on our driving boat, I saw your brother,$NEWLINE$Most provident in peril, bind himself,$NEWLINE$Courage and hope both teaching him the practice,$NEWLINE$To a strong mast that lived upon the sea,$NEWLINE$Where, like Arion on the dolphin’s back,$NEWLINE$I saw him hold acquaintance with the waves$NEWLINE$So long as I could see.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$It’s possible, ma'am. Don’t give up yet. When our ship was wrecked and you and a few other survivors were clinging onto our lifeboat, I saw your brother tie himself to a big mast floating in the sea. He was acting resourcefully and courageously in a dangerous situation. For as long as I could see him, he stayed afloat on the waves like
Arion on the dolphin’s back.$NEWLINE$Arion$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$(giving him money)$NEWLINE$(giving him money)$NEWLINE$For saying so, there’s gold.$NEWLINE$Mine own escape unfoldeth to my hope,$NEWLINE$Whereto thy speech serves for authority,$NEWLINE$The like of him. Know’st thou this country?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$(giving him money) Thank you for saying that—here’s some money to express my gratitude. Since I survived, it’s easier for me to imagine he survived too, and what you say gives me a reason to hope for the best. Do you know this area we’re in?$NEWLINE$(giving him money)

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$Ay, madam, well, for I was bred and born$NEWLINE$Not three hours' travel from this very place.
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$Yes, ma'am, I know it well. I was born and raised less than three hours from here.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Who governs here?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Who’s the ruler here?

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$A noble duke, in nature$NEWLINE$As in name.
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$A duke who is noble in name and character.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$What is his name?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$What’s his name?

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$Orsino.
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$Orsino.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Orsino. I have heard my father name him.$NEWLINE$He was a bachelor then.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Orsino. I’ve heard my father mention him. When I first heard about him, he was still a bachelor.

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$And so is now, or was so very late.$NEWLINE$For but a month ago I went from hence,$NEWLINE$And then ’twas fresh in murmur—as, you know,$NEWLINE$What great ones do the less will prattle of—$NEWLINE$That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$He’s still a bachelor, or at least he was a month ago, when I left. But there was a rumor—you know, people always gossip about royalty—that he was in love with the beautiful Olivia.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$What’s she?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Who’s she?

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$A virtuous maid, the daughter of a count$NEWLINE$That died some twelvemonth since, then leaving her$NEWLINE$In the protection of his son, her brother,$NEWLINE$Who shortly also died, for whose dear love,$NEWLINE$They say, she hath abjured the company$NEWLINE$And sight of men.
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$A virtuous young woman, the daughter of a count who died last year. Her brother had custody of her for a while, but then he died too. They say she’s totally sworn off men now, in memory of her brother.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Oh, that I served that lady$NEWLINE$And might not be delivered to the world,$NEWLINE$Till I had made mine own occasion mellow,$NEWLINE$What my estate is.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I wish I could work for that lady! It’d be a good way to hide from the world until the time was right to identify myself.

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$That were hard to compass,$NEWLINE$Because she will admit no kind of suit,$NEWLINE$No, not the duke’s.
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$That would be hard to do. She won’t allow anyone in to see her, not even the duke’s messengers.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$There is a fair behavior in thee, captain,$NEWLINE$And though that nature with a beauteous wall$NEWLINE$Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee$NEWLINE$I will believe thou hast a mind that suits$NEWLINE$With this thy fair and outward character.$NEWLINE$I prithee—and I’ll pay thee bounteously—$NEWLINE$Conceal me what I am, and be my aid$NEWLINE$For such disguise as haply shall become$NEWLINE$The form of my intent. I’ll serve this duke.$NEWLINE$Thou shall present me as an eunuch to him.$NEWLINE$It may be worth thy pains, for I can sing$NEWLINE$And speak to him in many sorts of music$NEWLINE$That will allow me very worth his service.$NEWLINE$What else may hap to time I will commit.$NEWLINE$Only shape thou thy silence to my wit.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$You seem to be a good person, captain, and although people who look beautiful are often corrupt inside, I believe that you have a beautiful mind to go with your good looks and manners. Please—and I’ll pay you plenty for this—help me conceal my identity, and find me the right disguise so I can look the way I want. I want to be this Duke’s servant. You’ll introduce me to him as a eunuch. You won’t be wasting your time, because I really can sing and talk to him about many different kinds of music, so he’ll be happy to have me in his service. Only time will tell what will happen after that—just please keep quiet about what I’m trying to do.

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$Be you his eunuch, and your mute I’ll be.$NEWLINE$When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$I won’t say a word. You can be a eunuch, but I’ll be mute. I swear on my life I won’t tell your secret.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I thank thee. Lead me on.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Thank you. Show me the way.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA enter.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$What a plague means my niece, to take the death of her brother thus? I am sure care’s an enemy to life.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$What’s wrong with my niece? Why is she reacting so strangely to her brother’s death? Grief is bad for people’s health.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o' nights. Your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions to your ill hours.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$For God’s sake, Sir Toby, you’ve got to come home earlier at night. My lady Olivia, your niece, disapproves of your late-night partying.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Why, let her except, before excepted.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Well, she can get used to it.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Ay, but you must confine yourself within the modest limits of order.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Yes, but you need to keep yourself within the limits of order and decency.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Confine? I’ll confine myself no finer than I am. These clothes are good enough to drink in, and so be these boots too. An they be not, let them hang themselves in their own straps.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Keep myself? The only thing I’m keeping myself in is the clothes I’m wearing. They’re good enough to drink in, and so are these boots. If they aren’t, they can go hang themselves by their own laces!

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$That quaffing and drinking will undo you: I heard my lady talk of it yesterday, and of a foolish knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$You’re going to destroy yourself with all this drinking. Lady Olivia said so yesterday. She also mentioned some stupid knight you brought in one night as a possible husband for her.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Ay, he.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Yes, that’s the one.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$He’s as tall a man as any ’s in Illyria.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$He’s as
tall as a man in Illyria.$NEWLINE$tall$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$What’s that to the purpose?
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$What does his height have to do with anything?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Why, he has an income of three thousand ducats a year.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Ay, but he’ll have but a year in all these ducats. He’s a very fool and a prodigal.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$I bet he’ll spend his whole inheritance in a year. He’s a fool and a spendthrift.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Fie, that you’ll say so! He plays o' the viol-de-gamboys, and speaks three or four languages word for word without book, and hath all the good gifts of nature.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$You shouldn’t talk about him like that! He plays the violin and speaks three or four languages word for word without a dictionary. He has all of nature’s best gifts.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$He hath indeed, almost natural, for besides that he’s a fool, he’s a great quarreler, and but that he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he hath in quarreling, ’tis thought among the prudent he would quickly have the gift of a grave.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Right—he’s a natural-born idiot. Besides being a fool, he’s argumentative. If he didn’t have the coward’s gift for backing down from a fight, they say he’d be dead by now.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$By this hand, they are scoundrels and substractors that say so of him. Who are they?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Anyone who says that is a lying piece of garbage. Who said that?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$They that add, moreover, he’s drunk nightly in your company.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$The same people who say he gets drunk with you every night.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$With drinking healths to my niece. I’ll drink to her as long as there is a passage in my throat and drink in Illyria. He’s a coward and a coistrel that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn o' th' toe like a parish top. What, wench! Castiliano vulgo, for here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.$NEWLINE$Castiliano vulgo
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$We only drink toasts to my niece. I’ll drink to her as long as there’s a hole in my throat and booze in Illyria. Anyone who refuses to drink to my niece until his brain spins around like a merry-go-round is scum. But speak of the devil, here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW enters.$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Sir Toby Belch! How now, Sir Toby Belch!
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Sir Toby Belch! How are you, Sir Toby Belch?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Sweet Sir Andrew!
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Sweet Sir Andrew!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(to MARIA) Bless you, fair shrew.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(to MARIA) And hello to you, my little wench.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$And you too, sir.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Hello, sir.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Chat her up, Sir Andrew. Chat her up.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$What’s that?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$What?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$My niece’s chambermaid.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$This is my niece’s maid.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$My dear Miss Chat-her-up, I look forward to getting to know you better.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$My name is Mary, sir.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$My name is Mary, sir.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Good Mistress Mary Accost—
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Miss Mary Chat-her-up—

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$You mistake, knight. “Accost” is front her, board her, woo her, assail her.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$No, you’ve got it wrong. When I said “chat her up,” I wasn’t saying her name. I was telling you to go after her, woo her, confront her.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$By my troth, I would not undertake her in this company. Is that the meaning of “accost”?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Good heavens, I’d never do that with people watching. Is that really what you meant?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Fare you well, gentlemen. (she starts to exit)$NEWLINE$(she starts to exit)
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Goodbye, gentlemen. (she starts to exit)$NEWLINE$(she starts to exit)

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst never draw sword again.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$She’s leaving. If you let her go this easily, Sir Andrew, you don’t deserve to ever use your sword again.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$An you part so, mistress, I would I might never draw sword again. Fair lady, do you think you have fools in hand?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$If you leave like this, my dear, I won’t ever use my sword again. I’m not just talking nonsense to you, I mean everything I say. Do you think you’ve got a couple of fools on your hands here?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Sir, I have not you by the hand.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$I’m not holding your hand, sir.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Marry, but you shall have, and here’s my hand.$NEWLINE$(he offers her his hand)$NEWLINE$(he offers her his hand)
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$But you will. Here’s my hand. (he offers her his hand)$NEWLINE$(he offers her his hand)

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$(taking his hand) Now, sir, thought is free. I pray you, bring your hand to the buttery-bar and let it drink.$NEWLINE$(taking his hand)
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$(taking his hand) A girl’s got a right to her opinions. Take your hand to a bar and put a drink in it.$NEWLINE$(taking his hand)

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Wherefore, sweetheart? What’s your metaphor?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Why, sweetheart? Is there a hidden meaning in this?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$It’s dry, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA$NEWLINE$You’re not holding a glass. Your hand is
dry, sir.$NEWLINE$dry$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Why, I think so. I am not such an ass, but I can keep my hand dry. But what’s your jest?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Well, I hope so. I’m not such an idiot that I can’t keep my hands dry. But I don’t get it—what’s the joke?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$A dry jest, sir.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Just a bit of my dry humor, sir.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Are you full of them?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Are you always so funny?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers' ends. Marry, now I let go your hand, I am barren.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Yes, I’ve got a handful of jokes. But oops, when I let go of your hand, I let go of the biggest joke of all.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MARIA exits.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$O knight, thou lackest a cup of canary. When did I see thee so put down?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Sir, you need a drink. When has anyone ever put you down like that.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Never in your life, I think, unless you see canary put me down. Methinks sometimes I have no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man has. But I am a great eater of beef, and I believe that does harm to my wit.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Never. I’ve only been that far down when I’ve drunk myself under the table. Sometimes I think I’m no smarter than average. I eat a lot of red meat, and maybe that makes me stupid.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$No question.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Absolutely.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$An I thought that, I’d forswear it. I’ll ride home tomorrow,$NEWLINE$Sir Toby.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$If I really believed that, I’d give up red meat totally. By the way, I’m going home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Pourquoi, my dear knight?$NEWLINE$Pourquoi,
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Pourquoi, my friend?$NEWLINE$Pourquoi$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$What is “pourquoi”? Do, or not do? I would I had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing, and bear-baiting. O, had I but followed the arts!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$What does “pourquoi” mean? Does it mean I will or I won’t? Oh, I wish I’d spent as much time learning languages as I spent on fencing, dancing, and
bear-baiting! If only I’d taken school more seriously!$NEWLINE$“pourquoi”$NEWLINE$bear-baiting$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$You’d have a great hairstyle if you had.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Why, would that have mended my hair?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Why, would that have fixed my hair?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Past question, for thou seest it will not curl by nature.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Oh, no question—it won’t style itself.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$But it becomes me well enough, does ’t not?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$But my hair looks good anyway, doesn’t it?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Excellent. It hangs like flax on a distaff. And I hope to see a housewife take thee between her legs and spin it off.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$It looks great. It hangs like an old worn-out mop. Some woman should give you syphilis so you go bald.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Faith, I’ll home tomorrow, Sir Toby. Your niece will not be seen. Or if she be, it’s four to one she’ll none of me. The count himself here hard by woos her.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Listen, I’m going home tomorrow, Sir Toby. Your niece is refusing to see anyone, and even if she saw me, ten to one she’d want nothing to do with me. That duke who lives nearby is courting her.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$She’ll none o' the count. She’ll not match above her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit. I have heard her swear ’t. Tut, there’s life in ’t, man.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$She’s not interested in the duke. She doesn’t want to marry anyone of higher social rank than her, or anyone richer, older, or smarter. I’ve heard her say that. So cheer up, there’s still hope for you, man.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I’ll stay a month longer. I am a fellow o' th' strangest mind i' th' world. I delight in masques and revels sometimes altogether.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$All right, I’ll stay another month. Ah, I’m an odd kind of guy. Sometimes all I want to do is see plays and go out dancing.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Are you good at those kinds of things?

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the degree of my betters. And yet I will not compare with an old man.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Yes, as good as any man in Illyria, except for the ones who are better at it than I am. I’m not as good as someone who’s been dancing for years.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$How good are you at those fast dances?

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Faith, I can cut a caper.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Believe me, I can
cut a caper.$NEWLINE$cut a caper$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$And I can cut the mutton to ’t.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$And I can cut some meat to go with your
capers.$NEWLINE$capers$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$And I think I have the back-trick simply as strong as any man in Illyria.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$And I can do that fancy backward step as well as any man in Illyria.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Wherefore are these things hid? Wherefore have these gifts a curtain before 'em? Are they like to take dust, like Mistress Mall’s picture? Why dost thou not go to church in a galliard and come home in a coranto? My very walk should be a jig. I would not so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace. What dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues in? I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy leg, it was formed under the star of a galliard.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Why do you hide these things? Why do you keep these talents behind a curtain? Are they likely to get dusty? Why don’t you go off to church dancing one way, and come home dancing another way? If I had your talents, I’d be dancing a jig every time I walked down the street. I wouldn’t even pee without dancing a waltz. What are you thinking? Is this the kind of world where we hide our accomplishments? You’re a born dancer. Look how shapely your legs are.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Ay, ’tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a dun-colored stock. Shall we set about some revels?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$That’s true. They’re strong, and they look pretty good in brown tights. Should we throw a little dance party?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$What shall we do else? Were we not born under Taurus?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Why not? Weren’t we both born under Taurus?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Taurus! That’s sides and heart.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Taurus! That governs the torso and heart, doesn’t it?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$No, sir, it is legs and thighs. Let me see the caper. (SIR$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$ANDREW dances) Ha, higher! Ha, ha, excellent!$NEWLINE$dances)
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$No, the legs and thighs. Let me see you dance. (SIR ANDREW dances) Ha, higher! Ha, ha, excellent!$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$dances)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter VALENTINE and VIOLA in man’s attire, as Cesario$NEWLINE$VALENTINE$NEWLINE$VIOLA
paragraphs.translated: VALENTINE enters with VIOLA, who is dressed as a young man named Cesario.$NEWLINE$VALENTINE$NEWLINE$VIOLA

paragraphs.original: VALENTINE$NEWLINE$If the duke continue these favors towards you, Cesario, you are like to be much advanced. He hath known you but three days, and already you are no stranger.
paragraphs.translated: VALENTINE$NEWLINE$If the Duke keeps treating you so well, Cesario, you’ll go far. He’s only known you for three days, but he’s already treating you like a close friend.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$You either fear his humor or my negligence, that you call in question the continuance of his love. Is he inconstant, sir, in his favors?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$When you wonder whether he’ll keep treating me well, it makes me think his mood might change—or else I’ll mess up somehow. Do his feelings toward people change suddenly?

paragraphs.original: VALENTINE$NEWLINE$No, believe me.
paragraphs.translated: VALENTINE$NEWLINE$No, not at all.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I thank you. Here comes the count.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Thanks for telling me. Here comes the Duke now.

paragraphs.original: Enter ORSINO, CURIO, and attendants$NEWLINE$ORSINO$NEWLINE$CURIO
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO, CURIO, and attendants enter.$NEWLINE$ORSINO$NEWLINE$CURIO

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Who saw Cesario, ho?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Has anyone seen Cesario?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$On your attendance, my lord, here.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I’m right here, my lord, at your service.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA and attendants)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and attendants)$NEWLINE$Stand you a while aloof. (to VIOLA) Cesario,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Thou know’st no less but all. I have unclasped$NEWLINE$To thee the book even of my secret soul.$NEWLINE$Therefore, good youth, address thy gait unto her;$NEWLINE$Be not denied access, stand at her doors,$NEWLINE$And tell them there thy fixed foot shall grow$NEWLINE$Till thou have audience.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA and attendants) We’ll need some privacy for a little while. (to VIOLA) Cesario, I want a word with you. You know everything about me. I’ve told you all the secrets of my soul. So please go to her house; if they don’t let you in, plant yourself outside her door and tell them you won’t leave until they let you see her.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and attendants)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Sure, my noble lord,$NEWLINE$If she be so abandoned to her sorrow$NEWLINE$As it is spoke, she never will admit me.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$But my lord, I’m sure that if she’s as depressed as people say, she’ll never let me in.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Be clamorous, and leap all civil bounds,$NEWLINE$Rather than make unprofited return.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Be loud and obnoxious. Do whatever it takes, just get the job done.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Say I do speak with her, my lord, what then?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Well, all right, let’s say hypothetically that I do get a chance to speak with her, my lord. What do I do then?

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$O, then unfold the passion of my love,$NEWLINE$Surprise her with discourse of my dear faith:$NEWLINE$It shall become thee well to act my woes;$NEWLINE$She will attend it better in thy youth$NEWLINE$Than in a nuncio’s of more grave aspect.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Tell her how passionately I love her. Overwhelm her with examples of how faithful I am. The best thing would be to act out my feelings for her. She’ll pay more attention to a young guy like you than to an older, more serious man.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I think not so, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I don’t think so, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Dear lad, believe it.$NEWLINE$For they shall yet belie thy happy years$NEWLINE$That say thou art a man. Diana’s lip$NEWLINE$Is not more smooth and rubious. Thy small pipe$NEWLINE$Is as the maiden’s organ, shrill and sound,$NEWLINE$And all is semblative a woman’s part.$NEWLINE$I know thy constellation is right apt$NEWLINE$For this affair. (to CURIO and attendants)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and attendants)$NEWLINE$Some four or five attend him.$NEWLINE$All, if you will, for I myself am best$NEWLINE$When least in company. (to VIOLA) Prosper well in this,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And thou shalt live as freely as thy lord,$NEWLINE$To call his fortunes thine.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$My boy, it’s true. Anyone who says you’re a man must not notice how young you are. Your lips are as smooth and red as the goddess Diana’s. Your soft voice is like a young girl’s, high and clear, and the rest of you is pretty feminine too. I know you’re the right person for this job. (to CURIO and attendants) Four or five of you go along with him, or you can all go if you like. I’m most comfortable when I’m alone. (to VIOLA) If you succeed at this assignment, I’ll reward you well. My whole fortune will be yours.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and attendants)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I’ll do my best$NEWLINE$To woo your lady—(aside) Yet, a barful strife—$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Whoe'er I woo, myself would be his wife.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I’ll do my best to make this lady love you.—(to herself) But what a tough task!—I have to go matchmaking for the man I want to marry myself!$NEWLINE$—(to herself)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter MARIA and the FOOL$NEWLINE$MARIA$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA and the
FOOL enter.$NEWLINE$MARIA$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Nay, either tell me where thou hast been, or I will not open my lips so wide as a bristle may enter in way of thy excuse. My lady will hang thee for thy absence.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$No. Either tell me where you’ve been, or I won’t make any excuses for you to Lady Olivia. Lady Olivia will have you executed for not showing up.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Let her hang me. He that is well hanged in this world needs to fear no colors.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$So let her execute me. Anyone who’s executed doesn’t have to be afraid of anything he sees.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Make that good.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$How do you know?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$He shall see none to fear.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well, he’ll be dead, so he won’t see anything.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$A good lenten answer. I can tell thee where that saying was born, of “I fear no colors.”
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$That’s a lame answer. By the way, I know where you get all your brave talk about not being afraid of anything.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Where, good Mistress Mary?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Where, good Miss Mary?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$In the wars. And that may you be bold to say in your foolery.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$From soldiers. But you’ll never see the front lines. It’s easy for you to talk about bravery, working as a fool in this palace.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well, God give them wisdom that have it. And those that are fools, let them use their talents.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well, we all have our special gifts. Some people are born wise; those of us who were meant to be fools should do what they do best.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent. Or to be turned away, is not that as good as a hanging to you?
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$But still, she’s going to kill you for being gone so long. Or at least fire you. And wouldn’t that be as bad for you as being killed?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Many a good hanging prevents a bad marriage, and, for turning away, let summer bear it out.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Sometimes getting killed is a good way to avoid getting married. And as for being fired, it’s summer, so it won’t be that bad to be homeless.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$You are resolute, then?
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$You’ve made up your mind, then?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Not so, neither, but I am resolved on two points.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, but I’ve made up my mind on two points.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$That if one break, the other will hold. Or, if both break, your gaskins fall.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Ah yes, the two points where your suspenders are attached to your buttons. If one breaks, the other will hold, but if both points break, your pants will fall down.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Apt, in good faith, very apt. Well, go thy way. If Sir Toby would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a piece of Eve’s flesh as any in Illyria.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Clever, very clever. Well, go along now. You’d be the funniest person in Illyria… if Sir Toby ever stopped drinking.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Peace, you rogue, no more o' that. Here comes my lady.$NEWLINE$Make your excuse wisely, you were best.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Shut up, you troublemaker, no more of that. Here comes my lady. If you know what’s good for you, you’ll think up some good excuse for being away so long.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MARIA exits.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(aside) Wit, an ’t be thy will, put me into good fooling! Those wits, that think they have thee, do very oft prove fools. And I, that am sure I lack thee, may pass for a wise man. For what says Quinapalus? “Better a witty fool, than a foolish wit.”$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL$NEWLINE$(to himself) Please, let me think of something funny to say now! Smart people who think they’re witty often turn out to be fools, but I know I’m not witty, so I might pass for smart. What did that philosopher
Quinapalus say? Ah yes, “A witty fool’s better than a foolish wit.”$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$Quinapalus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter OLIVIA with MALVOLIO with attendants$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA enters with MALVOLIO and attendants.$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: God bless thee, lady!
paragraphs.translated: Greetings to you, madam!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Take the fool away.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Get that fool out of here.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Do you not hear, fellows? Take away the lady.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Didn’t you hear her, guys? Get the lady out of here.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Go to, you’re a dry fool. I’ll no more of you. Besides, you grow dishonest.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Oh, go away, you’re a boring fool. I don’t want to have anything to do with you anymore. Besides, you’ve gotten unreliable.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Two faults, madonna, that drink and good counsel will amend. For give the dry fool drink, then is the fool not dry. Bid the dishonest man mend himself. If he mend, he is no longer dishonest. If he cannot, let the botcher mend him. Anything that’s mended is but patched. Virtue that transgresses is but patched with sin, and sin that amends is but patched with virtue. If that this simple syllogism will serve, so. If it will not, what remedy? As there is no true cuckold but calamity, so beauty’s a flower. The lady bade take away the fool. Therefore, I say again, take her away.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Madam, those are two character flaws that a little booze and some common sense can fix. If you hand a drink to a sober fool, he won’t be thirsty anymore. If you tell a bad man to mend his wicked ways, and he does, he won’t be bad anymore. If he cannot, let the tailor mend him. Anything that’s mended is only patched up. A good person who does something wrong is only patched up with sin. And a sinner who does something good is only patched up with goodness. If this logic works, that’s great. If not, what can you do about it? Since the only real betrayed husband in the world is the one deserted by Lady Luck—because we’re all married to her—beauty is a flower. The lady gave orders to take away the fool, so I’m telling you again, take her away.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Sir, I bade them take away you.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I told them to take you away.$NEWLINE$you

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Misprision in the highest degree! Lady, Cucullus non facit monachum—that’s as much to say as I wear not motley in my brain. Good madonna, give me leave to prove you a fool.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Oh, what a big mistake! Madam, you can’t judge a book by its cover. I mean, I may look like a fool, but my mind’s sharp. Please let me prove you’re a fool.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Can you do it?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Can you do that?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Dexterously, good madonna.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Easily, madam.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Make your proof.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Then go ahead and prove it.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$I must catechise you for it, madonna. Good my mouse of virtue, answer me.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I’ll have to ask you some questions, madam. Please answer, my good little student.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Well, sir, for want of other idleness, I’ll bide your proof.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I’m listening to you only because I’ve got nothing better to do.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Good madonna, why mournest thou?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$My dear madam, why are you in mourning?

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Good fool, for my brother’s death.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$My dear fool, because my brother died.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$I think his soul is in hell, madonna.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I think his soul’s in hell, my lady.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I know his soul is in heaven, fool.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I know his soul’s in heaven, fool.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brother’s soul being in heaven. Take away the fool, gentlemen.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Then you’re a fool for being sad that your brother’s soul is in heaven. Take away this fool, gentlemen.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What think you of this fool, Malvolio? Doth he not mend?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What do you think of this fool, Malvolio? Isn’t he getting funnier?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Yes, and shall do till the pangs of death shake him. Infirmity, that decays the wise, doth ever make the better fool.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Yes, and he’ll keep getting funnier till he dies. Old age always makes people act funny—even wise people, but fools more than anybody.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the better increasing your folly! Sir Toby will be sworn that I am no fox, but he will not pass his word for two pence that you are no fool.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I hope you go senile soon, sir, so you can become a more foolish fool! Sir Toby would bet a fortune that I’m not smart, but he wouldn’t bet two cents that you’re not a fool.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$How say you to that, Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What do you say to that, Malvolio?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a barren rascal.$NEWLINE$I saw him put down the other day with an ordinary fool that
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$I’m surprised you enjoy the company of this stupid troublemaker. The other day I saw him defeated in a

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: has no more brain than a stone. Look you now, he’s out of his guard already. Unless you laugh and minister occasion to him, he is gagged. I protest I take these wise men that crow so at these set kind of fools no better than the fools' zanies.
paragraphs.translated: battle of wits by an ordinary jester with no more brains than a rock. Look at him, he’s at a loss for words already. Unless he’s got somebody laughing at him, he can’t think of anything to say. I swear, anyone smart who laughs at these courts jesters is nothing but a jester’s apprentice.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Oh, you are sick of self-love, Malvolio, and taste with a distempered appetite. To be generous, guiltless, and of free disposition is to take those things for bird-bolts that you deem cannon-bullets. There is no slander in an allowed fool, though he do nothing but rail. Nor no railing in a known discreet man, though he do nothing but reprove.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Malvolio, your vanity is damaging your good taste. If you were generous, innocent, and good-natured, you wouldn’t get so upset by what the fool says. You’d think of his wisecracks as harmless little firecrackers, not hurtful bullets. A court jester isn’t really criticizing people, even if he does nothing but make fun of them all day long. And a wise person doesn’t make fun of people, even if all he does is criticize them.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou speakest well of fools!
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$You speak so highly of fools! I hope the god of deception rewards you by making you a wonderful liar.

paragraphs.original: Enter MARIA$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: MARIA enters.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Madam, there is at the gate a young gentleman much desires to speak with you.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Madam, there’s a young gentleman at the gate who really wants to speak to you.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$From the Count Orsino, is it?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Was he sent by Count Orsino?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$I know not, madam. 'Tis a fair young man, and well attended.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$I don’t know, madam. He’s a good-looking young man, and there are a lot of people with him.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Who of my people hold him in delay?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Who’s talking to him now?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Sir Toby, madam, your relative.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Fetch him off, I pray you. He speaks nothing but madman.$NEWLINE$Fie on him!
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Send Toby away, please. He talks nothing but nonsense.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit MARIA$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: MARIA exits.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: Go you, Malvolio. If it be a suit from the count, I am sick, or not at home. What you will, to dismiss it.
paragraphs.translated: Go out and talk to this visitor, Malvolio. If he’s got a message from the count, tell him I’m sick, or not home. Tell him anything you want, as long as you make him go away.

paragraphs.original: Exit MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO exits.$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: Now you see, sir, how your fooling grows old, and people dislike it.
paragraphs.translated: Now you see how your fooling gets boring, and people don’t like it.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Thou hast spoke for us, madonna, as if thy eldest son should be a fool, whose skull Jove cram with brains, for— here he comes—one of thy kin has a most weak pia mater.$NEWLINE$pia mater.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Madam, you’ve spoken so highly of us fools, you’d think your oldest son was going into that line of work. I hope God crams his skull full of brains, because here comes one of your relatives who’s pretty weak in the head.

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH enters.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$By mine honor, half-drunk. What is he at the gate, cousin?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I swear, he’s half drunk already. Who’s that at the gate, uncle?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$A gentleman.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$A gentleman.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$A gentleman? What gentleman?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$A gentleman? What gentleman?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$'Tis a gentleman here—a plague o' these pickle herring!$NEWLINE$How now, sot!
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$There’s some gentleman out there.—(belching) Damn these pickled herring! They upset my stomach. How’s it going, fool?$NEWLINE$(belching)

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Good Sir Toby!
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Good Sir Toby!

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Cousin, cousin, how have you come so early by this lethargy?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Uncle, uncle, how are you already so brain-dead so early in the day?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Lechery! I defy lechery. There’s one at the gate.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Brain-dead! Nonsense. I defy brain-death! I told you, someone’s at the gate.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Ay, marry, what is he?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Yes, but who is he?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Let him be the devil, an he will, I care not. Give me faith, say I. Well, it’s all one.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Let him be the devil if he wants to, I don’t care. God will protect me. What do I care who it is?

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH exits.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What’s a drunken man like, fool?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Tell me what a drunk is like, fool.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Like a drowned man, a fool and a madman. One draught above heat makes him a fool, the second mads him, and a third drowns him.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$He’s a fool, a madman, and a drowned man. The first drink makes him a fool, the second makes him crazy, and the third drowns him.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Go thou and seek the crowner, and let him sit o' my coz. For he’s in the third degree of drink, he’s drowned. Go look after him.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Go find the coroner and tell him to perform an inquest on my uncle, because he’s in the third degree of drunkenness—he’s drowned. Go take care of him.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$He is but mad yet, madonna, and the fool shall look to the madman.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$He’s still only in the crazy phase. The fool will go take care of the madman.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The FOOL exits.$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: Enter MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO enters.$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Madam, yond young fellow swears he will speak with you. I told him you were sick. He takes on him to understand so much, and therefore comes to speak with you. I told him you were asleep. He seems to have a foreknowledge of that too, and therefore comes to speak with you. What is to be said to him, lady? He’s fortified against any denial.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Madam, that young man out there says he’s got to speak to you. I told him you were sick. He claimed he knew that, and that’s why he’s come to speak with you. I told him you were asleep. He claimed to know that already too, and said that’s the reason he’s come to speak with you. What can I say to him, lady? He’s got an answer for everything.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Tell him he shall not speak with me.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Tell him he’s not going to speak with me.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Has been told so, and he says he’ll stand at your door like a sheriff’s post, and be the supporter to a bench, but he’ll speak with you.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$I told him that. He says he’ll stand at your door like a signpost or a bench until he speaks with you.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What kind o' man is he?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What kind of man is he?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Why, of mankind.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Just a man, like any other.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What manner of man?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$But what’s he like?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Of very ill manner. He’ll speak with you, will you or no.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$He’s very rude. He insists he’ll speak with you whether you want him to or not.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Of what personage and years is he?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What does he look like? How old is he?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for a boy, as a squash is before ’tis a peascod, or a codling when ’tis almost an apple. 'Tis with him in standing water, between boy and man. He is very well-favored, and he speaks very shrewishly. One would think his mother’s milk were scarce out of him.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Not old enough to be a man, but not young enough to be a boy. He’s like a bud before it becomes a pea pod, or like a little green apple before it gets big and ripe. He’s somewhere between boy and man. He’s very handsome and speaks well, but he’s very young. He looks like he just recently stopped breastfeeding.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Let him approach. Call in my gentlewoman.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Show him in. Call in my maid.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Gentlewoman, my lady calls.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Maria, our lady wants you.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO exits.$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: Enter MARIA$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: MARIA enters.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Give me my veil. Come, throw it o'er my face. (OLIVIA puts on a veil) We’ll once more hear Orsino’s embassy.$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$puts$NEWLINE$on a veil)
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Give me my veil. Come, put it over my face. (OLIVIA puts on her veil) We’re going to hear Orsino’s pleas again.$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$puts on her veil)

paragraphs.original: Enter VIOLA, with attendants$NEWLINE$VIOLA
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA enters, dressed as CESARIO, with attendants.$NEWLINE$VIOLA$NEWLINE$CESARIO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$The honorable lady of the house, which is she?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Which one of you is the lady of the house?

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Speak to me. I shall answer for her. Your will?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$You can speak to me. I represent her. What do you want?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Most radiant, exquisite and unmatchable beauty—I pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the house, for I never saw her. I would be loath to cast away my speech, for besides that it is excellently well penned, I have taken great pains to con it. Good beauties, let me sustain no scorn. I am very comptible, even to the least sinister usage.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$What stunning, exquisite, and unmatchable beauty—but please, tell me if you’re the lady of the house, because I’ve never seen her. I’d hate to waste my speech on the wrong person, because It’s very well written and I spent a lot of time and energy memorizing it. Beautiful ladies, please don’t treat me badly. I’m very sensitive, and even the smallest bit of rudeness hurts my feelings.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Whence came you, sir?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Where do you come from, sir?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I can say little more than I have studied, and that question’s out of my part. Good gentle one, give me modest assurance if you be the lady of the house, that I may proceed in my speech.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I’m sorry, but I memorized what I’m supposed to say here today, and that question isn’t part of the speech I learned. Please, my lady, just confirm that you’re the lady of the house so I can get on with my speech.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Are you a comedian?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Are you an actor?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$No, my profound heart. And yet, by the very fangs of malice I swear, I am not that I play. Are you the lady of the house?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$No, madam. But I swear I’m not the person I’m playing. Are you the lady of the house?

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$If I do not usurp myself, I am.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I am, unless I somehow stole this role.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp yourself, for what is yours to bestow is not yours to reserve. But this is from my commission. I will on with my speech in your praise and then show you the heart of my message.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$If you’re the lady of the house, then it’s true you’re stealing your role, because what’s yours to give away is not yours to keep for yourself. But that’s not part of what I’m supposed to say. I’ll go on with my speech praising you, and then I’ll get to the point.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Come to what is important in ’t. I forgive you the praise.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Get to the point now. I’ll let you get away with skipping the praise.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Alas, I took great pains to study it, and ’tis poetical.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$That’s too bad, because I spent a long time memorizing it, and it’s poetic.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$It is the more like to be feigned. I pray you, keep it in. I heard you were saucy at my gates and allowed your approach rather to wonder at you than to hear you. If you be not mad, be gone. If you have reason, be brief. 'Tis not that time of moon with me to make one in so skipping a dialogue.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$That means it’s more likely to be fake. Please, keep it to yourself. I heard you were rude when you were standing outside my gate, and that’s the only reason I let you in. I was curious. But I don’t necessarily want to listen to you. If you’re just insane, then get out of here. If you’re in your right mind, get to the point. I’ve got no patience for lunacy at the moment, and I don’t want to waste my time on ridiculous conversations.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Will you hoist sail, sir? Here lies your way.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Ready to set sail, sir? The door’s right here.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$No, good swabber, I am to hull here a little longer. Some mollification for your giant, sweet lady.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$No, this boat’s docking here a bit longer, little sailor.—My lady, would you mind asking your giant here to back off a bit?

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Tell me your mind.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Tell me what you want.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I am a messenger.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I have a message to deliver.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Sure, you have some hideous matter to deliver, when the courtesy of it is so fearful. Speak your office.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$It must be a message about something horrible, since you deliver it so rudely. Tell me what it’s about.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$It alone concerns your ear. I bring no overture of war, no taxation of homage. I hold the olive in my hand. My words are as full of peace as matter.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$It’s about you. I’m not bringing any declarations of war or demands for cash. I’m coming in peace.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Yet you began rudely. What are you? What would you?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$But you began so rudely. Who are you? What do you want?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$The rudeness that hath appeared in me have I learned from my entertainment. What I am and what I would are as secret as maidenhead. To your ears, divinity. To any other’s, profanation.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$If I seemed rude, it’s because of how badly I was treated when I got here. Who I am and what I want are a secret. You’re the only one I can share the secret with. It’s sacred, just for you. It’s not for anyone else to hear.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Give us the place alone. We will hear this divinity.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Everyone, please leave us alone for a moment. I’ve got a “sacred” secret to hear.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt MARIA and attendants$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: MARIA and attendants exit.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: Now, sir, what is your text?
paragraphs.translated: Now, sir, what’s this holy secret you wanted to tell me?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Most sweet lady—
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Most sweet lady—

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$A comfortable doctrine, and much may be said of it. Where lies your text?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Oh, “sweet”! It sounds like a nice and gentle kind of faith. Where’s the passage of holy scripture that you’re basing your sermon on?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$In Orsino’s bosom.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$In Orsino’s heart.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$In his bosom? In what chapter of his bosom?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$In his heart? In what chapter and verse of his heart?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$To answer by the method, in the first of his heart.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$The table of contents says it’s in the first chapter of his heart.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Oh, I have read it. It is heresy. Have you no more to say?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Oh, I’ve read that. That’s not holy, it’s heresy. Do you have anything else to say?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Good madam, let me see your face.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Madam, please let me see your face.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Have you any commission from your lord to negotiate with my face? You are now out of your text. But we will draw the curtain and show you the picture. Look you, sir, such a one I was this present. Is ’t not well done?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Has your lord given you any orders to negotiate with my face? I don’t think so. You’re overstepping your bounds now. But I’ll open the curtain and let you see the picture. Look, sir, this is a portrait of me as I am at this particular moment. It’s pretty well done, isn’t it?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA removes her veil$NEWLINE$OLIVIA
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA takes off her veil.$NEWLINE$OLIVIA

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Excellently done, if God did all.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$It was done excellently, if it’s all-natural, the way God made it.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$'Tis in grain, sir. 'Twill endure wind and weather.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Oh, it’s all-natural, sir. Wind and rain can’t wash it off.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$'Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white$NEWLINE$Nature’s own sweet and cunning hand laid on.$NEWLINE$Lady, you are the cruel’st she alive$NEWLINE$If you will lead these graces to the grave$NEWLINE$And leave the world no copy.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$That’s true beauty. Mother Nature herself painted your skin so white and your lips so red. My lady, you’d be the cruelest woman alive if you let your beauty die with you, with no children to inherit your good looks for future generations to enjoy.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted. I will give out divers schedules of my beauty. It shall be inventoried, and every particle and utensil labeled to my will: as, item, two lips indifferent red; item, two grey eyes, with lids to them; item, one neck, one chin, and so forth. Were you sent hither to praise me?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Oh, I’d never be that cruel. I’ll definitely do as you say and leave my beauty for the rest of the world to enjoy. I’ll write out a detailed inventory of my beauty and label every part. For example—item: two lips, ordinary red. Item: two gray eyes, with lids on them. Item: one neck, one chin, and so on. Anyway, were you sent here just to tell me I’m beautiful?$NEWLINE$item$NEWLINE$Item$NEWLINE$Item

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I see you what you are, you are too proud.$NEWLINE$But, if you were the devil, you are fair.$NEWLINE$My lord and master loves you. Oh, such love$NEWLINE$Could be but recompensed though you were crowned$NEWLINE$The nonpareil of beauty.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I see what you’re like. You’re proud. But you’d still be gorgeous even if you were as proud as the devil. My lord loves you. You should return a love as deep as his, even if you’re the most beautiful woman in the world.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$How does he love me?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$How does he love me?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$With adorations, fertile tears,$NEWLINE$With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$He adores you. He cries and groans and sighs.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Your lord does know my mind. I cannot love him.$NEWLINE$Yet I suppose him virtuous, know him noble,$NEWLINE$Of great estate, of fresh and stainless youth.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Your lord knows what I think. I can’t love him. I’m sure he’s a very nice man. I know he’s noble, rich, young, and with a fine reputation. People say he’s generous, well educated, and brave, and he’s very attractive.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: In voices well divulged, free, learned, and valiant;$NEWLINE$And in dimension and the shape of nature$NEWLINE$A gracious person. But yet I cannot love him;$NEWLINE$He might have took his answer long ago.
paragraphs.translated: But I just can’t love him. He should have resigned himself to that a long time ago.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$If I did love you in my master’s flame,$NEWLINE$With such a suffering, such a deadly life,$NEWLINE$In your denial I would find no sense;$NEWLINE$I would not understand it.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$If I loved you as passionately as my master does, and suffered like he does, your rejection would make no sense to me. I wouldn’t understand it.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Why, what would you?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What would you do about it?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Make me a willow cabin at your gate$NEWLINE$And call upon my soul within the house.$NEWLINE$Write loyal cantons of contemned love$NEWLINE$And sing them loud even in the dead of night.$NEWLINE$Halloo your name to the reverberate hills$NEWLINE$And make the babbling gossip of the air$NEWLINE$Cry out “Olivia!” Oh, you should not rest$NEWLINE$Between the elements of air and earth,$NEWLINE$But you should pity me.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I’d build myself a sad little cabin near your house, where my soul’s imprisoned. From that cabin I’d call out to my soul. I’d write sad songs about unrequited love and sing them loudly in the middle of the night. I’d shout your name to the hills and make the air echo with your name, “Olivia!” Oh, you wouldn’t be able to go anywhere without feeling sorry for me.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$You might do much.$NEWLINE$What is your parentage?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Not bad; you might accomplish something. Who are your parents?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Above my fortunes, yet my state is well.$NEWLINE$I am a gentleman.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I was born to a higher position than I’ve got now. But I’m still fairly high-ranking. I’m a gentleman.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Get you to your lord.$NEWLINE$I cannot love him. Let him send no more—$NEWLINE$Unless perchance you come to me again$NEWLINE$To tell me how he takes it. Fare you well.$NEWLINE$I thank you for your pains. Spend this for me.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Go back to your lord. I can’t love him. Tell him not to send any more messengers—unless you feel like coming back to tell me how he took the bad news. Goodbye. Thanks for your trouble. Here’s some money for you.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA offers VIOLA money$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$VIOLA
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA offers VIOLA money$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$VIOLA

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I am no fee’d post, lady. Keep your purse.$NEWLINE$My master, not myself, lacks recompense.$NEWLINE$Love make his heart of flint that you shall love,$NEWLINE$And let your fervor, like my master’s, be$NEWLINE$Placed in contempt. Farewell, fair cruelty.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I’m not a paid messenger, my lady. Keep your money. It’s my master who’s not getting the reward he deserves, not me. I hope you fall in love with a man whose heart is hard as a rock and who treats your love like a big joke, just like you’ve done. Goodbye, you beautiful, cruel woman.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA exits.$NEWLINE$VIOLA

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$“What is your parentage?”$NEWLINE$“Above my fortunes, yet my state is well.$NEWLINE$I am a gentleman.” I’ll be sworn thou art;$NEWLINE$Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbs, actions, and spirit,$NEWLINE$Do give thee fivefold blazon. Not too fast! Soft, soft!$NEWLINE$Unless the master were the man. How now?$NEWLINE$Even so quickly may one catch the plague?$NEWLINE$Methinks I feel this youth’s perfections$NEWLINE$With an invisible and subtle stealth$NEWLINE$To creep in at mine eyes. Well, let it be.—$NEWLINE$What ho, Malvolio!
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$“Who are your parents?” “I was born to a higher position than I’ve got now. But I’m still fairly high-ranking. I’m a gentleman.” Yes, I’m sure you are. Your way of talking, your face, your body, your behavior, and your sensitive soul all prove you’re a gentleman. Ah, no. Calm down, calm down. If only his lord were more like him. How strange I’m feeling! Can someone fall in love this quickly? I can feel this young man’s perfection creeping in through my eyes like some kind of disease, slowly and invisibly. Oh, well.—Malvolio! Come here!

paragraphs.original: Enter MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO enters.$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Here, madam, at your service.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$At your service, madam.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Run after that same peevish messenger,$NEWLINE$The county’s man. He left this ring behind him,$NEWLINE$Would I or not. Tell him I’ll none of it.$NEWLINE$OLIVIA hands him a ring$NEWLINE$hands him a ring$NEWLINE$Desire him not to flatter with his lord,$NEWLINE$Nor hold him up with hopes. I am not for him.$NEWLINE$If that the youth will come this way tomorrow,$NEWLINE$I’ll give him reasons for ’t. Hie thee, Malvolio.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Run after that obnoxious messenger, the duke’s servant. He insisted on leaving this ring with me whether I wanted it or not. Tell him I want nothing to do with it. (she hands him a ring) Ask him not to encourage Orsino or to get his hopes up. I’m not for him. If that young man comes here again tomorrow, I’ll tell him why. Hurry, Malvolio.$NEWLINE$(she hands him a ring)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Madam, I will.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Madam, I will.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO exits.$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I do I know not what and fear to find$NEWLINE$Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind.$NEWLINE$Fate, show thy force. Ourselves we do not owe.$NEWLINE$What is decreed must be, and be this so.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I don’t know what I’m doing. I’m afraid I’m not using my head, and I’m falling for his good looks. Fate, do your work. We human beings don’t control our own destinies. What is fated to happen must happen. So let it happen!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA exits.$NEWLINE$OLIVIA

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN enter.$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Will you stay no longer, nor will you not that I go with you?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$You won’t stay any longer? And you don’t want me to come with you?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$By your patience, no. My stars shine darkly over me. The malignancy of my fate might perhaps distemper yours. Therefore I shall crave of you your leave that I may bear my evils alone. It were a bad recompense for your love to lay any of them on you.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$No, I’d rather you stayed here. My luck is pretty bad right now, and it might rub off on you. So just let me say goodbye and face the bad stuff alone—otherwise I wouldn’t be thanking you very well for all you’ve done for me.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Let me yet know of you whither you are bound.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$At least tell me where you’re going.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$No, sooth, sir. My determinate voyage is mere extravagancy. But I perceive in you so excellent a touch of modesty that you will not extort from me what I am willing to keep in. Therefore it charges me in manners the rather to express myself. You must know of me then, Antonio, my name is Sebastian, which I called Roderigo. My father was that Sebastian of Messaline, whom I know you have heard of. He left behind him myself and a sister, both born in an hour. If the heavens had been pleased, would we had so ended! But you, sir, altered that, for some hour before you took me from the breach of the sea was my sister drowned.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Honestly, I can’t. I’m just wandering, with no particular destination. But I know you’d never force me to tell you things I don’t want to, so I should be polite and tell you what I can. My name’s Sebastian, though I’ve been calling myself Roderigo. My father was Sebastian of Messaline. I know you’ve heard of him. He’s dead now. He left behind myself and my twin sister, who was born in the same hour as me. If God had been willing, I wish we had died in the same hour too! But you kept that from happening. An hour before you pulled me out of the breaking waves, my sister drowned.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Alas the day!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$How tragic!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$A lady, sir, though it was said she much resembled me, was yet of many accounted beautiful. But though I could not with such estimable wonder overfar believe that, yet thus far I will boldly publish her: she bore a mind that envy could not but call fair. She is drowned already, sir, with salt water, though I seem to drown her remembrance again with more.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Although many people said she looked like me, she was considered beautiful. And though I can’t believe everything people said about her beauty, I’ll be so bold as to say she had a beautiful mind. Even those who were jealous of her would have to admit that.
