She’s been drowned in salty sea water, and now my salty tears are about to drown her memory all over again.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Pardon me, sir, your bad entertainment.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I’m sorry I wasn’t a better host for you, sir.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$O good Antonio, forgive me your trouble.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, Antonio, I’m sorry I caused you so much trouble.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$If you will not murder me for my love, let me be your servant.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I care about you a lot. Please let me be your servant so I can be with you. You’ll be killing me if you don’t.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$If you will not undo what you have done—that is, kill him whom you have recovered—desire it not. Fare you well at once. My bosom is full of kindness, and I am yet so near the manners of my mother, that upon the least occasion more mine eyes will tell tales of me. I am bound to the Count Orsino’s court. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$If you don’t want to break my heart, then say goodbye to me right now. I like you very much. I’m really about to cry, just like my mother would do. I’m going to Count Orsino’s court. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN exits.$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$The gentleness of all the gods go with thee!$NEWLINE$I have many enemies in Orsino’s court,$NEWLINE$Else would I very shortly see thee there.$NEWLINE$But, come what may, I do adore thee so$NEWLINE$That danger shall seem sport, and I will go.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I wish you all the best. If I didn’t have so many enemies in Orsino’s court, I’d go join you there. But who cares. I’m so crazy about you that danger doesn’t bother me. I’ll go anyway.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO exits.$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter VIOLA, MALVOLIO following$NEWLINE$VIOLA$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA enters with MALVOLIO following.$NEWLINE$VIOLA$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Were not you even now with the Countess Olivia?
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Excuse me, weren’t you with Countess Olivia just now?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Even now, sir. On a moderate pace I have since arrived but hither.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Yes, sir. I’ve only made it this far since I left her place, walking at a moderate pace.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$She returns this ring to you, sir. You might have saved me my pains to have taken it away yourself. She adds, moreover, that you should put your lord into a desperate assurance she will none of him. And one thing more, that you be never so hardy to come again in his affairs, unless it be to report your lord’s taking of this. Receive it so.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$She’s sending this ring back to you, sir. You should’ve saved me some trouble and taken it away yourself. She wants you to make it very clear to your lord that she wants nothing to do with him, and that you should never come again on his behalf, unless you want to come back to tell her how he reacted to the bad news. Here, take the ring.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$She took the ring of me. I’ll none of it.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$She took that ring from me. I won’t take it back.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Come, sir, you peevishly threw it to her, and her will is it should be so returned. (he throws down the ring) If it be worth stooping for, there it lies in your eye. If not, be it his that finds it.$NEWLINE$(he throws down the ring)
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$You threw it at her rudely, and she wants you to take it back. (he throws down the ring) If it’s worth bending over to pick up, there it is on the ground, where you can see it. If not, whoever finds it can have it.$NEWLINE$(he throws down the ring)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO exits.$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I left no ring with her. What means this lady?$NEWLINE$Fortune forbid my outside have not charmed her!$NEWLINE$She made good view of me, indeed so much$NEWLINE$That sure methought her eyes had lost her tongue,$NEWLINE$For she did speak in starts distractedly.$NEWLINE$She loves me, sure! The cunning of her passion$NEWLINE$Invites me in this churlish messenger.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I didn’t give her any ring. What’s she trying to say? I hope she doesn’t have a crush on me! It’s true she looked at me a lot, in fact, she looked at me so much that she seemed distracted, and couldn’t really finish her sentences very well. Oh, I really think she loves me! She sent this rude messenger to tell me to come back, instead of coming herself, which would be indis-

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: None of my lord’s ring? Why, he sent her none.$NEWLINE$I am the man. If it be so, as ’tis,$NEWLINE$Poor lady, she were better love a dream.$NEWLINE$Disguise, I see thou art a wickedness,$NEWLINE$Wherein the pregnant enemy does much.$NEWLINE$How easy is it for the proper false$NEWLINE$In women’s waxen hearts to set their forms!$NEWLINE$Alas, our frailty is the cause, not we,$NEWLINE$For such as we are made of, such we be.$NEWLINE$How will this fadge? My master loves her dearly,$NEWLINE$And I, poor monster, fond as much on him,$NEWLINE$And she, mistaken, seems to dote on me.$NEWLINE$What will become of this? As I am man,$NEWLINE$My state is desperate for my master’s love.$NEWLINE$As I am woman, now, alas the day,$NEWLINE$What thriftless sighs shall poor Olivia breathe!$NEWLINE$O time, thou must untangle this, not I.$NEWLINE$It is too hard a knot for me to untie!
paragraphs.translated: creet. She doesn’t want Orsino’s ring! Orsino never sent her a ring. I’m the man she wants. If that’s true, which it is, she might as well be in love with a dream, the poor lady. Now I understand why it’s bad to wear disguises. Disguises help the devil do his work. It’s so easy for a good-looking but deceitful man to make women fall in love with him. It’s not our fault—we women are weak. We can’t help what we’re made of. Ah, how will this all turn out? My lord loves her, and. poor me, I love him just as much. And she’s deluded enough to be in love with me. What can possibly fix this situation? I’m pretending to be a man, so my love for the Duke is hopeless. And since I’m a woman—too bad I’m a woman—Olivia’s love for me is hopeless as well! Oh, only time can sort out this mess. I can’t figure it out by myself!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA exits.$NEWLINE$VIOLA

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH and SIR ANDREW enter.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Approach, Sir Andrew. Not to be abed after midnight is to be up betimes, and diluculo surgere, thou know’st,—$NEWLINE$diluculo surgere,
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come on, Sir Andrew. If we’re still awake after midnight, then we’re up early in the morning. And the doctors say it’s healthy to get up early—

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Nay, my troth, I know not. But I know to be up late is to be up late.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I don’t know what the doctors say. All I know is that staying up late is staying up late.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$A false conclusion. I hate it as an unfilled can. To be up after midnight and to go to bed then, is early, so that to go to bed after midnight is to go to bed betimes. Does not our life consist of the four elements?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$A false conclusion. I hate your logic as much as I hate an empty drinking cup. Staying up after midnight means that you go to bed after midnight, in the wee hours of the morning, which is early. So it’s like going to bed early. Isn’t everybody made up of the four elements—earth, water, fire, and air?

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Faith, so they say, but I think it rather consists of eating and drinking.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$That’s what they say, but I think life consists of food and booze.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Thou'rt a scholar. Let us therefore eat and drink. Marian,$NEWLINE$I say! A stoup of wine!
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$You’re a smart guy. So we should eat and drink. Maria! Bring us some wine!

paragraphs.original: Enter FOOL$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated: The FOOL enters.$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Here comes the fool, i' faith.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Look, here comes the fool.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$How now, my hearts! Did you never see the picture of “We$NEWLINE$Three”?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Hello, my friends! What a pretty picture, three fools all together.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Welcome, ass. Now let’s have a catch.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Hello, you idiot. Sing us a song.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast. I had rather than forty shillings I had such a leg, and so sweet a breath to sing, as the fool has.—(to the FOOL) In sooth, thou wast in very gracious fooling last night when thou spokest of Pigrogromitus, of the Vapians passing the equinoctial of Queubus. 'Twas very good, i' faith. I sent thee sixpence for thy leman. Hadst it?$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I swear, this fool has an excellent singing voice. I’d give forty shillings to have his nice legs and his beautiful voice. (to the FOOL) Fool, you were very funny last night talking that
astrological nonsense about Pigrogromitus and the Vapians passing the equinox of Queubus. Very amusing. I sent you some money to spend on your girlfriend. Did you get it?$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$astrological nonsense$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$I did impeticos thy gratillity, for Malvolio’s nose is no whipstock. My lady has a white hand, and the Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL$NEWLINE$I gave your little present to my girlfriend because you can’t get a grip on Malvolio’s nose to whip your horse with it. My girlfriend has beautiful white hands, and great warriors aren’t
mom-and-pop diners, you know.$NEWLINE$mom-and-pop diners$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Excellent! Why, this is the best fooling when all is done.$NEWLINE$Now, a song.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Ha, ha! I love it when you talk nonsense—that’s what fools should do. Come on now, sing for us.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(giving money to the FOOL)$NEWLINE$(giving money to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Come on. There is sixpence for you. Let’s have a song.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(giving the FOOL money) Yes, come on. Here’s sixpence for you. Let’s hear a song.$NEWLINE$(giving the$NEWLINE$money)

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(giving money to the FOOL)$NEWLINE$(giving money to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$There’s a testril of me too. If one knight give a—
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(giving the FOOL money) Here’s something from me too. If one knight gives—$NEWLINE$(giving the$NEWLINE$money)

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Would you have a love song or a song of good life?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Would you rather hear a love song or a song about the good life?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$A love song, a love song.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$A love song, a love song.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Ay, ay. I care not for good life.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Yes, yes. I’m not interested in being good.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$O mistress mine, where are you roaming?$NEWLINE$O mistress mine, where are you roaming?$NEWLINE$O, stay and hear! Your true love’s coming,$NEWLINE$O, stay and hear! Your true love’s coming,$NEWLINE$That can sing both high and low:$NEWLINE$That can sing both high and low:$NEWLINE$Trip no further, pretty sweeting.$NEWLINE$Trip no further, pretty sweeting.$NEWLINE$Journeys end in lovers meeting,$NEWLINE$Journeys end in lovers meeting,$NEWLINE$Every wise man’s son doth know.$NEWLINE$Every wise man’s son doth know.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(he sings)$NEWLINE$(he sings)$NEWLINE$Oh my lover, where are you roaming? Stay and listen! Your true love’s coming, the one who can sing both high and low: Don’t roam any further, pretty darling. Your journey ends when you meet a lover, as every wise man’s son knows.$NEWLINE$Oh my lover, where are you roaming? Stay and listen! Your true love’s coming, the one who can sing both high and low: Don’t roam any further, pretty darling. Your journey ends when you meet a lover, as every wise man’s son knows.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Excellent good, i' faith.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$That was excellent, really excellent.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Good, good.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Good, very good.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$What is love? 'Tis not hereafter.$NEWLINE$What is love? 'Tis not hereafter.$NEWLINE$Present mirth hath present laughter.$NEWLINE$Present mirth hath present laughter.$NEWLINE$What’s to come is still unsure.$NEWLINE$What’s to come is still unsure.$NEWLINE$In delay there lies no plenty.$NEWLINE$In delay there lies no plenty.$NEWLINE$Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty.$NEWLINE$Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty.$NEWLINE$Youth’s a stuff will not endure.$NEWLINE$Youth’s a stuff will not endure.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$What is love? It isn’t in the future. When you’re having fun now, you’re laughing right now. The future’s unsure, and there’s no reason to waste time. Come kiss me while you’re twenty. You won’t be young forever.$NEWLINE$What is love? It isn’t in the future. When you’re having fun now, you’re laughing right now. The future’s unsure, and there’s no reason to waste time. Come kiss me while you’re twenty. You won’t be young forever.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$A beautiful voice, I swear.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$A contagious breath.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$His breath stinks.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Very sweet and contagious, i' faith.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Yes, it stinks very sweetly.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion. But shall we make the welkin dance indeed? Shall we rouse the night owl in a catch that will draw three souls out of one weaver? Shall we do that?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$If we could listen to him with our noses, we would definitely say he stinks very sweetly. So what do you say, should we sing loud enough to shake the heavens? Should we sing a round to wake up the night owl? Should we do that?

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$An you love me, let’s do ’t. I am dog at a catch.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Let’s go for it. I’m a very good singer, and can sing rounds like a
dog.$NEWLINE$dog$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$By 'r lady, sir, and some dogs will catch well.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Then you’ll be good at catchy tunes. Dogs like to play catch.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Most certain. Let our catch be “Thou Knave.”
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Absolutely. Let’s dance to “You Jerk.”

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$“Hold thy peace, thou knave,” knight? I shall be constrained in ’t to call thee knave, knight.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$You mean, “Shut up, you jerk”? That’s the song where the singers call each other jerks, right? So I’ll be forced to call you a jerk, Sir Andrew.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$'Tis not the first time I have constrained one to call me$NEWLINE$“knave.” Begin, Fool. It begins “Hold thy peace.”
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$It won’t be the first time someone was forced to call me that. You start, Fool. It starts, “Shut up.”

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$I shall never begin if I hold my peace.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I’ll never be able to start if I shut up.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Good, i' faith. Come, begin.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$That’s true. But come on, start.

paragraphs.original: Catch sung
paragraphs.translated: They sing.

paragraphs.original: Enter MARIA$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: MARIA enters.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$What a caterwauling do you keep here! If my lady have not called up her steward Malvolio and bid him turn you out of doors, never trust me.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$You’re making a terrible racket out here! Lady Olivia told her servant Malvolio to kick you out of the house. I swear it’s true.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$My lady’s a Cataian. We are politicians, Malvolio’s a Peg- a-Ramsey, and (sings) Three merry men be we.—Am not I consanguineous? Am I not of her blood? Tillyvally! “Lady”! (sings) There dwelt a man in Babylon, lady, lady!$NEWLINE$sings) There dwelt a man in Babylon, lady, lady!
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Lady Olivia can go to China for all I care. We’re very smart guys, and Malvolio’s Little Bo Peep. (he sings) We’re just having some fun.—Aren’t I her relative, after all? Aren’t we related? Fiddle-dee-dee, “Lady!” (singing) There lived a man in Babylon, lady, lady!$NEWLINE$(he sings) We’re just having some fun.$NEWLINE$(singing) There lived a man in Babylon, lady, lady!

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Beshrew me, the knight’s in admirable fooling.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Gosh, the knight’s very good at acting like a fool.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Ay, he does well enough if he be disposed, and so do I too.$NEWLINE$He does it with a better grace, but I do it more natural.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Yes, he’s good at it when he’s in the mood, and so am I. He’s practiced more, but it comes more naturally to me.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(sings) O' the twelfth day of December—$NEWLINE$(sings) O' the twelfth day of December—
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(he sings) On the twelfth day of December—$NEWLINE$(he sings) On the twelfth day of December—

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$For the love o' God, peace!
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$For God’s sake, shut up!

paragraphs.original: Enter MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO enters.$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$My masters, are you mad? Or what are you? Have you no wit, manners, nor honesty but to gabble like tinkers at this time of night? Do you make an alehouse of my lady’s house, that you squeak out your coziers' catches without any mitigation or remorse of voice? Is there no respect of place, persons, nor time in you?
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Are you all crazy? What’s wrong with you? Are you making all this noise at this time of night because you have no manners, or because you’re just stupid? Are you trying to turn my mistress’s house into a noisy bar? Is that why you’re squealing out these ridiculous vulgar songs without lowering your voices at all? Don’t you have any respect for anything?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$We did keep time, sir, in our catches. Sneck up!
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$We respected the beat of the song, sir. So shut up!

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sir Toby, I must be round with you. My lady bade me tell you, that, though she harbors you as her kinsman, she’s nothing allied to your disorders. If you can separate yourself and your misdemeanors, you are welcome to the house. If not, an it would please you to take leave of her, she is very willing to bid you farewell.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sir Toby, I’ve got to be frank with you. My lady told me to tell you that while she lets you stay at her house because you’re a relative, she doesn’t approve of your behavior. If you can shape up, you’re welcome to stay in the house. If you can’t, and would prefer to leave, she’s very willing to say goodbye to you.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(sings) Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone.$NEWLINE$(sings) Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(he
sings ) Goodnight, sweetheart, I’m going to leave you now.$NEWLINE$(he$NEWLINE$sings$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$) Goodnight, sweetheart, I’m going to leave you now.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Nay, good Sir Toby.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$No, good Sir Toby.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings) His eyes do show his days are almost done.$NEWLINE$sings$NEWLINE$His eyes do show his days are almost done.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(singing) You can tell from his eyes that his life is almost over.$NEWLINE$(singing) You can tell from his eyes that his life is almost over.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Is ’t even so?
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Is this how it’s going to be?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(sings) But I will never die.$NEWLINE$sings$NEWLINE$But I will never die.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(singing) But I will never die.$NEWLINE$(singing) But I will never die.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings) Sir Toby, there you lie.$NEWLINE$sings$NEWLINE$Sir Toby, there you lie.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(singing) Sir Toby, that’s a lie.$NEWLINE$(singing) Sir Toby, that’s a lie.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$This is much credit to you.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$This behavior really makes you look great.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(sings) Shall I bid him go?$NEWLINE$(sings) Shall I bid him go?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(singing) Should I tell him to go?$NEWLINE$(singing) Should I tell him to go?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings) What an if you do?$NEWLINE$(sings) What an if you do?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(singing) What if y,ou do?$NEWLINE$(singing) What if y,ou do?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(sings) Shall I bid him go, and spare not?$NEWLINE$(sings) Shall I bid him go, and spare not?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(singing) Should I tell him to go, and be harsh with him?$NEWLINE$(singing) Should I tell him to go, and be harsh with him?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings) O no, no, no, no, you dare not.$NEWLINE$(sings) O no, no, no, no, you dare not.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(singing) Oh no, no, no, no, don’t you dare.$NEWLINE$(singing) Oh no, no, no, no, don’t you dare.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Out o' tune, sir. You lie. Art any more than a steward? Dost thou think, because thou art virtuous, there shall be no more cakes and ale?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$That’s out of tune, sir. You lie. (to MALVOLIO) You’re nothing more than a servant here. Do you think that just because you’re a goody two shoes, no one else can enjoy himself?$NEWLINE$to

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall be hot i' the mouth too.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$They certainly will. They’ll have double helpings, too.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Thou'rt i' the right. Go, sir, rub your chain with crumbs. A stoup of wine, Maria!
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$You’re right. (to MALVOLIO) Go polish your steward’s chain, sir. Maria, bring us some wine!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Mistress Mary, if you prized my lady’s favor at anything more than contempt, you would not give means for this uncivil rule. She shall know of it, by this hand.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Miss Mary, if you cared what Lady Olivia thinks about you at all, you wouldn’t contribute to this rude behavior. I assure you, she’ll find out about this.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO exits.$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Go shake your ears!
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Go and wiggle your ears!

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$'Twere as good a deed as to drink when a man’s a-hungry, to challenge him the field and then to break promise with him and make a fool of him.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$There’s nothing I’d love more than to make a fool out of that guy somehow. I could challenge him to a duel and then not show up. That would do the trick.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Do ’t, knight. I’ll write thee a challenge. Or I’ll deliver thy indignation to him by word of mouth.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Do that. I’ll write a letter challenging him to a duel on your behalf. Or I’ll deliver your insults to his face.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight. Since the youth of the count’s was today with thy lady, she is much out of quiet. For Monsieur Malvolio, let me alone with him. If I do not gull him into a nayword and make him a common recreation, do not think I have wit enough to lie straight in my bed. I know I can do it.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Dear Sir Toby, don’t do anything rash tonight. Ever since the Duke’s messenger visited Olivia, she’s been upset. As for Monsieur Malvolio, let me take care of him. I’ll make a big fool out of him, just trust me. I’ll make him famous for his stupidity. Everyone will laugh at him. I know I can do it.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Possess us, possess us, tell us something of him.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Tell us something about him. Come on, tell us something.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, sometimes he is a kind of puritan.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Well, sometimes he acts like a goody two shoes.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$O, if I thought that, I’d beat him like a dog!
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Oh, I’ll beat him up for that!

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$What, for being a puritan? Thy exquisite reason, dear knight?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$You’re going to beat him up for being good? And what’s your brilliant reason for that, please?

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I have no exquisite reason for ’t, but I have reason good enough.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I don’t have any “brilliant” reason for it, but I have a good enough reason.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$The devil a puritan that he is, or anything constantly, but a time-pleaser; an affectioned ass that cons state without book and utters it by great swarths; the best persuaded of himself, so crammed, as he thinks, with excellencies, that it is his grounds of faith that all that look on him love him. And on that vice in him will my revenge find notable cause to work.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$He isn’t really that pure and good. He’s just a conceited flatterer. He’s a pretentious guy who aspires to speak and act like nobility. He’s proud, and he thinks he’s so stuffed full of wonderful qualities that everyone loves him. That’s the weakness I’ll use to get revenge on him.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$What wilt thou do?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$What are you going to do?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$I will drop in his way some obscure epistles of love, wherein by the color of his beard, the shape of his leg, the manner of his gait, the expressure of his eye, forehead, and complexion,he shall find himself most feelingly personated.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$I’ll drop some mysterious love letters in his path. He’ll think they’re addressed to him, because they’ll describe the color of his beard, the shape of his legs, the way he walks, and the expression on his face. I can make my handwriting look just like Lady Olivia’s: she

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I can write very like my lady your niece: on a forgotten matter we can hardly make distinction of our hands.
paragraphs.translated: and I can’t tell the difference between each other’s handwriting.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Excellent! I smell a device.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Excellent! Sounds like you’ve got a good trick in mind.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I have ’t in my nose too.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I like it too.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop, that they come from my niece, and that she’s in love with him.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$He’ll think these letters are from Olivia and that she’s in love with him.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$My purpose is, indeed, a horse of that color.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Yes, that’s the idea.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$And your horse now would make him an ass.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$He’s going to look like a total idiot.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Ass, I doubt not.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Absolutely, you idiot.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Oh, ’twill be admirable!
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$This is going to be great!

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Sport royal, I warrant you. I know my physic will work with him. I will plant you two, and let the fool make a third, where he shall find the letter. Observe his construction of it. For this night, to bed, and dream on the event. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$It’s going to be fun, I promise. I know my medicine will work on him. I’ll have you two hide—and the fool too—right where he’ll find the letter. Watch his reaction. Meanwhile, let’s go to bed and dream about this. Good night.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MARIA exits.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Good night, Penthesilea.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Good night, you amazing woman, you.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Before me, she’s a good wench.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$She’s a fine woman, all right.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$She’s a beagle, true-bred, and one that adores me. What o' that?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$She’s a good little woman, and she adores me. What about it?

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I was adored once too.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Someone adored me once, too.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Let’s to bed, knight. Thou hadst need send for more money.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Let’s go to bed, knight. Tomorrow you need to get more money sent to you.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$If I cannot recover your niece, I am a foul way out.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$If I can’t persuade your niece to marry me, I’m going to be in some serious financial trouble.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Send for money, knight. If thou hast her not i' the end, call me “Cut.”
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Get your hands on some money and everything will be all right. I know you’ll win over Olivia in the end.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$If I do not, never trust me, take it how you will.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I know I will too, if it’s the last thing I do.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come, come, I’ll go burn some sack. 'Tis too late to go to bed now. Come, knight. Come, knight.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come on, I’ll go warm up a nice glass of sherry for us. It’s too late to go to bed now. Come on, my friend, come on.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ORSINO, VIOLA, CURIO, and others$NEWLINE$ORSINO$NEWLINE$VIOLA$NEWLINE$CURIO
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO, VIOLA, CURIO, and others enter.$NEWLINE$ORSINO$NEWLINE$VIOLA$NEWLINE$CURIO

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Give me some music. (music plays)$NEWLINE$music plays$NEWLINE$Now, good morrow, friends.—$NEWLINE$Now, good Cesario, but that piece of song,$NEWLINE$That old and antique song we heard last night.$NEWLINE$Methought it did relieve my passion much,$NEWLINE$More than light airs and recollected terms$NEWLINE$Of these most brisk and giddy-paced times:$NEWLINE$Come, but one verse.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Play me some music. (music plays) Good morning, my friends.—Have them sing me that song again, Cesario, that old-fashioned song someone sang last night. It made me feel better and took my mind off my troubles much better than the silly songs they sing nowadays. Please, have them sing just one verse.$NEWLINE$(music plays)

paragraphs.original: CURIO$NEWLINE$He is not here, so please your lordship, that should sing it.
paragraphs.translated: CURIO$NEWLINE$Sir, the person who should sing that song isn’t here.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Who was it?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Who was it?

paragraphs.original: CURIO$NEWLINE$Feste, the jester, my lord, a fool that the lady Olivia’s father took much delight in. He is about the house.
paragraphs.translated: CURIO$NEWLINE$Feste, the jester, my lord. Olivia’s father used to like him. He’s somewhere else in the house.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Seek him out, and play the tune the while.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Then go find him. Meanwhile, play the tune.

paragraphs.original: Exit CURIO. Music plays$NEWLINE$CURIO
paragraphs.translated: CURIO exits. Music plays.$NEWLINE$CURIO

paragraphs.original: (to VIOLA) Come hither, boy. If ever thou shalt love,$NEWLINE$to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$In the sweet pangs of it remember me;$NEWLINE$For such as I am, all true lovers are,$NEWLINE$Unstaid and skittish in all motions else$NEWLINE$Save in the constant image of the creature$NEWLINE$That is beloved. How dost thou like this tune?
paragraphs.translated: (to VIOLA) Come here, boy. If you ever fall in love and feel the bittersweet pain it brings, think of me. Because the way I am now, moody and unable to focus on anything except the face of the woman I love, is exactly how all true lovers are. What do you think of this song?$NEWLINE$to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$It gives a very echo to the seat$NEWLINE$Where Love is throned.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$It really makes you feel what a lover feels.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Thou dost speak masterly.$NEWLINE$My life upon ’t, young though thou art, thine eye$NEWLINE$Hath stay’d upon some favor that it loves.$NEWLINE$Hath it not, boy?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$You’re absolutely right. I’d bet my life that, as young as you are, you’ve fallen in love with someone. Haven’t you, boy?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$A little, by your favor.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$A little bit.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$What kind of woman is’t?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$What kind of woman is she?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Of your complexion.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$She’s a lot like you.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$She is not worth thee, then. What years, i' faith?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$She’s not good enough for you, then. How old is she?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$About your years, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$About as old as you are, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Too old by heaven. Let still the woman take$NEWLINE$An elder than herself. So wears she to him,$NEWLINE$So sways she level in her husband’s heart.$NEWLINE$For, boy, however we do praise ourselves,$NEWLINE$Our fancies are more giddy and unfirm,$NEWLINE$More longing, wavering, sooner lost and worn,$NEWLINE$Than women’s are.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$That’s definitely too old. A woman should always pick an older man. That way she’ll adjust herself to what her husband wants, and the husband will be happy and faithful to her. Because however much we like to brag, boy, the truth is that we men change our minds a lot more than women do, and our desires come and go a lot faster than theirs.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I think it well, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I think you’re right, sir.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Then let thy love be younger than thyself,$NEWLINE$Or thy affection cannot hold the bent.$NEWLINE$For women are as roses, whose fair flower$NEWLINE$Being once displayed, doth fall that very hour.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$So find someone younger to love, or you won’t be able to maintain your feelings. Women are like roses: the moment their beauty is in full bloom, it’s about to decay.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$And so they are. Alas, that they are so,$NEWLINE$To die even when they to perfection grow!
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$That’s true. It’s too bad their beauty fades right when it reaches perfection!

paragraphs.original: Enter CURIO and FOOL$NEWLINE$CURIO$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated: CURIO and the FOOL enter.$NEWLINE$CURIO$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$O, fellow, come, the song we had last night.—$NEWLINE$Mark it, Cesario, it is old and plain;$NEWLINE$The spinsters and the knitters in the sun$NEWLINE$And the free maids that weave their thread with bones$NEWLINE$Do use to chant it. It is silly sooth,$NEWLINE$And dallies with the innocence of love,$NEWLINE$Like the old age.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$My friend, sing us the song you sang last night.—Listen to it carefully, Cesario, it’s a simple old song. Spinners and knitters used to sing it while they sewed, and maidens used to sing it over their weaving. It tells the simple truth about innocent love, as it was in the good old days.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Are you ready, sir?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Are you ready, sir?

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Ay; prithee, sing.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Yes. Please, sing.

paragraphs.original: Music
paragraphs.translated: Music plays.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Come away, come away, death,$NEWLINE$Come away, come away, death,$NEWLINE$And in sad cypress let me be laid.$NEWLINE$And in sad cypress let me be laid.$NEWLINE$Fly away, fly away breath,$NEWLINE$Fly away, fly away breath,$NEWLINE$I am slain by a fair cruel maid.$NEWLINE$I am slain by a fair cruel maid.$NEWLINE$My shroud of white, stuck all with yew,$NEWLINE$My shroud of white, stuck all with yew,$NEWLINE$O, prepare it!$NEWLINE$O, prepare it!$NEWLINE$My part of death, no one so true$NEWLINE$My part of death, no one so true$NEWLINE$Did share it.$NEWLINE$Did share it.$NEWLINE$Not a flower, not a flower sweet$NEWLINE$Not a flower, not a flower sweet$NEWLINE$On my black coffin let there be strown.$NEWLINE$On my black coffin let there be strown.$NEWLINE$Not a friend, not a friend greet$NEWLINE$Not a friend, not a friend greet$NEWLINE$My poor corpse, where my bones shall be thrown.$NEWLINE$My poor corpse, where my bones shall be thrown.$NEWLINE$A thousand thousand sighs to save,$NEWLINE$A thousand thousand sighs to save,$NEWLINE$Lay me, O, where$NEWLINE$Lay me, O, where$NEWLINE$Sad true lover never find my grave,$NEWLINE$Sad true lover never find my grave,$NEWLINE$To weep there!$NEWLINE$To weep there!
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(he sings)$NEWLINE$(he sings)$NEWLINE$Come on, let me die now$NEWLINE$Come on, let me die now$NEWLINE$And put my body in a dark coffin.$NEWLINE$And put my body in a dark coffin.$NEWLINE$I feel my breath leaving me.$NEWLINE$I feel my breath leaving me.$NEWLINE$I’ve been killed by a beautiful girl.$NEWLINE$I’ve been killed by a beautiful girl.$NEWLINE$Prepare my shroud of white,$NEWLINE$Prepare my shroud of white,$NEWLINE$Adorned with sprigs of yew-tree.$NEWLINE$Adorned with sprigs of yew-tree.$NEWLINE$I’m the most faithful person$NEWLINE$I’m the most faithful person$NEWLINE$Who ever lived or died.$NEWLINE$Who ever lived or died.$NEWLINE$Don’t scatter sweet flowers$NEWLINE$Don’t scatter sweet flowers$NEWLINE$On my black coffin.$NEWLINE$On my black coffin.$NEWLINE$Don’t let my friends$NEWLINE$Don’t let my friends$NEWLINE$See my poor corpse.$NEWLINE$See my poor corpse.$NEWLINE$I don’t want to hear sad sighs,$NEWLINE$I don’t want to hear sad sighs,$NEWLINE$So bury me where no sad lovers$NEWLINE$So bury me where no sad lovers$NEWLINE$can find my grave to weep over it!$NEWLINE$can find my grave to weep over it!

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$(giving money) There’s for thy pains.$NEWLINE$(giving money)
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$(giving the FOOL money) Here’s some money for your trouble.$NEWLINE$(giving the$NEWLINE$money)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$No pains, sir. I take pleasure in singing, sir.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$No trouble, sir. I like singing.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$I’ll pay thy pleasure then.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Then I’ll pay you for doing what you like.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Truly, sir, and pleasure will be paid, one time or another.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well, in that case, all right. We all pay for what we like sooner or later.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Give me now leave to leave thee.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$You may leave.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Now, the melancholy god protect thee, and the tailor make thy doublet of changeable taffeta, for thy mind is a very opal. I would have men of such constancy put to sea, that their business might be everything and their intent everywhere, for that’s it that always makes a good voyage of nothing. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I’ll pray for the god of sadness to protect you, sir. And I hope your tailor will make you an outfit out of fabric that changes color, because your mind is like an opal that changes colors constantly. Men as wonderfully changeable as you are should all go drifting on the sea, where they can do whatever comes their way, and go wherever the current takes them. Those are the men whose trips are always successful. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The FOOL exits.$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Let all the rest give place.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$All the rest of you can leave too.

paragraphs.original: CURIO and attendants retire$NEWLINE$CURIO
paragraphs.translated: CURIO and attendants retire.$NEWLINE$CURIO

paragraphs.original: Once more, Cesario,$NEWLINE$Get thee to yond same sovereign cruelty.$NEWLINE$Tell her my love, more noble than the world,$NEWLINE$Prizes not quantity of dirty lands;$NEWLINE$The parts that fortune hath bestowed upon her,$NEWLINE$Tell her, I hold as giddily as fortune;$NEWLINE$But ’tis that miracle and queen of gems$NEWLINE$That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.
paragraphs.translated: Cesario, go visit that cruel Olivia one more time. Tell her my love is purer than anything else in the whole world, and has nothing to do with her property. The wealth she’s inherited isn’t what makes me value her. It’s her rich, jewel-like beauty that attracts me.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$But if she cannot love you, sir?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$But if she can’t love you, sir?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$I cannot be so answer’d.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$I refuse to accept that.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Sooth, but you must.$NEWLINE$Say that some lady, as perhaps there is,$NEWLINE$Hath for your love a great a pang of heart$NEWLINE$As you have for Olivia. You cannot love her.$NEWLINE$You tell her so. Must she not then be answered?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$But you have to. Just imagine some lady might exist who loves you as powerfully and agonizingly as you love Olivia. But you can’t love her, and you tell her so. Shouldn’t she just accept that?

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$There is no woman’s sides$NEWLINE$Can bide the beating of so strong a passion$NEWLINE$As love doth give my heart. No woman’s heart$NEWLINE$So big, to hold so much. They lack retention.$NEWLINE$Alas, their love may be called appetite,$NEWLINE$No motion of the liver, but the palate,$NEWLINE$That suffer surfeit, cloyment, and revolt;$NEWLINE$But mine is all as hungry as the sea,$NEWLINE$And can digest as much. Make no compare$NEWLINE$Between that love a woman can bear me$NEWLINE$And that I owe Olivia.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$No woman is strong enough to put up with the kind of intense passion I feel. No woman’s heart is big enough to hold all my love. Women don’t feel love like that—love is as shallow as appetite for them. It has nothing to do with their hearts, just their sense of taste. They eat too much and get indigestion and nausea. But my love’s different. It’s as all-consuming and insatiable as the sea, and it can swallow as much as the sea can. Don’t compare a woman’s love for a man with my love for Olivia.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Ay, but I know—
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Yes, but I know—

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$What dost thou know?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$What do you know?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Too well what love women to men may owe.$NEWLINE$In faith, they are as true of heart as we.$NEWLINE$My father had a daughter loved a man$NEWLINE$As it might be, perhaps, were I a woman,$NEWLINE$I should your lordship.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I know a lot about the love women can feel for men. Actually, their hearts are as sensitive and loyal as ours are. My father had a daughter who loved a man in the same way that I might love you, if I were a woman.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$And what’s her history?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$And what’s her story?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$A blank, my lord. She never told her love,$NEWLINE$But let concealment, like a worm i' the bud,$NEWLINE$Feed on her damask cheek. She pined in thought,$NEWLINE$And with a green and yellow melancholy$NEWLINE$She sat like patience on a monument,$NEWLINE$Smiling at grief. Was not this love indeed?$NEWLINE$We men may say more, swear more, but indeed$NEWLINE$Our shows are more than will, for still we prove$NEWLINE$Much in our vows, but little in our love.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$There was no story, my lord. She never told him she loved him. She kept her love bottled up inside her until it destroyed her, ruining her beauty. She pined away. She just sat waiting patiently, sadly, smiling despite her sadness. Her complexion turned greenish from depression. Doesn’t that sound like true love? We men might talk more and promise more, but in fact we talk more than we really feel. We might be great at making vows, but our love isn’t sincere.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$But died thy sister of her love, my boy?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$But did your sister die of love?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I am all the daughters of my father’s house,$NEWLINE$And all the brothers too—and yet I know not.$NEWLINE$Sir, shall I to this lady?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I am the only daughter in my father’s family, and all the brothers too—but I’m not completely sure about that. Anyway, sir, should I go see the lady?

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Ay, that’s the theme.$NEWLINE$To her in haste. Give her this jewel. Say$NEWLINE$My love can give no place, bide no denay.$NEWLINE$(he hands her a jewel)$NEWLINE$(he hands her a jewel)
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Yes, go quickly and give her this jewel. Tell her my love won’t go away and won’t be denied. (he hands her a jewel)$NEWLINE$(he hands her a jewel)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$FABIAN
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN enter.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$FABIAN

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come thy ways, Signior Fabian.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come along with us, Signor Fabian.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Nay, I’ll come. If I lose a scruple of this sport, let me be boiled to death with melancholy.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$I’m coming, don’t worry. If I miss this, let me be boiled alive.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Wouldst thou not be glad to have the niggardly rascally sheep-biter come by some notable shame?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Won’t you be glad to see that rascal dog humiliated?

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$I would exult, man. You know, he brought me out o' favor with my lady about a bear-baiting here.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$I’ll be thrilled. You know, he got me in trouble with the lady of the house once when I arranged a bear-baiting here.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$To anger him, we’ll have the bear again, and we will fool him black and blue. Shall we not, Sir Andrew?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$We’ll have another bear-baiting just to make him angry, and we’ll mock him till he’s black and blue. Won’t we, Sir Andrew?

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$An we do not, it is pity of our lives.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$If we don’t, it’ll be the biggest disappointment of our lives.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Here comes the little villain.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Here comes the little villain herself.

paragraphs.original: Enter MARIA$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: MARIA enters.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: How now, my metal of India?
paragraphs.translated: How are you, my golden girl?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Get you all three into the boxtree. Malvolio’s coming down this walk. He has been yonder i' the sun practising behavior to his own shadow this half hour. Observe him, for the love of mockery, for I know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of him. Close, in the name of jesting!
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Hide behind the boxwood hedge, all three of you. Malvolio’s coming down the path. He’s been over there practicing how to act for the past half hour. Watch him carefully if you want to have some fun, guys. This letter’s going to turn him into a starry-eyed idiot. Now hide, for God’s sake!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: They hide
paragraphs.translated: They all hide.

paragraphs.original: Lie thou there (throwing down a letter), for here comes the trout that must be caught with tickling.
paragraphs.translated: Now, you lie there on the path. (MARIA throws down a letter) Here comes the fish that’s going to gobble up our bait.$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$throws down a letter)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MARIA exits.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: Enter MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO enters.$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$'Tis but fortune, all is fortune. Maria once told me she did affect me, and I have heard herself come thus near, that, should she fancy, it should be one of my complexion. Besides, she uses me with a more exalted respect than anyone else that follows her. What should I think on ’t?
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$It’s all luck. Everything’s luck. Maria once told me Olivia was fond of me. I’ve almost heard Olivia say that herself. She said if she were interested in someone, it would be someone who looked like me. Besides, she treats me more respectfully than the other servants. What’s the obvious conclusion from that?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) Here’s an overweening rogue!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) What an egomaniac!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) O, peace! Contemplation makes a rare turkey-cock of him. How he jets under his advanced plumes!$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) Shh! When he’s alone with his thoughts, he’s even more like a haughty peacock. Watch him strut!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(aside) 'Slight, I could so beat the rogue!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(whispering) I swear, I’d like to beat the jerk so hard!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) Peace, I say.$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) Be quiet!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$To be Count Malvolio!
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Just think, I could be Count Malvolio!

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) Ah, rogue!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) Ah, what a jerk!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(aside) Pistol him, pistol him.$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(whispering) Shoot him, just shoot him.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) Peace, peace!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) Shh, shh!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$There is example for ’t. The lady of the Strachy married the yeoman of the wardrobe.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$After all, it wouldn’t be the first time that kind of thing has happened. Lady Strachy married her wardrobe manager.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(aside) Fie on him, Jezebel!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(whispering) Damn him, the arrogant fool!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) O, peace! Now he’s deeply in. Look how imagination blows him.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) Shh! We’ve got him right where we want him. He’s on a big ego trip.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Having been three months married to her, sitting in my state—
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Just think of me, having been married to her for three months, sitting around majestically—

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) Oh, for a stone-bow, to hit him in the eye!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) If only I had a slingshot so I could hit him in the eye!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Calling my officers about me, in my branched velvet gown, having come from a daybed, where I have left Olivia sleeping—
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Calling my servants together, wearing an embroidered robe, having just come from a couch where I’ve left Olivia sleeping—

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) Fire and brimstone!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) That does it!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) O, peace, peace!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) Oh, be quiet, be quiet!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$And then to have the humor of state, and after a demure travel of regard, telling them I know my place as I would they should do theirs, to ask for my kinsman Toby—
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Then I’d put on a lofty and exalted expression. I’d look around the room calmly, then tell them that I know my place, and I’d like them to know theirs. Then I’d tell them to go find my cousin Toby—

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) Bolts and shackles!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) That really does it!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) O peace, peace, peace! Now, now.$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) Oh, quiet, quiet! Please, please.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Seven of my people, with an obedient start, make out for him. I frown the while, and perchance wind up watch, or play with my—some rich jewel. Toby approaches, curtsies there to me—
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$I’d send seven of my servants to go get him. While I waited, I’d frown impatiently, and perhaps wind my watch, or play with my—with some expensive piece of jewelry I happen to be wearing. Toby would approach me. He’d bow to me—

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) Shall this fellow live?$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) Are we going to let this guy live?$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) Though our silence be drawn from us with cars, yet peace.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) Yes, we have to be quiet, even if it’s torture.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$I extend my hand to him thus, quenching my familiar smile with an austere regard of control—
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$I reach out my hand to him like this, giving him a stern look instead of my usual friendly smile—

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) And does not Toby take you a blow o' the lips then?$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) And then doesn’t Toby punch you in the mouth?$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Saying, “Cousin Toby, my fortunes having cast me on your niece give me this prerogative of speech—”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$And I’d say to him, “Cousin Toby, since I’ve been lucky enough to marry your niece, I have the right to say a few things to you—”

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) What, what?$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) Oh yeah, like what?$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“You must amend your drunkenness.”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“You must stop being such a drunk.”

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) Out, scab!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) Get out of here, you scab!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) Nay, patience, or we break the sinews of our plot.$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) No, be quiet, or we’ll screw up the joke.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“Besides, you waste the treasure of your time with a foolish knight—”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“And you’re wasting your time with that foolish knight—”

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(aside) That’s me, I warrant you.$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(whispering) That’s me, I bet.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“One Sir Andrew—”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“That Sir Andrew—”

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(aside) I knew ’twas I, for many do call me fool.$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(whispering) I knew he was talking about me. A lot of people call me foolish.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$(seeing the letter) What employment have we here?$NEWLINE$seeing the letter
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$(seeing the letter) What’s this?$NEWLINE$seeing the letter

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) Now is the woodcock near the gin.$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) He’s taking the bait.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) O, peace! And the spirit of humors intimate reading aloud to him!$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) Shhh! I hope he reads it out loud, to make it funnier!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$(picking up the letter) By my life, this is my lady’s hand these be her very C’s, her U’s and her T’s and thus makes she her great P’s. It is, in contempt of question, her hand.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$(picking up the letter) My goodness, this is my lady’s
handwriting! These are her C’s, her U’s and her T’s, and that’s how she makes her big P’s. It’s definitely her handwriting, no doubt about it.$NEWLINE$picking up the letter$NEWLINE$handwriting$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(aside) Her C’s, her U’s and her T’s. Why that?$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(whispering) Her C’s, her U’s, and her T’s. Why focus on that?$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$(reads) “To the unknown beloved, this, and my good wishes”—Her very phrases! By your leave, wax. Soft! And the impressure her Lucrece, with which she uses to seal. 'Tis my lady. To whom should this be?$NEWLINE$(reads)
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$(reads) To my dear beloved who doesn’t know I love him, I send you this letter with all my heart”—That’s exactly how she talks! Excuse me, sealing wax. (he breaks the seal) Wait! This is the stamp my lady seals her letters with—it has a picture of Lucrece on it. This letter is from Olivia. Who is this written to?$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(he breaks the seal)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) This wins him, liver and all.$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) This’ll get him.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“Jove knows I love,$NEWLINE$But who?$NEWLINE$Lips, do not move;$NEWLINE$No man must know.”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$God knows I love someone.$NEWLINE$But who?$NEWLINE$I can’t let my lips say his name;$NEWLINE$“No man must know.”

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“No man must know.” What follows? The numbers altered. “No man must know.” If this should be thee, Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“No man must know.” What comes after that? Look, the meter changes in her poem. “No man must know.” What if this someone were you, Malvolio?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) Marry, hang thee, brock!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) Go hang yourself, you stinking badger!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“I may command where I adore,$NEWLINE$But silence, like a Lucrece knife,$NEWLINE$With bloodless stroke my heart doth gore;$NEWLINE$M.O.A.I. doth sway my life.”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$(reading)$NEWLINE$(reading)$NEWLINE$“I may order the one I love.$NEWLINE$But silence, like a knife, cuts open my heart$NEWLINE$With strokes that draw no blood.$NEWLINE$M.O.A.I. rules my life.”

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) A fustian riddle!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) What a pretentious riddle!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) Excellent wench, say I.$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) That Maria has outdone herself!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“M.O.A.I. doth sway my life.” Nay, but first, let me see, let me see, let me see.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“M.O.A.I. rules my life.” Hmm, let me see, let me see, let me see.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) What dish o' poison has she dressed him!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) What a dish of poison she’s mixed for him!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) And with what wing the staniel checks at it!$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) And look how willingly he’s taking the bait.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“I may command where I adore.” Why, she may command me. I serve her, she is my lady. Why, this is evident to any formal capacity. There is no obstruction in this. And the end—what should that alphabetical position portend? If I could make that resemble something in me—Softly! M.O.A.I.—
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“I may command the one I love.” Well, she commands me. I’m her servant. She’s my boss. Why, anyone can see what this means. There’s no ambiguity here. But the end, what do those letters mean? If only I could somehow relate them to me! Hmm. M.O.A.I.—

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) O, ay, make up that.—He is now at a cold scent.$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering) Oh, bad dog.—He’s losing the scent!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) Sowter will cry upon ’t for all this, though it be as rank as a fox.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) He’ll find it again, no matter how much it stinks.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“M”—Malvolio. “M”—why, that begins my name.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“M”—Malvolio. “M”—why, that’s the first letter in my name.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) Did not I say he would work it out? The cur is excellent at faults.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) Didn’t I tell you he’d figure it out? This dog’s excellent at following false leads.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“M.” But then there is no consonancy in the sequel that suffers under probation “A” should follow but “O” does.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“M.” But then the next letter isn’t the same. “A” should be next, but instead “O” comes next.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) And “O” shall end, I hope.$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) And an “O” like a noose will end this, I hope.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) Ay, or I’ll cudgel him and make him cry “O!”$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(whispering)Yeah, or I’ll beat him up and make him yell “Oh!”$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$And then “I” comes behind.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$And then the “I” comes next.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) Ay, an you had any eye behind you, you might see more detraction at your heels than fortunes before you.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) If you had an I in the back of your head, you’d see trouble behind you.$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“M.O.A.I.” This simulation is not as the former, and yet to crush this a little, it would bow to me, for every one of these letters are in my name. Soft, here follows prose.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$M.O.A.I. This code’s not as easy to crack as the other one. But if I shake it up a little it’ll work, because every one of those letters is in my name. But wait, there’s some prose after her poem.

paragraphs.original: (reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“If this fall into thy hand, revolve. In my stars I am above thee, but be not afraid of greatness. Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em. Thy Fates open their hands. Let thy blood and spirit embrace them. And, to inure thyself to what thou art like to be, cast thy humble slough and appear fresh. Be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants.
paragraphs.translated: (he reads)$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$“If this letter falls into your hands, think carefully about what it says. By my birth I rank above you, but don’t be afraid of my greatness. Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them. Your fate awaits you. Accept it in body and spirit. To get used to the life you’ll most likely be leading soon, get rid of your low-class trappings. Show some eagerness for the new upscale lifestyle that’s waiting

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Let thy tongue tang arguments of state. Put thyself into the trick of singularity. She thus advises thee that sighs for thee. Remember who commended thy yellow stockings and wished to see thee ever cross-gartered. I say, remember. Go to, thou art made, if thou desir’st to be so; if not, let me see thee a steward still, the fellow of servants, and not worthy to touch Fortune’s fingers. Farewell. She that would alter services with thee,$NEWLINE$The Fortunate Unhappy”
paragraphs.translated: for you. Argue with a relative like a nobleman, and be rude to servants. Talk about politics and affairs of state, and act free and independent. The woman who advises you to do this loves you. Remember the woman who complimented you on your yellow stockings, and said she always wanted to see you with crisscrossing laces going up your legs—remember her. Go ahead. A happy new life is there if you want it. If you don’t want it, just keep acting like a lowly servant who’s not brave enough to grab the happiness there before him. Goodbye. Signed, she who would be your servant,$NEWLINE$The Fortunate Unhappy.”

paragraphs.original: Daylight and champaign discovers not more. This is open. I will be proud, I will read politic authors, I will baffle Sir Toby, I will wash off gross acquaintance, I will be point- devise the very man. I do not now fool myself, to let imagination jade me, for every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me. She did commend my yellow stockings of late, she did praise my leg being cross-gartered, and in this she manifests herself to my love, and with a kind of injunction, drives me to these habits of her liking. I thank my stars I am happy. I will be strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and cross-gartered, even with the swiftness of putting on. Jove and my stars be praised! Here is yet a postscript.
paragraphs.translated: This is as clear as sunlight in an open field. I’ll do it. I’ll be vain and proud, I’ll read up on politics, I’ll insult Sir Toby, I’ll get rid of my lower-class friends, and I’ll be the perfect man for her. I know I’m not fooling myself, or letting myself get carried away by my imagination, because every clue points to the fact that Lady Olivia loves me. She did compliment me on my yellow stockings recently, and she said she liked how the crisscross laces looked on my legs. That’s her way of saying she loves me. Oh, I thank my lucky stars, I’m so happy. For her I’ll be strange and condescending, and I’ll put on my yellow stockings and crisscross laces right away. Thank God and my horoscope! Here’s a postscript!.

paragraphs.original: (reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“Thou canst not choose but know who I am. If thou entertainest my love, let it appear in thy smiling. Thy smiles become thee well. Therefore in my presence still smile, dear my sweet, I prithee.”
paragraphs.translated: (reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“You must have figured out who I am. If you love me, let me know by smiling at me. You’re so attractive when you smile. Please smile whenever you’re near me, my dearest darling.”

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Jove, I thank thee! I will smile. I will do everything that thou wilt have me.
paragraphs.translated: Dear God, thank you! I’ll do everything she wants me to do.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO exits.$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$I will not give my part of this sport for a pension of thousands to be paid from the Sophy.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$I wouldn’t have missed this even for a pension of thousands of pounds, to be paid by the shah of Persia.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I could marry this wench for this device.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I could marry that Maria for thinking this up.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$So could I too.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$So could I.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$And ask no other dowry with her but such another jest.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$And I wouldn’t ask for any dowry except for her to play another trick like this one.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Nor I neither.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Neither would I.

paragraphs.original: Enter MARIA$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: MARIA enters.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Here comes my noble gull-catcher.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Here she comes, the brilliant fool-catcher.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Wilt thou set thy foot o' my neck?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$May I kiss your feet?

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Or o' mine either?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$And I too?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Shall I play my freedom at tray-trip, and become thy bondslave?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Shall I be your slave?

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I' faith, or I either?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Me too.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Why, thou hast put him in such a dream that when the image of it leaves him he must run mad.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$You’ve made him so delusional he’ll go crazy when he learns the truth.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Nay, but say true, does it work upon him?
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Did it really work?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Like aqua vitae with a midwife.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Like medicine for a sick man.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$If you will then see the fruits of the sport, mark his first approach before my lady. He will come to her in yellow stockings, and ’tis a color she abhors, and cross-gartered, a fashion she detests. And he will smile upon her, which will now be so unsuitable to her disposition, being addicted to a melancholy as she is, that it cannot but turn him into a notable contempt. If you will see it, follow me.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$If you want to really have some fun, watch him next time he’s near Lady Olivia. He’ll show up in yellow stockings—she hates yellow—and with laces crisscrossing up his legs—she hates that style of dress—and he’ll smile, which will go completely against her mood, since she’s addicted to sadness now. She’ll definitely get upset with him. If you want to watch, follow me.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$To the gates of Tartar, thou most excellent devil of wit!
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I’d follow you to the gates of Hell, you sneaky little devil!

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I’ll make one too.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I’ll come too.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter VIOLA, and the FOOL playing with a tabor$NEWLINE$VIOLA$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA and the FOOL, playing a drum, enter.$NEWLINE$VIOLA$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Save thee, friend, and thy music. Dost thou live by thy tabour?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$God bless you, my friend, and your music too. Do you make your living by playing that drum?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, sir, I live by the church.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, sir, I live by the church.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Art thou a churchman?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Oh, you’re a clergyman?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$No such matter, sir. I do live by the church; for I do live at my house, and my house doth stand by the church.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, I live by the church because I live in a house, and my house is by the church.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$So thou mayst say the king lies by a beggar if a beggar dwell near him, or the church stands by thy tabor, if thy tabor stand by the church.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$You could just as easily say that a king sleeps near a beggar if the beggar lives near him, or that the church is supported by your drum because it “stands by” your drum.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$You have said, sir. To see this age! A sentence is but a cheveril glove to a good wit. How quickly the wrong side may be turned outward!
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$You’re right, sir. What a wonderful time to be alive! Sentences can be turned inside out so easily nowadays!

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Nay, that’s certain. They that dally nicely with words may quickly make them wanton.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$That’s true. People who fool around with words too much can make words act like whores—changing all the time, and immoral too.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$I would therefore my sister had no name, sir.
