paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$That’s why I wish my sister didn’t have a name, sir.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Why, man?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Why, man?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Why, sir, her name’s a word, and to dally with that word might make my sister wanton. But, indeed, words are very rascals since bonds disgraced them.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well, her name’s a word, and if you fooled around with it you might make her into a whore. But, you know, words have been rascals ever since people started using written contracts rather than their word of honor.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Thy reason, man?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Why do you say that?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Troth, sir, I can yield you none without words, and words are grown so false, I am loath to prove reason with them.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Honestly, sir, I’d need to use words to explain why, and since words are so unreliable and false, I’d rather avoid using them in a serious discussion.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I warrant thou art a merry fellow and carest for nothing.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I bet you’re a happy fellow who doesn’t care about anything.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Not so, sir, I do care for something. But in my conscience, sir, I do not care for you. If that be to care for nothing, sir, I would it would make you invisible.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$You’re wrong, sir, I do care about something. But I’ll admit I don’t care for you. If that means I don’t care about anything, you should disappear right now, since you’re nothing.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Art not thou the Lady Olivia’s fool?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Aren’t you Lady Olivia’s fool?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly. She will keep no fool, sir, till she be married, and fools are as like husbands as pilchards are to herrings; the husband’s the bigger: I am indeed not her fool, but her corrupter of words.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, sir. Lady Olivia doesn’t want to have anything to do with foolishness. So she won’t have a fool until she gets married. Fools are to husbands as anchovies are to sardines—husbands are the bigger ones. I’m not her fool. I just make words into whores for her.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I saw thee late at the Count Orsino’s.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I saw you at Count Orsino’s recently.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb like the sun. It shines everywhere. I would be sorry, sir, but the fool should be as oft with your master as with my mistress: I think I saw your wisdom there.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I’m everywhere. Foolishness is all over the world, just like sunshine. I’d be sorry if people thought your master was less familiar with foolishness than my mistress is. I think I saw you there, you wise man.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Nay, an thou pass upon me, I’ll no more with thee. Hold, there’s expenses for thee.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Oh no, if you’re joking around with me, I’m leaving. Wait, here’s a coin for you.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send thee a beard!
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Next time God sends out a shipment of hair, I hope he gives you a beard!

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$By my troth, I’ll tell thee, I am almost sick for one, (aside) though I would not have it grow on my chin. (to fool) Is thy lady within?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Oh, I know. Seriously, I’m dying for one, (to herself) I mean, I’m dying for a man who has a beard; I don’t want one to grow on my chin. (to the FOOL) Is Lady Olivia inside?$NEWLINE$(to herself)$NEWLINE$(to the

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Would not a pair of these have bred, sir?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$If I had two of these coins, do you think they’d breed more coins?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Yes, being kept together and put to use.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Yes, if you kept them together and invested them.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia, sir, to bring a$NEWLINE$Cressida to this Troilus.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL$NEWLINE$I’d like to be like that famous pimp, Lord Pandarus, and get a
Cressida for my Troilus.$NEWLINE$Cressida for my Troilus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$(giving him money) I understand you, sir. 'Tis well begged.$NEWLINE$(giving him money)
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$(giving the FOOL money) I get what you’re driving at, sir. You’re a very clever beggar.$NEWLINE$(giving the$NEWLINE$money)

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$The matter, I hope, is not great, sir, begging but a beggar. Cressida was a beggar. My lady is within, sir. I will construe to them whence you come. Who you are and what you would are out of my welkin, I might say “element,” but the word is overworn.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$It shouldn’t be too much to ask; I’m only begging for a beggar. They say Cressida became a beggar in her old age. My lady Olivia’s inside, sir. I’ll tell them where you come from, though I don’t know who you are or what you want. I’d say I was “out of my element,” but that phrase is overused, so I’ll say I’m “out of my air.”

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The FOOL exits.$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$This fellow is wise enough to play the fool,$NEWLINE$And to do that well craves a kind of wit.$NEWLINE$He must observe their mood on whom he jests,$NEWLINE$The quality of persons, and the time,$NEWLINE$And, like the haggard, check at every feather$NEWLINE$That comes before his eye. This is a practise$NEWLINE$As full of labor as a wise man’s art,$NEWLINE$For folly that he wisely shows is fit.$NEWLINE$But wise men, folly-fall'n, quite taint their wit.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$This guy’s wise enough to play the fool, and only clever people can do that. He pays attention to the mood and social rank of the person he’s joking with, and also to the time of day. And he doesn’t let go of his target when a distraction appears. His job requires as much effort and skill as any wise man’s occupation could. And he shows he’s very smart at playing the fool, while smart people look stupid when they play the fool.

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, and SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH and SIR ANDREW enter.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Save you, gentleman.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Hello, sir.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$And you, sir.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Hello to you too, sir.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Dieu vous garde, monsieur.$NEWLINE$Dieu vous garde, monsieur.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) May God protect you, sir.$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Et vous aussi. Votre serviteur!$NEWLINE$Et vous aussi. Votre serviteur!
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) And you too, sir. I’m at your service.$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I hope, sir, you are, and I am yours.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(
stammering) Oh, good, I am too.$NEWLINE$stammering$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Will you encounter the house? My niece is desirous you should enter, if your trade be to her.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$My niece would like you to come in to the house, if your business here has to do with her.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I am bound to your niece, sir. I mean, she is the list of my voyage.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I’m headed for your niece, sir. She’s the reason I’m here.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Taste your legs, sir. Put them to motion.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Taste your legs, sir. Please go inside.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$My legs do better understand me, sir, than I understand what you mean by bidding me taste my legs.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Taste my legs? My legs stand under me, but I don’t understand what “taste your legs” means.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I mean, to go, sir, to enter.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I mean please go into the house, sir.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I will answer you with gait and entrance. But we are prevented.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I will. But now we don’t have to!

paragraphs.original: Enter OLIVIA and MARIA$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA and MARIA enter.$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain odors on you!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, beautiful and accomplished lady, may the heavens rain odors upon you!

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(aside) That youth’s a rare courtier. “Rain odors.” Well.$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(to himself) That young man’s classy. “Rain odors.” That’s good.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$My matter hath no voice, lady, but to your own most pregnant and vouchsafed ear.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$My message is not for anyone else to hear, my lady. It’s only for your willing and receptive ear.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(aside) “Odors,” “pregnant,” and “vouchsafed.” I’ll get$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$'em all three all ready.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(to himself) “Odors,” “willing,” and “deserving.” I’ll have to remember those words so I can use them later myself.$NEWLINE$(to himself) “

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to my hearing.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Close the garden door and leave me alone to hear his message.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and MARIA$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and MARIA exit.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: Give me your hand, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Give me your hand, sir.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$My duty, madam, and most humble service.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I give you my obedience and my humble service, madam.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What is your name?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What’s your name?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Cesario is your servant’s name, fair princess.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Cesario is my name—your servant’s name—fair princess.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$My servant, sir! 'Twas never merry world$NEWLINE$Since lowly feigning was call’d compliment.$NEWLINE$You’re servant to the Count Orsino, youth.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$My servant! The world’s gone downhill since fake humility started passing for compliments. You’re not my servant, young man. You’re Count Orsino’s servant.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$And he is yours, and his must needs be yours:$NEWLINE$Your servant’s servant is your servant, madam.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$But he’s your servant, so everything that’s his must be yours too. Your servant’s servant is your servant, madam.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$For him, I think not on him. For his thoughts,$NEWLINE$Would they were blanks, rather than fill’d with me.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$As for him, I never think about him. As for his thoughts, I wish he’d think about nothing at all rather than think about me all the time.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts$NEWLINE$On his behalf.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Madam, I’ve come here to try to make you like him.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$O, by your leave, I pray you,$NEWLINE$I bade you never speak again of him.$NEWLINE$But, would you undertake another suit,$NEWLINE$I had rather hear you to solicit that$NEWLINE$Than music from the spheres.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Oh, please, I’m begging you, don’t mention him again. But if you want to tell me that someone else loves me, I’d enjoy hearing that more than I’d enjoy listening to angels sing.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Dear lady—
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$My dear lady—

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Give me leave, beseech you. I did send,$NEWLINE$After the last enchantment you did here,$NEWLINE$A ring in chase of you. So did I abuse$NEWLINE$Myself, my servant, and, I fear me, you:$NEWLINE$Under your hard construction must I sit,$NEWLINE$To force that on you, in a shameful cunning$NEWLINE$Which you knew none of yours. What might you think?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Please let me say something, I’m begging you. After you cast your magic spell on me last time, I sent you a ring. I fear it was a mistake, since I tricked my servant, myself, and you too. You probably think poorly of me after I forced that ring on you with such outrageous trickery. What else could you possibly think of me?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Have you not set mine honor at the stake,$NEWLINE$And baited it with all the unmuzzled thoughts$NEWLINE$That tyrannous heart can think? To one of your receiving$NEWLINE$Enough is shown. A cypress, not a bosom,$NEWLINE$Hides my heart. So, let me hear you speak.
paragraphs.translated: Haven’t you totally dismissed my honor and integrity in your anger? For someone as intelligent as you the situation must be clear enough. I’m wearing my heart on my sleeve, and I can’t hide my feelings. So let me hear what you have to say.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I pity you.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I feel sorry for you.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$That’s a degree to love.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$That’s a step in the direction of love.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$No, not a grize. For ’tis a vulgar proof$NEWLINE$That very oft we pity enemies.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$No, not at all. It’s a perfectly ordinary experience for us to feel sorry for our enemies.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Why then methinks ’tis time to smile again.$NEWLINE$O world, how apt the poor are to be proud!$NEWLINE$If one should be a prey, how much the better$NEWLINE$To fall before the lion than the wolf! (clock strikes)$NEWLINE$clock strikes$NEWLINE$The clock upbraids me with the waste of time.$NEWLINE$Be not afraid, good youth, I will not have you.$NEWLINE$And yet when wit and youth is come to harvest,$NEWLINE$Your wife is like to reap a proper man.$NEWLINE$There lies your way, due west.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Well, enough of my whining then. That’s that! I was getting carried away with fantasies I didn’t deserve to have. But I should consider myself lucky. It’s much better to be destroyed by a noble enemy than by a cruel and heartless one. (a clock strikes) Listen to that, the clock’s scolding me for wasting my time loving you. Don’t worry, young man, I won’t stalk you. And when you’re older and wiser and ready for marriage, your future wife will have a fine husband. There’s the way back home for you, due west.$NEWLINE$(a clock strikes)

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Then westward ho!$NEWLINE$Grace and good disposition attend your ladyship!$NEWLINE$You’ll nothing, madam, to my lord by me?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Then west is where I’m headed! I wish you all the best. You do

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Stay, I prithee, tell me what thou thinkest of me.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Stay, Please, tell me what you think of me.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$That you do think you are not what you are.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I think you’re denying what you really are.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$If I think so, I think the same of you.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$If that’s true, I think the same thing about you.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Then think you right: I am not what I am.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$You’re right. I am not what I am.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I would you were as I would have you be!
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I wish you were what I wanted you to be!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Would it be better, madam, than I am?$NEWLINE$I wish it might, for now I am your fool.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Would it be better if I were that, instead of what I am? I wish I were something better, because right now I’m a big fool.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$(aside) Oh, what a deal of scorn looks beautiful$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$In the contempt and anger of his lip!$NEWLINE$A murderous guilt shows not itself more soon$NEWLINE$Than love that would seem hid. Love’s night is noon.$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA) Cesario, by the roses of the spring,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$By maidhood, honor, truth, and everything,$NEWLINE$I love thee so, that, maugre all thy pride,$NEWLINE$Nor wit nor reason can my passion hide.$NEWLINE$Do not extort thy reasons from this clause,$NEWLINE$For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause,$NEWLINE$But rather reason thus with reason fetter.$NEWLINE$Love sought is good, but given unsought better.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$(to herself) Oh, how beautiful he is even when he’s angry and full of contempt! A murderer can hide his guilt longer than someone in love can hide her love. Love shines brightly and can’t be hidden. (to VIOLA) Cesario, I swear by the spring roses, by virginity, honor, truth, and everything, I swear I love you. I love you so much that I can’t hide my passion for you, as clever as I am. Don’t assume that because I’m pursuing you there’s no reason to pursue me. Put two and two together and realize that asking for love is good, but getting it without asking is much better.$NEWLINE$(to herself)$NEWLINE$(to

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$By innocence I swear, and by my youth$NEWLINE$I have one heart, one bosom, and one truth,$NEWLINE$And that no woman has, nor never none$NEWLINE$Shall mistress be of it, save I alone.$NEWLINE$And so adieu, good madam. Nevermore$NEWLINE$Will I my master’s tears to you deplore.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$And I swear by my youth and innocence that I’ve only got one heart and one love to give, and that I’ve never given them to a woman and never will. So goodbye, my lady. I won’t ever come to complain about my lord’s love for you again.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Yet come again, for thou perhaps mayst move$NEWLINE$That heart, which now abhors, to like his love.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Then come again for another reason. You might still be able to make yourself fall in love with me, the person he loves, even though you hate me now.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$FABIAN
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN enter.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$FABIAN

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$No, faith, I’ll not stay a jot longer.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$No, I won’t stay a second longer.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Thy reason, dear venom, give thy reason.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Why are you leaving, my angry friend?

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$You must needs yield your reason, Sir Andrew.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Yes, you have to tell us why, Sir Andrew.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Marry, I saw your niece do more favors to the Count’s servingman than ever she bestowed upon me. I saw ’t i' the orchard.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Well, because I saw your niece Olivia treat the count’s messenger better than she’s ever treated me. I saw it in the orchard.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Did she see thee the while, old boy? Tell me that.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Did she see you there the whole time, old boy? Tell me that.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$As plain as I see you now.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Yes, she saw me quite clearly.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$This was a great argument of love in her toward you.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Well, that proves she’s in love with you.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$'Slight, will you make an ass o' me?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Are you trying to make fun of me?

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$I will prove it legitimate, sir, upon the oaths of judgment and reason.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$No, I’ll prove it with airtight evidence and logical argument.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$And they have been grand-jurymen since before Noah was a sailor.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$And you can’t deny evidence and argument—They’ve been around since Noah’s ark.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$She did show favor to the youth in your sight only to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valor, to put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver. You should then have accosted her, and with some excellent jests, fire-new from the mint, you should have banged the youth into dumbness.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$She flirted with the messenger boy to exasperate you, fire up your passions, and make you angry and jealous. You should have run up to her, unleashed a few excellent quips invented on the spot, and rendered the young man speechless.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: This was looked for at your hand, and this was balked. The double gilt of this opportunity you let time wash off, and you are now sailed into the north of my lady’s opinion, where you will hang like an icicle on a Dutchman’s beard, unless you do redeem it by some laudable attempt either of valor or policy.
paragraphs.translated: That’s what she was expecting, and you let her down. You wasted a golden opportunity, and now my lady thinks badly of you. You can only raise her opinion of you with some impressive act of courage or complicated intrigue.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$An ’t be any way, it must be with valor, for policy I hate. I had as lief be a Brownist as a politician.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I’ll have to do something courageous then, because I hate intrigue. I’d rather be a heretic than a schemer with fancy plots.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the basis of valor. Challenge me the count’s youth to fight with him. Hurt him in eleven places. My niece shall take note of it, and assure thyself, there is no love-broker in the world can more prevail in man’s commendation with woman than report of valor.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Well then, improve your situation with a show of courage. Challenge the count’s young servant to a fight. Hurt him in eleven different places. My niece Olivia will notice, and let me tell you, no matchmaker in the world can get you a woman faster than a reputation for courage.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$It’s really the only way, Sir Andrew.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Will either of you bear me a challenge to him?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Will either of you give him the message that I’m challenging him to a duel?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Go, write it in a martial hand. Be curst and brief. It is no matter how witty, so it be eloquent and full of invention. Taunt him with the license of ink. If thou “thou”-est him some thrice, it shall not be amiss; and as many lies as will lie in thy sheet of paper, although the sheet were big enough for the bed of Ware in England, set 'em down. Go, about it. Let there be gall enough in thy ink, though thou write with a goose-pen, no matter. About it.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Go ahead and write it down. Make your handwriting look like a soldier’s. Be pointed and brief. It doesn’t need to be witty as long as it’s eloquent and imaginative. Taunt him as much as you want, since you’re only doing it in writing. It’s fine if you refer to him as “thou” instead of
“you.” Write down as many lies as you can fit on a sheet of paper. Go ahead, get on with it. You may be using an ordinary pen, but you can fill it with poison ink. Now get busy.$NEWLINE$“you.”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Where shall I find you?
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Where will I find you when I’ve finished it?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$We’ll call thee at the cubiculo. Go.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$We’ll come find you in the bedroom. Go on.

paragraphs.original: Exit SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW exits.$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$This is a dear manikin to you, Sir Toby.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$This precious little guy is putty in your hands, Sir Toby.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand strong, or so.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$He must like me, since he’s let me spend two thousand of his ducats.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$We shall have a rare letter from him: but you’ll not deliver ’t?
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$His letter’s going to be hilarious. But you’re not going to deliver it, are you?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Never trust me, then. And by all means stir on the youth to an answer. I think oxen and wainropes cannot hale them together. For Andrew, if he were opened and you find so much blood in his liver as will clog the foot of a flea, I’ll eat the rest of the anatomy.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Never trust me again if I don’t. And by all means see if you can get the young man to answer it. I don’t think a team of oxen could get them close enough to fight. If you dissected Andrew and found enough red blood in his
liver for a flea to eat, then I’d eat the rest of his corpse. He’s a coward.$NEWLINE$liver$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$And his opposite, the youth, bears in his visage no great presage of cruelty.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$And his opponent, the young messenger, doesn’t look like he’d be very aggressive in a fight.

paragraphs.original: Enter MARIA$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: MARIA enters.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Look where the youngest wren of nine comes.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Here comes my little bird.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourself into stitches, follow me. Yond gull Malvolio is turned heathen, a very renegado. For there is no Christian that means to be saved by believing rightly can ever believe such impossible passages of grossness. He’s in yellow stockings.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Listen, if you want a good laugh—and I mean a side-splitting one—then follow me. That gullible idiot Malvolio must have renounced Christianity, since no Christian could do such outrageous things as he’s doing. He’s wearing yellow stockings.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$And cross-gartered?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$With crisscrossed laces?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Most villanously, like a pedant that keeps a school i' the church. I have dogged him, like his murderer. He does obey every point of the letter that I dropped to betray him. He does smile his face into more lines than is in the new map with the augmentation of the Indies. You have not seen such a thing as ’tis. I can hardly forbear hurling things at him. I know my lady will strike him. If she do, he’ll smile and take ’t for a great favor.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Oh, he looks like a pathetic Sunday school teacher. I’ve stalked him like a murderer, and he’s done everything the letter told him to. He smiles so much his face has more lines in it than a map of the East Indies. You’ve never seen anything like it. I can hardly keep myself from throwing things at him. I know that my lady’s going to end up hitting him. And when she does, he’ll imagine she’s flirting with him.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come, bring us, bring us where he is.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come on, take us to him.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO enter.$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I would not by my will have troubled you,$NEWLINE$But, since you make your pleasure of your pains,$NEWLINE$I will no further chide you.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I really didn’t want to inconvenience you. But since you seem to enjoy helping me, I won’t nag you to stop any more.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I could not stay behind you. My desire,$NEWLINE$More sharp than filèd steel, did spur me forth.$NEWLINE$And not all love to see you, though so much$NEWLINE$As might have drawn one to a longer voyage,$NEWLINE$But jealousy what might befall your travel,$NEWLINE$Being skilless in these parts, which to a stranger,$NEWLINE$Unguided and unfriended, often prove$NEWLINE$Rough and unhospitable. My willing love,$NEWLINE$The rather by these arguments of fear,$NEWLINE$Set forth in your pursuit.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I couldn’t stay behind after you left. I just felt a sharp desire to follow you. It wasn’t just that I wanted to see you, though I very much did want that. I was also worried about what might happen to you while you were traveling, since you’re not familiar with this area, and it’s rough and unwelcoming to a stranger with no guide. I followed you because I love you and I was worried about you.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$My kind Antonio,$NEWLINE$I can no other answer make but thanks,$NEWLINE$And thanks, and ever thanks. And oft good turns$NEWLINE$Are shuffled off with such uncurrent pay.$NEWLINE$But were my worth as is my conscience, firm,$NEWLINE$You should find better dealing. What’s to do?$NEWLINE$Shall we go see the relics of this town?
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$My friend Antonio, all I can say is thank you. I know words are cheap. If I had any money I’d back up my gratitude with cash. Anyway, what should we do? Should we go see the sights in the town?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, sir. Best first go see your lodging.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$We can do that tomorrow, sir. First we should make sure you have somewhere to stay.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I am not weary, and ’tis long to night:$NEWLINE$I pray you, let us satisfy our eyes$NEWLINE$With the memorials and the things of fame$NEWLINE$That do renown this city.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I’m not tired, and night is a long time away. Come on, let’s go see the sights.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Would you’d pardon me;$NEWLINE$I do not without danger walk these streets:$NEWLINE$Once in a sea-fight 'gainst the Count his galleys$NEWLINE$I did some service, of such note indeed,$NEWLINE$That were I ta'en here it would scarce be answered.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I’m sorry, but I can’t. You see, it’s dangerous for me to walk in these streets. Once in a battle at sea I did a lot of damage to Count Orsino’s warships. If they arrested me here, it’d be the end of me.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Belike you slew great number of his people?
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$You probably killed a lot of his men?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$The offence is not of such a bloody nature;$NEWLINE$Albeit the quality of the time and quarrel$NEWLINE$Might well have given us bloody argument.$NEWLINE$It might have since been answered in repaying$NEWLINE$What we took from them, which, for traffic’s sake,$NEWLINE$Most of our city did. Only myself stood out;$NEWLINE$For which, if I be lapsèd in this place,$NEWLINE$I shall pay dear.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$No, I didn’t do anything as violent as that, though we would’ve been justified in shedding a little blood over the matter. The whole quarrel might have been resolved since then when we repaid what we stole from them—which most of our city did, for the sake of friendly trade relations. I was the only one who refused to give back what I stole. That’s why I’ll pay dearly if they find me here.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Do not then walk too open.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Then don’t make yourself too conspicuous.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$It doth not fit me. Hold, sir, here’s my purse.$NEWLINE$(giving him money)$NEWLINE$(giving him money)$NEWLINE$In the south suburbs, at the Elephant,$NEWLINE$Is best to lodge. I will bespeak our diet,$NEWLINE$Whiles you beguile the time and feed your knowledge$NEWLINE$With viewing of the town. There shall you have me.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$You’re right. Hang on a minute, here’s some money for you. (he gives SEBASTIAN money) The best place to stay around here is an inn called the Elephant, in the suburbs south of the city. I’ll arrange for our meals while you enjoy yourself and educate yourself by looking at the town. You’ll find me at the Elephant.$NEWLINE$(he gives$NEWLINE$money)

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Why I your purse?
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Why are you giving me your purse?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Haply your eye shall light upon some toy$NEWLINE$You have desire to purchase, and your store,$NEWLINE$I think, is not for idle markets, sir.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Maybe you’ll see some little trinket you want to buy. I doubt you’ve got enough money for little purchases like that.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I’ll be your purse-bearer and leave you$NEWLINE$For an hour.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I’ll hold on to your money and leave you for an hour.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$To the Elephant.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$We’ll meet at the Elephant.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I do remember.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I remember.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter OLIVIA and MARIA$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA and MARIA enter.$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I have sent after him. He says he’ll come.$NEWLINE$How shall I feast him? What bestow of him?$NEWLINE$For youth is bought more oft than begged or borrow’d.$NEWLINE$I speak too loud.—$NEWLINE$Where’s Malvolio? He is sad and civil$NEWLINE$And suits well for a servant with my fortunes.$NEWLINE$Where is Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I’ve sent for him. He says he’ll come. What kind of food should I serve him? What presents should I give him? It’s easier to buy young people than to beg or borrow them. Oh, I’m talking too loud.—Where’s Malvolio? He’s very serious, which is right for someone in mourning like me. Where is Malvolio?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$He’s coming, madam; but in very strange manner. He is sure possessed, madam.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$He’s coming, madam; but he’s acting very strangely. He must be possessed by the devil.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Why, what’s the matter? Does he rave?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Why, what’s the matter with him? Is he talking nonsense?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$No, madam, he does nothing but smile. Your ladyship were best to have some guard about you if he come, for sure the man is tainted in ’s wits.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$No, he just smiles. You should have a guard nearby if he comes in here, because he’s clearly disturbed.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Go call him hither.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Ask him in here.

paragraphs.original: Exit MARIA$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: MARIA exits.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: I am as mad as he,$NEWLINE$If sad and merry madness equal be.
paragraphs.translated: I’m as crazy as he is, if sad craziness and happy craziness are equivalent.

paragraphs.original: Enter MARIA, with MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$MARIA$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated: MARIA enters with MALVOLIO.$NEWLINE$MARIA$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: How now, Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated: What’s going on, Malvolio?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sweet lady, ho, ho.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Hello, sweet lady.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Smilest thou? I sent for thee upon a sad occasion.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$You’re smiling? I sent for you about a sad occasion.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sad, lady! I could be sad. This does make some obstruction in the blood, this cross-gartering, but what of that? If it please the eye of one, it is with me as the very true sonnet is, “Please one, and please all.”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sad, my lady! I could be sad if I wanted to be. These crisscrossing laces do cut off the circulation in my legs a bit, but who cares? As the sonnet says, “If you please one special person, you please everyone who matters.”

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Why, how dost thou, man? What is the matter with thee?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Why, what’s going on? What’s the matter with you?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Not black in my mind, though yellow in my legs. It did come to his hands, and commands shall be executed. I think we do know the sweet Roman hand.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$My legs may be yellow, but I don’t feel blue. It was addressed to him, and orders must be obeyed. I think we know whose fancy handwriting that was.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Don’t you think you should go to bed, Malvolio?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$To bed? “Ay, sweetheart, and I’ll come to thee.”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$To bed! “Yes, sweetheart, I’ll come to you.”

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$God comfort thee! Why dost thou smile so, and kiss thy hand so oft?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$For heaven’s sake, why are you smiling like that and kissing your hand so much?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$How do you, Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$How are you feeling, Malvolio?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$At your request! Yes, nightingales answer daws!
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$You’re asking me! Noble people don’t answer to peasants!

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness before my lady?
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Why are you acting so brazen toward my lady?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“Be not afraid of greatness.” 'Twas well writ.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“Don’t be afraid of greatness.” That was well written.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What meanest thou by that, Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What do you mean by that, Malvolio?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“Some are born great—”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“Some are born great—”

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Ha?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“Some achieve greatness—”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“Some achieve greatness—”

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What sayest thou?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What are you saying?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“And some have greatness thrust upon them.”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“And some have greatness thrust upon them.”

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Heaven restore thee!
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Heaven help you!

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“Remember who commended thy yellow stockings—”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“Remember who liked your yellow stockings—”

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Thy yellow stockings?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Your yellow stockings?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“And wished to see thee cross-gartered.”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“And wanted to see you with laces crisscrossed over your legs.”

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Cross-gartered?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Crisscrossed?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“Go to, thou art made, if thou desirest to be so—”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“Go ahead. A happy new life is there if you want it—”

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Am I made?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Am I a new life?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“If not, let me see thee a servant still.”
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$“If you don’t want it, just keep acting like a lowly servant.”

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Why, this is very midsummer madness.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$This is completely insane.

paragraphs.original: Enter SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT enters.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Madam, the young gentleman of the Count Orsino’s is returned. I could hardly entreat him back. He attends your ladyship’s pleasure.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Madam, Count Orsino’s young messenger has returned. It was hard to get him to come back, but he’s here now, waiting for you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I’ll come to him.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I’ll go to him.

paragraphs.original: Exit SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT exits.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: Good Maria, let this fellow be looked to. Where’s my cousin Toby? Let some of my people have a special care of him. I would not have him miscarry for the half of my dowry.
paragraphs.translated: Maria, take care of this poor fellow here. Where’s my cousin Toby? Have some of my servants take care of Malvolio. I’d give half my dowry to keep anything bad from happening to him.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt OLIVIA and MARIA$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA and MARIA exit.$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Oh, ho! Do you come near me now? No worse man than Sir Toby to look to me. This concurs directly with the letter. She sends him on purpose that I may appear stubborn to him, for she incites me to that in the letter. “Cast thy humble slough,” says she. “Be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants. Let thy tongue tang with arguments of state. Put thyself into the trick of singularity,” and consequently sets down the manner how: as, a sad face, a reverend carriage, a slow tongue, in the habit of some sir of note, and so forth. I have limed her, but it is Jove’s doing, and Jove make me thankful! And when she went away now, “Let this fellow be looked to.” “Fellow!” Not “Malvolio,” nor after my degree, but “fellow.” Why, everything adheres together, that no dram of a scruple, no scruple of a scruple, no obstacle, no incredulous or unsafe circumstance—what can be said? Nothing that can be can come between me and the full prospect of my hopes. Well, Jove, not I, is the doer of this, and he is to be thanked.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Oh ho! Look at me now! No less a person than Sir Toby, Lady Olivia’s own relative, is going to take care of me. This is just what the letter said. She’s sending him to me on purpose, so I can be rude to him just like she said in the letter. “Get rid of your low-class trapping,” she said. “Argue with a relative of mine like a nobleman, and be rude to servants. Talk about politics and affairs of state, and act free and independent.” And then she explains how to do it: I should have a serious face and dignified demeanor, well-modulated speech, acting like a distinguished gentleman and so on. I’ve got her now, but I’ve got God to thank for it! And when she left just now, she said “Take care of this poor fellow here.” Fellow!” Not “Malvolio,” not anything referring to my low station in life, but “fellow.” Everything’s going perfectly. Not the tiniest ounce, not the littlest insignificant amount of trouble or bad luck could ruin it—what can I say? Nothing can come between me and the fulfillment of all my hopes. Well, God is responsible for that, not me, and he deserves thanks.

paragraphs.original: Enter MARIA, with SIR TOBY BELCH and FABIAN$NEWLINE$MARIA$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$FABIAN
paragraphs.translated: MARIA enters with SIR TOBY BELCH and FABIAN.$NEWLINE$MARIA$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$FABIAN

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Which way is he, in the name of sanctity? If all the devils of hell be drawn in little, and Legion himself possessed him, yet I’ll speak to him.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Where is he, for God’s sake? I don’t care if all the devils in hell crammed together to possess him, I still want to speak to him.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Here he is, here he is. How is’t with you, sir? How is’t with you, man?
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Here he is, here he is. How are you, sir?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Go off, I discard you. Let me enjoy my private. Go off.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Go away. I don’t want to see your face. Let me enjoy my privacy. Go away.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$(to SIR TOBY BELCH) Lo, how hollow the fiend speaks within him! Did not I tell you? Sir Toby, my lady prays you to have a care of him.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$(to SIR TOBY BELCH) Ooh, listen to the scary devil speaking from inside him! Didn’t I tell you? Sir Toby, Lady Olivia wants you to take care of him.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Aha! Does she so?
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Ah-ha! Does she?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(to FABIAN and MARIA) Go to, go to! Peace, peace. We must deal gently with him. Let me alone.—How do you, Malvolio? How is ’t with you? What, man, defy the devil! Consider, he’s an enemy to mankind.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(to FABIAN and MARIA) Come on, come on! Calm down, calm down. We need to treat him gently. Let me take care of this.—How are you, Malvolio? How are things? Come on, man, just say no to the devil! Think about it, he’s the enemy of mankind.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Do you know what you say?
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Do you even know what you’re talking about?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$(to SIR TOBY BELCH) La you, an you speak ill of the devil, how he takes it at heart! Pray God, he be not bewitched!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$(to SIR TOBY BELCH) Look at that, he acts insulted if you say bad things about the devil! I hope to God he’s not bewitched!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Carry his water to the wisewoman.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Get a urine sample and take it to a witch doctor to find out.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Marry, and it shall be done tomorrow morning if I live. My lady would not lose him for more than I’ll say.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Sure thing, we’ll do it tomorrow morning. My lady would never want to lose him.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$How now, mistress?
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$What are you saying, mistress?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$O Lord!
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Oh, Lord!

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(to MARIA) Prithee, hold thy peace. This is not the way. Do you not see you move him? Let me alone with him.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(to MARIA) Please, keep quiet. This is not the way to act. Don’t you see you’re upsetting him? Leave me alone with him.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$No way but gentleness, gently, gently. The fiend is rough and will not be roughly used.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Gentleness is the only way to go—gently, gently. The devil inside him is rough, but we can’t treat it roughly.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(to MALVOLIO) Why, how now, my bawcock! How dost thou, chuck?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(to the imaginary devil inside MALVOLIO) So how are you, my pretty little bird? How are you doing in there, sweet little chicken?$NEWLINE$(to the imaginary devil inside$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sir!
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sir!

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Ay, Biddy, come with me.—What, man! 'Tis not for gravity to play at cherry-pit with Satan. Hang him, foul collier!
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Yes, dear little chick, come along with me.—Shut up, man! You’re serious enough to know not to play games with Satan. Damn that dirty black coalminer of a devil!

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Get him to say his prayers, good Sir Toby, get him to pray.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$Get him to say his prayers, Sir Toby, get him to pray.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$My prayers, minx?
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$My prayers, you hussy?

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$(to SIR TOBY BELCH) No, I warrant you, he will not hear of godliness.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$(to SIR TOBY BELCH) No, I’m telling you, he refuses to hear anything about religion.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Go, hang yourselves all! You are idle, shallow things. I am not of your element. You shall know more hereafter.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Go hang yourselves, all of you! You’re all lazy and shallow. I’m not like you. I have a higher future waiting for me. You’ll know more about it later.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO exits.$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Is ’t possible?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Is it possible?

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$If this were played upon a stage now, I could condemn it as an improbable fiction.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$If this were a play, I’d complain it was unrealistic.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$His very genius hath taken the infection of the device, man.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$He’s really taken this prank to heart. He’s playing the role perfectly.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take air and taint.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$No, follow him now, before he divulges the prank and ruins everything.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Why, we shall make him mad indeed.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Wow, we’re really going to drive him crazy.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$The house will be the quieter.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$The house will be so much quieter.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come, we’ll have him in a dark room and bound. My niece is already in the belief that he’s mad. We may carry it thus, for our pleasure and his penance, till our very pastime, tired out of breath, prompt us to have mercy on him, at which time we will bring the device to the bar and crown thee for a finder of madmen. But see, but see!
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come on, let’s put him in a dark room and tie him up. My niece already thinks he’s insane. We can go on like this, punishing him and having some fun, until we’re tired of it. Then we can take mercy on him and let him out, and talk about how well the joke went. We’ll also worship you for setting up this trick. Let’s do it, let’s do it!

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW enters.$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$More matter for a May morning.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Here’s more insanity for us.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(presenting a paper) Here’s the challenge, read it. Warrant there’s vinegar and pepper in ’t.$NEWLINE$(presenting a paper)
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(presenting them a piece of paper) Here’s the challenge, read it. It’s bursting with fighting words.$NEWLINE$(presenting them a piece of paper)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Is ’t so saucy?
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Is it that aggressive?

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Ay, is ’t, I warrant him. Do but read.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Yes, it is, I think. Just read it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Give me. (reads) “Youth, whatsoever thou art, thou art but a scurvy fellow.”$NEWLINE$(reads)
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Give it to me. (he reads) “Young man, whatever you are, you’re a real scum bucket.”$NEWLINE$(he reads)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Good, and valiant.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Nice. Very courageous.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(reads) “Wonder not, nor admire not in thy mind, why I do call thee so, for I will show thee no reason for ’t.”$NEWLINE$(reads)
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(reading) “Don’t even ask why I call you that, because I won’t give you any explanation.”$NEWLINE$(reading)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$A good note, that keeps you from the blow of the law.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$That’s a good thing to put in—it keeps you from getting in trouble with the law.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(reads) “Thou comest to the lady Olivia, and in my sight she uses thee kindly. But thou liest in thy throat. That is not the matter I challenge thee for.”$NEWLINE$(reads)
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(reading) “You come to see the lady Olivia, and she’s kind to you. But you’re a complete liar. That’s not why I’m challenging you to a duel.”$NEWLINE$(reading)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Very brief, and to exceeding good sense—less.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Nice and short and full of good sense—or should I say nonsense?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(reads) “I will waylay thee going home, where if it be thy chance to kill me—”$NEWLINE$(reads)
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(reading) “I’ll ambush you on your way home, and if you’re lucky enough to kill me—”$NEWLINE$(reading)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Good.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Good.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(reads) “Thou killest me like a rogue and a villain.”$NEWLINE$(reads)
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(reading) “You’ll be killing me like a common criminal, a mugger.”$NEWLINE$(reading)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Still you keep o' the windy side of the law. Good.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$You still haven’t said anything incriminating. Good.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(reads) “Fare thee well, and God have mercy upon one of our souls. He may have mercy upon mine, but my hope is better, and so look to thyself. Thy friend, as thou usest him, and thy sworn enemy,$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$Andrew Aguecheek”
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(reading) “Good luck, and may God have mercy on one of our souls. He may have mercy upon mine. But I have a better chance of surviving, so watch out. Signed, your friend, if you treat him right, and your sworn enemy,$NEWLINE$(reading)$NEWLINE$Andrew Aguecheek”

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If this letter move him not, his legs cannot. I’ll give ’t him.
paragraphs.translated: If this letter doesn’t make him fight, I don’t know what will. I’ll give it to him.

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$You may have very fit occasion for ’t. He is now in some commerce with my lady and will by and by depart.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$You might have a great opportunity to give it to him right now. He’s conducting some business with my lady, and sooner or later he’ll leave.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Go, Sir Andrew. Scout me for him at the corner the orchard like a bum-baily. So soon as ever thou seest him, draw, and as thou drawest, swear horrible, for it comes to pass oft that a terrible oath, with a swaggering accent sharply twanged off, gives manhood more approbation than ever proof itself would have earned him. Away!
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Go, Sir Andrew. Look out for him in the corner of the orchard as if you were a sheriff’s deputy. As soon as you see him, draw your sword, and as you draw it, start swearing horribly. Sometimes a terrible swear word, like a well-shot arrow, makes you look more brave and manly than getting in a fight would. Now go!

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Nay, let me alone for swearing.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Don’t worry about me not swearing enough.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW exits.$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Now will not I deliver his letter, for the behavior of the young gentleman gives him out to be of good capacity and breeding. His employment between his lord and my niece confirms no less. Therefore this letter, being so excellently ignorant, will breed no terror in the youth. He will find it comes from a clodpole. But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by word of mouth, set upon Aguecheek a notable report of valor, and drive the gentleman (as I know his youth will aptly receive it) into a most hideous opinion of his rage, skill, fury, and impetuosity. This will so fright them both that they will kill one another by the look, like cockatrices.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I won’t deliver this letter. The young gentleman’s behavior shows that he’s sensible and has good manners. The fact that he serves as a go-between for his lord and my niece Olivia confirms this. So this letter, which is so incredibly stupid and ignorant, isn’t going to scare him at all. He’ll just think an idiot wrote it. But I’ll deliver Sir Andrew’s challenge by word of mouth, describing Sir Andrew as courageous in battle and convincing the young gentleman that Sir Andrew is furious, impetuous, and a skilled fighter (he’ll believe me because he’s young). This will make them both so afraid that they’ll kill each other just by looking at each other.

paragraphs.original: Enter OLIVIA, with VIOLA$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$VIOLA
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA enters with VIOLA.$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$VIOLA

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Here he comes with your niece. Give them way till he take leave, and presently after him.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Here comes the messenger with your niece. Leave them alone until he sets off home, and then follow him.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I will meditate the while upon some horrid message for a challenge.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Meanwhile, I’ll think of some horrible way to phrase the challenge.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH, FABIAN, and MARIA$NEWLINE$Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$FABIAN$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH, FABIAN, and MARIA exit.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$FABIAN$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I have said too much unto a heart of stone$NEWLINE$And laid mine honor too unchary on ’t.$NEWLINE$There’s something in me that reproves my fault,$NEWLINE$But such a headstrong potent fault it is$NEWLINE$That it but mocks reproof.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I’ve said too much to someone with a heart of stone. I’ve foolishly jeopardized my honor and reputation. I hate myself for behaving that way, but I just had to, and no criticism could have stopped me.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$With the same 'havior that your passion bears$NEWLINE$Goes on my master’s grief.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$My lord acts just as crazy with love as you do.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Here, wear this jewel for me. 'Tis my picture.$NEWLINE$Refuse it not. It hath no tongue to vex you.$NEWLINE$And I beseech you come again tomorrow.$NEWLINE$What shall you ask of me that I’ll deny,$NEWLINE$That honor, saved, may upon asking give?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Here, take this piece of jewelry. There’s a picture of me inside. Don’t refuse it. It won’t annoy you like me, because it doesn’t have a voice. And I beg you, please come here again tomorrow. What could you possibly ask of me that I wouldn’t give you, as long as it didn’t damage my honor and self-respect?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Nothing but this: your true love for my master.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Nothing, except your true love for my lord.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$How with mine honor may I give him that$NEWLINE$Which I have given to you?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$How could I honorably give him what I’ve already given you?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I will acquit you.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I’ll give it back to you.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Well, come again tomorrow. Fare thee well.$NEWLINE$A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Just come again tomorrow. Good-bye. A devil like you could lead me to hell.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA exits.$NEWLINE$OLIVIA exits

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and FABIAN$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$FABIAN
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH and FABIAN enter.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$FABIAN

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Gentleman, God save thee.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Hello, sir.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$And you, sir.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Hello to you.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$That defense thou hast, betake thee to ’t. Of what nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know not, but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody as the hunter, attends thee at the orchard end. Dismount thy tuck, be yare in thy preparation, for thy assailant is quick, skillful and deadly.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$You’d better think up a way to defend yourself. I don’t know what you’ve done to upset him, but someone has challenged you to a duel. He’s riled up and bloodthirsty, and he’s waiting for you at the back of the orchard. Draw your sword and get on your toes, because your assailant is quick, skillful, and deadly.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$You mistake, sir. I am sure no man hath any quarrel to me. My remembrance is very free and clear from any image of offense done to any man.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$There must be some mistake, sir. I’m sure nobody would have any reason to fight with me. I can’t remember anything I’ve ever done to offend anyone.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$You’ll find it otherwise, I assure you. Therefore, if you hold your life at any price, betake you to your guard, for your opposite hath in him what youth, strength, skill, and wrath can furnish man withal.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$You’re wrong about that, I assure you. So if you value your life at all, be on your guard. Your opponent has enough youth, strength, skill, and anger to outfight anyone.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I pray you, sir, what is he?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$But who is this person, sir?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$He is knight, dubbed with unhatched rapier and on carpet consideration, but he is a devil in private brawl. Souls and bodies hath he divorced three, and his incensement at this moment is so implacable that satisfaction can be none but by pangs of death and sepulchre. Hob, nob, is his word. “Give ’t or take ’t.”
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$He’s a knight. He was made a knight because of his court connections, but when he’s fighting a civilian he’s a real monster. He’s killed three people, and he’s so furious right now that the only thing that will satisfy him is seeing you die. “Fight to the death” is his motto.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I will return again into the house and desire some conduct of the lady. I am no fighter. I have heard of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on others, to taste their valor. Belike this is a man of that quirk.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I’ll go back inside and ask the lady for some kind of escort. I’m not a fighter. I’ve heard of men who pick fights with other people on purpose, just to see how brave they are. This man is probably like that.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Sir, no. His indignation derives itself out of a very competent injury. Therefore get you on and give him his desire. Back you shall not to the house, unless you undertake that with me which with as much safety you might answer him. Therefore on, or strip your sword stark naked, for meddle you must, that’s certain, or forswear to wear iron about you.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$No, sir. He’s furious because you insulted him, and he has a right to satisfaction. So go out there and give him what he wants. You can’t go back into the house unless you want to fight with me—and if you’re willing to do that, you might as well just go and fight with him. So go to the orchard, or take out your sword right now. You’re going to have to fight one way or another, there’s no doubt about that, or else you’ll have to stop wearing a sword and claiming to be a gentleman.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$This is as uncivil as strange. I beseech you, do me this courteous office, as to know of the knight what my offense to him is. It is something of my negligence, nothing of my purpose.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$This is as rude as it is strange. Please, do me this one favor: find out what I’ve done to offend this knight. It must be something I did accidentally.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I will do so. Signior Fabian, stay you by this gentleman till my return.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I will do so. Mr. Fabian, stay with this gentleman until I come back.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY exits.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Excuse me, sir, do you know anything about this?

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$I know the knight is incensed against you, even to a mortal arbitrament, but nothing of the circumstance more.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$I know the knight is furious with you, so much that he’s willing to fight you to the death, but I don’t know anything else about it.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I beseech you, what manner of man is he?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$What kind of man is he?

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Nothing of that wonderful promise, to read him by his form, as you are like to find him in the proof of his valor. He is, indeed, sir, the most skillful, bloody, and fatal opposite that you could possibly have found in any part of Illyria. Will you walk towards him? I will make your peace with him if I can.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$He’s not much to look at, but he’s very brave in battle. He really is the most skillful, bloodthirsty, and dangerous opponent you can find in Illyria. Do you want to go see him? I’ll try to calm him down for you if I can.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I shall be much bound to you for ’t. I am one that had rather go with sir priest than sir knight. I care not who knows so much of my mettle.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I’d be very grateful to you if you did. I’m much more of a religious type than a fighter, and I don’t care who knows it.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, with SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH enters with SIR ANDREW.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Why, man, he’s a very devil. I have not seen such a firago. I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all, and he gives me the stuck-in with such a mortal motion, that it is inevitable. And on the answer, he pays you as surely as your feet hit the ground they step on. They say he has been fencer to the Sophy.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Wow, he’s a real devil. I’ve never seen such a monster. I had a round with him, and his sword thrust is so deadly that you can’t even duck out of the way. And when he strikes back at you, he’ll hit you as sure as you’re standing there. They say he used to fence for the shah of Persia.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Pox on ’t! I’ll not meddle with him.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$That’s it! I won’t mess with him.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Ay, but he will not now be pacified. Fabian can scarce hold him yonder.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Yes, but now there’s no way to calm him down. Fabian can hardly control him over there.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Plague on ’t, an I thought he had been valiant and so cunning in fence, I’d have seen him damned ere I’d have challenged him. Let him let the matter slip, and I’ll give him my horse, gray Capilet.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Darn it, if I’d guessed he was so brave and such a good swordsman, I never would have challenged him. I’ll give him my gray horse Capilet if he forgets the whole thing.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I’ll make the motion. Stand here, make a good show on ’t.$NEWLINE$This shall end without the perdition of souls. (aside) Marry,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$I’ll ride your horse as well as I ride you.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I’ll give it a try. Stay right here and try to look good. This may end without anyone getting killed. (to himself) I’ll ride your horse just like I ride you.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Enter FABIAN and VIOLA$NEWLINE$FABIAN$NEWLINE$VIOLA
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN and VIOLA enter.$NEWLINE$FABIAN$NEWLINE$VIOLA

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: (to FABIAN) I have his horse to take up the quarrel. I have persuaded him the youth’s a devil.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: (to FABIAN) He’s given me his horse to try to avoid the fight—I’ve persuaded him that the young man is a fighting machine.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$He is as horribly conceited of him, and pants and looks pale, as if a bear were at his heels.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$He’s just as terrified of Sir Andrew. He’s pale and hyperventilating, as if a bear were chasing him.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA) There’s no remedy, sir; he will fight with you for ’s oath sake. Marry, he hath better bethought him of his quarrel, and he finds that now scarce to be worth talking of. Therefore, draw for the supportance of his vow. He protests he will not hurt you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA) There’s nothing you can do about it, sir. He insists on fighting with you because he swore he would. But he’s thought over his reason for challenging you to fight, and he realizes it’s so insignificant that it’s not worth thinking about. So draw your sword so he can carry out his vow. He promises not to hurt you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$(aside) Pray God defend me! A little thing would make me tell them how much I lack of a man.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$(to herself) God help me! If anything happens I’m going to have to tell them exactly how unmanly I am.$NEWLINE$(to herself)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Give ground, if you see him furious.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Back off if he seems really furious.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come, Sir Andrew, there’s no remedy. The gentleman will, for his honor’s sake, have one bout with you. He cannot by the duello avoid it. But he has promised me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier, he will not hurt you. Come on, to ’t.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come on, Sir Andrew, there’s nothing you can do about it. The gentleman insists on fighting a round with you, for the sake of his honor. The rules of dueling say he has to. But as a gentleman and a soldier he’s promised me he won’t hurt you. Come on, get ready.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Pray God, he keep his oath!
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I hope to God he keeps his promise!

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I do assure you, ’tis against my will.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I swear to you, I don’t want to be doing this.

paragraphs.original: They draw swords Enter ANTONIO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: They draw their swords. ANTONIO enters.$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Put up your sword. If this young gentleman$NEWLINE$Have done offence, I take the fault on me.$NEWLINE$If you offend him, I for him defy you.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Put your sword away. If this young gentleman has offended you, I’ll take the blame for it. If you’ve offended him, I’ll fight you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$You, sir? Why, what are you?
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$You, sir? Who are you?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more$NEWLINE$Than you have heard him brag to you he will.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I’m just a good friend of his. In fact, I’d do even more to him than what you’ve heard him promise to do.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$If you’re someone who gets into fights, I’ll fight with you.

paragraphs.original: They draw swords Enter OFFICERS$NEWLINE$OFFICERS
paragraphs.translated: They draw their swords. OFFICERS enter.$NEWLINE$OFFICERS

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$O good Sir Toby, hold! Here come the officers.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, Sir Toby, stop! The police are here.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) I’ll be with you anon.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) I’ll be back for you soon.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$(to ANDREW) Pray, sir, put your sword up, if you please.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$(to ANDREW) Please, sir, put away your sword. Please.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Marry, will I, sir. And for that I promised you, I’ll be as good as my word. He will bear you easily and reins well.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I certainly will, sir. And as for what I promised to you, I’m as good as my word. You can ride him easily, and he responds well when you pull the reins.

paragraphs.original: FIRST OFFICER$NEWLINE$This is the man. Do thy office.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST OFFICER$NEWLINE$This is the man. Do your job.

paragraphs.original: SECOND OFFICER$NEWLINE$Antonio, I arrest thee at the suit of Count Orsino.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND OFFICER$NEWLINE$Antonio, you’re under arrest on the orders of Count Orsino.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$You do mistake me, sir.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$You must be mistaking me for someone else, sir.

paragraphs.original: FIRST OFFICER$NEWLINE$No, sir, no jot. I know your favor well,$NEWLINE$Though now you have no sea-cap on your head.—$NEWLINE$Take him away. He knows I know him well.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST OFFICER$NEWLINE$No, sir, not at all. I recognize your face perfectly, even without a sailor’s cap on your head.—Take him away. He knows I recognize him.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I must obey. (to VIOLA) This comes with seeking you:$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$But there’s no remedy. I shall answer it.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I have to obey. (to VIOLA) This has happened because I came looking for you, but there’s nothing I can do about it now. I’ll take what’s coming to me. But what’ll you do now that I have to ask you for my purse back?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT
