paragraphs.original: What will you do, now my necessity$NEWLINE$Makes me to ask you for my purse? It grieves me$NEWLINE$Much more for what I cannot do for you$NEWLINE$Than what befalls myself. You stand amazed,$NEWLINE$But be of comfort.
paragraphs.translated: I’m more upset about not being able to help you than I am about what’s going to happen to me. You look so confused. Don’t worry about me.

paragraphs.original: SECOND OFFICER$NEWLINE$Come, sir, away.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND OFFICER$NEWLINE$Come on, sir, let’s go.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA) I must entreat of you some of that money.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA) Really, I must ask you for some of that money.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$What money, sir?$NEWLINE$For the fair kindness you have showed me here,$NEWLINE$And part being prompted by your present trouble,$NEWLINE$Out of my lean and low ability$NEWLINE$I’ll lend you something. My having is not much.$NEWLINE$I’ll make division of my present with you.$NEWLINE$Hold, there’s half my coffer. (offering him money)$NEWLINE$(offering him money)
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$What money, sir? I feel sorry for you in this situation, and I want to thank you for the kindness you’ve shown me here, so I’ll lend you some of my money, though I don’t have much. I’ll give you half of everything I have right now. Take this. It’s half of all my money. (she offers him money)$NEWLINE$(she offers him money)

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Will you deny me now?$NEWLINE$Is ’t possible that my deserts to you$NEWLINE$Can lack persuasion? Do not tempt my misery,$NEWLINE$Lest that it make me so unsound a man$NEWLINE$As to upbraid you with those kindnesses$NEWLINE$That I have done for you.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Are you really going to pretend you don’t know me now? After everything I’ve done for you, you’re refusing to help me? Don’t make me more miserable than I am. I might do something really weak and unmanly, like listing the kind things I’ve done for you.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I know of none,$NEWLINE$Nor know I you by voice or any feature.$NEWLINE$I hate ingratitude more in a man$NEWLINE$Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness,$NEWLINE$Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption$NEWLINE$Inhabits our frail blood—
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I don’t know any kind things you’ve done for me, and I don’t recognize your voice or your face. I hate an ungrateful man more than I hate lying, vanity, babbling, drunkenness, or any other vice that we feeble human beings are susceptible to.—

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$O heavens themselves!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Oh, my God!

paragraphs.original: SECOND OFFICER$NEWLINE$Come, sir, I pray you, go.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND OFFICER$NEWLINE$Come on, sir, please. Let’s go.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Let me speak a little. This youth that you see here$NEWLINE$I snatched one half out of the jaws of death,$NEWLINE$Relieved him with such sanctity of love,$NEWLINE$And to his image, which methought did promise$NEWLINE$Most venerable worth, did I devotion.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$No, I’ve got something to say. I saved this young man’s life when he was half-dead, and nursed him back to health lovingly and tenderly. I devoted myself to him, since he looked noble and good.

paragraphs.original: FIRST OFFICER$NEWLINE$What’s that to us? The time goes by. Away!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST OFFICER$NEWLINE$Why should we care? Time’s passing. Let’s go!

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$But oh, how vile an idol proves this god!$NEWLINE$Thou hast, Sebastian, done good feature shame.$NEWLINE$In nature there’s no blemish but the mind.$NEWLINE$None can be called deformed but the unkind.$NEWLINE$Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil$NEWLINE$Are empty trunks o'erflourished by the devil.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$But oh, what a deceiver he turned out to be! You don’t live up to your good looks, Sebastian. You look good but you’re bad on the inside, where it counts, since the only real flaws in nature are in a person’s mind and soul. Only really cruel people can be called deformed. Virtue is beauty, but someone beautiful and wicked is like an empty box decorated by the devil.

paragraphs.original: FIRST OFFICER$NEWLINE$The man grows mad. Away with him. Come, come, sir.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST OFFICER$NEWLINE$The man’s going crazy. Take him away. Come on, sir. Come on.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Lead me on.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Take me.

paragraphs.original: Exit with OFFICERS$NEWLINE$OFFICERS
paragraphs.translated: He exits with the OFFICERS.$NEWLINE$OFFICERS

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Methinks his words do from such passion fly,$NEWLINE$That he believes himself. So do not I.$NEWLINE$Prove true, imagination, oh, prove true,$NEWLINE$That I, dear brother, be now ta'en for you!
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$He was so angry I feel he must really believe what he was saying. I don’t believe it. Yet I wish I could. Oh, please be true, please let it be that this man has mistaken me for you, my dear brother!

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come hither, knight. Come hither, Fabian. We’ll whisper o'er a couplet or two of most sage saws.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come here, Sir Andrew. You too, Fabian. We’ve got some words of wisdom to mull over.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$He named Sebastian. I my brother know$NEWLINE$Yet living in my glass. Even such and so$NEWLINE$In favor was my brother, and he went
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$He called me Sebastian. I know my brother’s still alive in a sense, since I see him whenever I look in the mirror. My brother looked like me, and he dressed the same way that I’m dressed now—in the same colors,

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Still in this fashion, color, ornament,$NEWLINE$For him I imitate. Oh, if it prove,$NEWLINE$Tempests are kind and salt waves fresh in love!
paragraphs.translated: with the same accessories. Oh, if it turns out to be true that he survived, then that storm was kind, and the ocean was full of love!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA exits.$NEWLINE$VIOLA

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward than a hare. His dishonesty appears in leaving his friend here in necessity and denying him. And for his cowardship, ask Fabian.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$He’s a very dishonest, puny boy, and more cowardly than a rabbit. He abandoned his friend here in an emergency, and even pretended he didn’t know him. That shows he’s dishonest. As for his cowardliness, ask Fabian.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$A coward, a most devout coward, religious in it.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$He’s a coward, a total coward. He’s religiously devoted to his cowardice.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$'Slid, I’ll after him again and beat him.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$By God, I’ll go after him again and beat him up.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Do, cuff him soundly, but never draw thy sword.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Please do. Beat him up well, but don’t draw your sword.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$An I do not—
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I swear I will—

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Come, let’s see the event.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Come on, let’s go see what happens.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I dare lay any money ’twill be nothing yet.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$I’ll bet anything you like that nothing will happen, once again.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SEBASTIAN and FOOL$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN and the FOOL enter.$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Will you make me believe that I am not sent for you?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Are you trying to tell me that I wasn’t sent to get you?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Go to, go to, thou art a foolish fellow. Let me be clear of thee.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, who cares, you’re acting like a fool. Leave me alone.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well held out, i' faith. No, I do not know you, nor I am not sent to you by my lady, to bid you come speak with her, nor your name is not Master Cesario, nor this is not my nose neither. Nothing that is so is so.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Good for you, holding out on me like this! No, I don’t know you, and my lady didn’t send me to get you, and I’m not supposed to tell you to come speak with her, and your name is not Master Cesario, and this is not my nose, either. Nothing is what it is.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I prithee, vent thy folly somewhere else. Thou know’st not me.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Oh please, go somewhere else to blab your nonsense. You don’t know me.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Vent my folly? He has heard that word of some great man and now applies it to a fool. Vent my folly! I am afraid this great lubber, the world, will prove a cockney. I prithee now, ungird thy strangeness and tell me what I shall vent to my lady. Shall I vent to her that thou art coming?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Blab my nonsense? He must’ve heard that phrase describing some great man and now he’s using it on a jester. Blab my nonsense! What an idiotic place this world is. Now please stop being so strange and tell me what exactly I should blab to my lady. Should I blab to her that you’re coming?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me. There’s money for thee. (giving money) If you tarry longer, I shall give worse payment.$NEWLINE$(giving money)
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Please, fool, go away. Here’s money for you. (giving him money) If you stay any longer, I’ll give you something worse.$NEWLINE$(giving him money)

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$By my troth, thou hast an open hand. These wise men that give fools money get themselves a good report—after fourteen years' purchase.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well, well. You’re a generous man. Wise men who give fools money might get a good reputation—if they keep up regular payments for fourteen years.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR ANDREW, SIR TOBY BELCH, and FABIAN$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$FABIAN
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW, SIR TOBY BELCH, and FABIAN enter.$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$FABIAN

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$(to SEBASTIAN) Now, sir, have I met you again? There’s for you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Well, sir, we meet again? Take that.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW strikes SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW hits SEBASTIAN.$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(returning the blow) Why, there’s for thee, and there, and there. Are all the people mad?$NEWLINE$(returning the blow)
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(returning the blow) Well, then, take that, and that, and that. Is everyone here insane?$NEWLINE$(returning the blow)

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Hold, sir, or I’ll throw your dagger o'er the house.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Stop right now or I’ll throw your dagger over the roof.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(aside) This will I tell my lady straight. I would not be in some of your coats for two pence.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(to himself) I’m going to tell my lady about this right away. I wouldn’t be in any of your shoes if you paid me.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: FOOL exits.$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(seizing SEBASTIAN) Come on, sir, hold!$NEWLINE$seizing
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(grabbing SEBASTIAN) Come on, sir, stop!$NEWLINE$(grabbing$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Nay, let him alone. I’ll go another way to work with him. I’ll have an action of battery against him if there be any law in Illyria. Though I struck him first, yet it’s no matter for that.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$No, leave him alone. I’ll get back at him another way. I’ll sue him for assault and battery, if there’s any justice in Illyria. It doesn’t matter that I hit him first.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(to SIR TOBY BELCH) Let go thy hand.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(to SIR TOBY BELCH) Let me go.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Come, sir, I will not let you go. Come, my young soldier, put up your iron. You are well fleshed. Come on.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$No, sir, I won’t let you go. Come on, put your sword away, my little soldier. You’re awfully eager to fight. Come on.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I will be free from thee.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I’ll get free of you.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN pulls free and draws his sword$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN pulls free and draws his sword.$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: What wouldst thou now? If thou darest tempt me further, draw thy sword.
paragraphs.translated: What are you going to do now? If you insist on trying my patience any further, then take out your sword right now.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$What, what? Nay, then I must have an ounce or two of this malapert blood from you.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$What? No. Because then I’d have to shed an ounce or two of your impudent blood.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH draws his sword Enter OLIVIA$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$OLIVIA
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH draws his sword. OLIVIA enters.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$OLIVIA

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Hold, Toby! On thy life I charge thee, hold!
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Stop, Sir Toby! I order you to stop!

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Madam!
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Madam!

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Will it be ever thus? Ungracious wretch,$NEWLINE$Fit for the mountains and the barbarous caves,$NEWLINE$Where manners ne'er were preach’d! Out of my sight!—$NEWLINE$Be not offended, dear Cesario.—$NEWLINE$Rudesby, be gone!
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Are you always going to be like this? You’re an ungrateful slob who’s only fit to live in the mountains, in caves far from civilized people where you won’t ever need good manners! Get out of my sight!—Dear Cesario, please don’t be offended.—Get out of here, you barbarian!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$FABIAN
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN exit.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$FABIAN

paragraphs.original: I prithee, gentle friend,$NEWLINE$Let thy fair wisdom, not thy passion, sway$NEWLINE$In this uncivil and unjust extent$NEWLINE$Against thy peace. Go with me to my house,$NEWLINE$And hear thou there how many fruitless pranks$NEWLINE$This ruffian hath botched up, that thou thereby$NEWLINE$Mayst smile at this. Thou shalt not choose but go.$NEWLINE$Do not deny. Beshrew his soul for me!$NEWLINE$He started one poor heart of mine in thee.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my dear friend, please don’t get too upset by these rude people who bothered you. Come with me to my house. I’ll tell you about all the pointless, clumsy pranks this thug uncle of mine has come up with, so that you can laugh at this one. You have to come with me. Please don’t say no. Damn that Toby! He made my heart leap for you.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(aside) What relish is in this? How runs the stream?$NEWLINE$aside$NEWLINE$Or I am mad, or else this is a dream.$NEWLINE$Let fancy still my sense in Lethe steep.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(to himself) What does this mean? Where is this all going? Either I’m insane or this is a dream. I hope these$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!
paragraphs.translated: delusions continue. If this is a dream, let me keep on sleeping!

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Nay, come, I prithee. Would thou’dst be ruled by me!
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Come with me, please. I wish you’d do what I ask!

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Madam, I will.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Madam, I will.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Oh, say so, and so be!
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Oh, say it, and mean it!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter MARIA and FOOL$NEWLINE$MARIA$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated: MARIA and the FOOL enter.$NEWLINE$MARIA$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Nay, I prithee, put on this gown and this beard. Make him believe thou art Sir Topas the curate. Do it quickly. I’ll call Sir Toby the whilst.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$No, I’m telling you, put on this robe and beard. Make him think you’re Sir Topas the priest. Be quick. Meanwhile, I’ll get Sir Toby.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MARIA exits.$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well, I’ll put it on, and I will dissemble myself in ’t, and I would I were the first that ever dissembled in such a gown.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well, I’ll put it on and disguise myself. I wish I were the first person who ever told lies in a priest’s robe.

paragraphs.original: FOOL puts on gown and beard$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated: The FOOL puts on the robe and beard.$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: I am not tall enough to become the function well, nor lean enough to be thought a good student, but to be said an honest man and a good housekeeper goes as fairly as to say a careful man and a great scholar. The competitors enter.
paragraphs.translated: I’m not tall enough to make a believable priest, or skinny enough to look like a good student. But if you’re an honest man and a good host, that’s almost as good as being moral and studious. Here come the conspirators.

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA enter.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Jove bless thee, master Parson.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$God bless you, Mr. Priest.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Bonos dies, Sir Toby. For, as the old hermit of Prague, that never saw pen and ink, very wittily said to a niece of King Gorboduc, “That that is is.” So I, being Master Parson, am Master Parson. For, what is “that” but “that,” and “is” but “is”?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Bonos dies, Sir Toby. As the old hermit of Prague, who couldn’t read or write, said very wittily to a niece of King Gorboduc, “Whatever is, is.” So since I’m Mr. Priest, I’m Mr. Priest. Because isn’t “that” “that,” and isn’t “is” “is”?$NEWLINE$Bonos dies$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$To him, Sir Topas.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Go to him, Sir Topas.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(disguising his voice) What ho, I say! Peace in this prison!$NEWLINE$disguising his voice
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(disguising his voice) Quiet down in this prison!$NEWLINE$(disguising his voice)

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$The knave counterfeits well. A good knave.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$The fool’s a good actor. A good fool.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$(from within) Who calls there?$NEWLINE$from within
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$(offstage) Who’s shouting?$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Sir Topas the curate, who comes to visit Malvolio the lunatic.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I’m Sir Topas the priest. I’ve come to visit Malvolio the lunatic.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, go to my lady—
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, please go find my lady Olivia—

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Out, hyperbolical fiend! How vexest thou this man! Talkest thou nothing but of ladies?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Get out, demon! Why are you bothering this poor man! Can’t you talk about anything besides ladies?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(aside) Well said, Master Parson.$NEWLINE$aside
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$(to himself) Well said, Mr. Priest.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sir Topas, never was man thus wronged. Good Sir Topas, do not think I am mad. They have laid me here in hideous darkness.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sir Topas, nobody’s ever been as badly treated as I’ve been. Good Sir Topas, don’t believe I’m insane, They’ve shut me up here in horrible darkness.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Fie, thou dishonest Satan! I call thee by the most modest terms, for I am one of those gentle ones that will use the devil himself with courtesy. Sayest thou that house is dark?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$You should be ashamed of yourself, Satan, you liar! I’m being gentle with you, because I’m one of those good-hearted people who are polite to the devil himself. You call this house dark?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$As hell, Sir Topas.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Dark as hell, Sir Topas.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Why, it hath bay windows transparent as barricadoes, and the clerestories toward the south-north are as lustrous as ebony. And yet complainest thou of obstruction?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$But it has bay windows that are as transparent as stone walls, and the upper windows facing south-north are as clear as coal. But you’re still complaining of darkness and a bad view?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$I am not mad, Sir Topas. I say to you this house is dark.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$I’m not insane, Sir Topas. I’m telling you, this house is dark.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Madman, thou errest. I say, there is no darkness but ignorance, in which thou art more puzzled than the Egyptians in their fog.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$You’re wrong, you madman. There’s no darkness except ignorance, and you’re more ignorant than the Egyptians during the plague of fog.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$I say, this house is as dark as ignorance, though ignorance were as dark as hell. And I say, there was never man thus abused. I am no more mad than you are. Make the trial of it in any constant question.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$I tell you, this house is as dark as ignorance. And I tell you, no man has ever been treated worse than me. I’m no more insane than you are, and I’ll prove it. Ask me any commonsense question.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning wildfowl?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$What was the philosopher Pythagoras’s belief about wild birds?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$That the soul of our grandam might haply inhabit a bird.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$That our grandmother’s soul could end up inhabiting a bird.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$What thinkest thou of his opinion?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$What do you think of his belief?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$I think nobly of the soul, and no way approve his opinion.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$I respect the soul very much, so I disagree with his belief.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Fare thee well. Remain thou still in darkness. Thou shalt hold the opinion of Pythagoras ere I will allow of thy wits, and fear to kill a woodcock lest thou dispossess the soul of thy grandam. Fare thee well.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well then, goodbye. Stay in the dark. I’ll only admit that you’re sane when you agree with Pythagoras and hesitate to kill a bird because it might contain your grandmother’s soul. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sir Topas, Sir Topas!
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$My most exquisite Sir Topas!
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$The brilliant Sir Topas!

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Nay, I am for all waters.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I can do anything!

paragraphs.original: MARIA$NEWLINE$Thou mightst have done this without thy beard and gown.$NEWLINE$He sees thee not.
paragraphs.translated: MARIA$NEWLINE$You could’ve done this without your beard and gown. He couldn’t see you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$To him in thine own voice, and bring me word how thou findest him. I would we were well rid of this knavery. If he may be conveniently delivered, I would he were, for I am now so far in offense with my niece that I cannot pursue with any safety this sport to the upshot. Come by and by to my chamber.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Now talk to him in your own voice, and tell me how he is. I wish this trick would be over. If we can find a convenient way to let him go, I want to do it. I’m in so much trouble with my niece that it wouldn’t be safe to let this prank go to its conclusion. Come to my room later on.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$MARIA
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA exit.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$MARIA

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings in his own voice)$NEWLINE$(sings in his own voice)$NEWLINE$Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,$NEWLINE$Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,$NEWLINE$Tell me how thy lady does.$NEWLINE$Tell me how thy lady does.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(he sings in his own voice)$NEWLINE$(he sings in his own voice)$NEWLINE$Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,$NEWLINE$Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,$NEWLINE$Tell me how your lady is.$NEWLINE$Tell me how your lady is.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Fool!
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Fool!

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings) My lady is unkind, perdy.$NEWLINE$(sings) My lady is unkind, perdy.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(singing) My lady’s mean, and that’s a fact.$NEWLINE$(singing) My lady’s mean, and that’s a fact.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Fool!
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Fool!

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings) Alas, why is she so?$NEWLINE$(sings) Alas, why is she so?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(singing) Oh, I’m sorry, why is she mean?$NEWLINE$(singing) Oh, I’m sorry, why is she mean?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Fool, I say!
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Fool, I say!

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings) She loves another—Who calls, ha?$NEWLINE$(sings) She loves another—Who calls, ha?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(singing) She loves someone else—Who’s shouting?$NEWLINE$(singing) She loves someone else—Who’s shouting?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Good fool, as ever thou wilt deserve well at my hand, help me to a candle, and pen, ink, and paper. As I am a gentleman, I will live to be thankful to thee for ’t.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Good fool, good jester, I’ll make it worth your while if you get me a candle, and a pen, ink and paper. You have my word as a gentleman that I’ll always be grateful to you.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Master Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Master Malvolio?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Ay, good fool.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Yes, good fool.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Alas, sir, how fell you besides your five wits?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Poor man, how did you go insane?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Fool, there was never a man so notoriously abused: I am as well in my wits, Fool, as thou art.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Fool, no one has ever been as mistreated as I am. I’m completely sane, Fool. I’m as sane as you are.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$But as well? Then you are mad indeed, if you be no better in your wits than a fool.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$As sane as me? Then you really are insane, if you’re no saner than a fool.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$They have here propertied me, keep me in darkness, send ministers to me—asses!—and do all they can to face me out of my wits.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$They treat me like garbage here. They keep me in darkness, and send idiotic priests to talk to me—those asses!—and do everything they can to insist I’m insane.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Advise you what you say. The minister is here. (in the voice of Sir Topas) Malvolio, Malvolio, thy wits the heavens restore! Endeavor thyself to sleep, and leave thy vain bibble-babble.$NEWLINE$(in the voice$NEWLINE$of Sir Topas)
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Be careful what you say—the priest is here. (in the voice of Sir Topas) Malvolio, Malvolio, may heaven make you sane again! Try to sleep, and stop your pointless babbling.$NEWLINE$(in the voice of Sir Topas)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sir Topas!
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Sir Topas!

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(as Sir Topas) Maintain no words with him, good fellow. (in his own voice) Who, I, sir? Not I, sir. God b' wi' you, good Sir Topas. (as Sir Topas) Marry, amen. (in his own voice) I will, sir, I will.$NEWLINE$(as Sir Topas)$NEWLINE$(in$NEWLINE$his own voice)$NEWLINE$(as Sir Topas)$NEWLINE$(in his own voice)
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(as Sir Topas) Don’t talk to him, my friend. (in his own voice) Who, me, sir? Not me, sir. God be with you, Sir Topas, goodbye. (as Sir Topas) Well then, amen. (in his own voice) Goodbye, sir.$NEWLINE$(as Sir Topas)$NEWLINE$(in his own voice)$NEWLINE$(as Sir Topas)$NEWLINE$(in his own voice)

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Fool, fool, fool, I say!
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Fool, fool, hey, fool!

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Alas, sir, be patient. What say you sir? I am shent for speaking to you.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Please, sir, be quiet. What do you want to say, sir? I’ve just been scolded for speaking to you.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Good fool, help me to some light and some paper. I tell thee, I am as well in my wits as any man in Illyria.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Be a nice fool and help me find a candle and some paper. I tell you, I’m as sane as any man in Illyria.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well-a-day that you were, sir.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$If only you were, sir.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$By this hand, I am. Good fool, some ink, paper, and light, and convey what I will set down to my lady. It shall advantage thee more than ever the bearing of letter did.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$I swear I am. Get me some ink, paper, and a candle. I’ll write a letter and you’ll take it to my lady. You’ll get a bigger reward than you ever got delivering a letter before.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$I will help you to ’t. But tell me true, are you not mad indeed? Or do you but counterfeit?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I’ll help you. But tell me honestly, are you sure you’re not insane? Or are you just pretending?

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Believe me, I am not. I tell thee true.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Believe me, I’m not. I’m telling the truth.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Nay, I’ll ne'er believe a madman till I see his brains. I will fetch you light, and paper, and ink.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I’ll never believe a madman until I can see his brains. But I’ll get you a candle and paper and ink.

paragraphs.original: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Fool, I’ll requite it in the highest degree. I prithee, be gone.
paragraphs.translated: MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$Fool, I’ll repay you for this favor. Please, hurry.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$I am gone, sir,$NEWLINE$I am gone, sir,$NEWLINE$And anon, sir,$NEWLINE$And anon, sir,$NEWLINE$I’ll be with you again,$NEWLINE$I’ll be with you again,$NEWLINE$In a trice,$NEWLINE$In a trice,$NEWLINE$Like to the old Vice,$NEWLINE$Like to the old Vice,$NEWLINE$Your need to sustain,$NEWLINE$Your need to sustain,$NEWLINE$Who, with dagger of lath$NEWLINE$Who, with dagger of lath$NEWLINE$In his rage and his wrath,$NEWLINE$In his rage and his wrath,$NEWLINE$Cries “Aha,” to the devil,$NEWLINE$Cries “Aha,” to the devil,$NEWLINE$Like a mad lad,$NEWLINE$Like a mad lad,$NEWLINE$“Pare thy nails, dad,$NEWLINE$“Pare thy nails, dad,$NEWLINE$Adieu, goodman devil.”$NEWLINE$Adieu, goodman devil.”
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(he sings)$NEWLINE$(he sings)$NEWLINE$I’m going now, sir, but soon$NEWLINE$I’m going now, sir, but soon$NEWLINE$I’ll be with you again,$NEWLINE$I’ll be with you again,$NEWLINE$To help you resist the devil,$NEWLINE$To help you resist the devil,$NEWLINE$Like the sidekick in the old plays$NEWLINE$Like the sidekick in the old plays$NEWLINE$Who shakes a wooden dagger,$NEWLINE$Who shakes a wooden dagger,$NEWLINE$Fumes in rage and wrath,$NEWLINE$Fumes in rage and wrath,$NEWLINE$And shouts “Whoa!” to the devil.$NEWLINE$And shouts “Whoa!” to the devil.$NEWLINE$He yells, “Trim your nails, old man.$NEWLINE$He yells, “Trim your nails, old man.$NEWLINE$And goodbye, Satan, you peasant.”$NEWLINE$And goodbye, Satan, you peasant.”

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: FOOL exits.$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN enters.$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$This is the air, that is the glorious sun.$NEWLINE$This pearl she gave me, I do feel ’t and see ’t,$NEWLINE$And though ’tis wonder that enwraps me thus,$NEWLINE$Yet ’tis not madness. Where’s Antonio, then?$NEWLINE$I could not find him at the Elephant.$NEWLINE$Yet there he was, and there I found this credit,$NEWLINE$That he did range the town to seek me out.$NEWLINE$His counsel now might do me golden service.$NEWLINE$For though my soul disputes well with my sense$NEWLINE$That this may be some error, but no madness,$NEWLINE$Yet doth this accident and flood of fortune$NEWLINE$So far exceed all instance, all discourse,$NEWLINE$That I am ready to distrust mine eyes$NEWLINE$And wrangle with my reason that persuades me$NEWLINE$To any other trust but that I am mad—$NEWLINE$Or else the lady’s mad. Yet if ’twere so,$NEWLINE$She could not sway her house, command her followers,$NEWLINE$Take and give back affairs and their dispatch$NEWLINE$With such a smooth, discreet, and stable bearing$NEWLINE$As I perceive she does. There’s something in ’t$NEWLINE$That is deceivable. But here the lady comes.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$This is the air, that’s the glorious sun. I can feel and see this pearl she gave me. I may be dazed and confused, but I’m not insane. Where’s Antonio, then? I didn’t find him at the Elephant. But he’d been there before me, and they told me he’d gone out looking for me. I could really use his advice right now. I feel sure this situation is due to some mistake, and I don’t think I’m crazy. But this sudden flood of good luck is so unbelievable that I’m ready to distrust my own eyes and my own rational mind when they tell me I’m not insane—maybe the lady’s insane. But if that were the case, she wouldn’t be able to run her house, command her servants, listen to reports, make decisions, and take care of business as smoothly as she does. There’s something going on that’s not what it seems. But here she comes.

paragraphs.original: Enter OLIVIA and PRIEST$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$PRIEST
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA and a PRIEST enter.$NEWLINE$OLIVIA$NEWLINE$PRIEST

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$(to SEBASTIAN)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Blame not this haste of mine. If you mean well,$NEWLINE$Now go with me and with this holy man$NEWLINE$Into the chantry by. There, before him$NEWLINE$And underneath that consecrated roof,$NEWLINE$Plight me the full assurance of your faith,$NEWLINE$That my most jealous and too doubtful soul$NEWLINE$May live at peace. He shall conceal it$NEWLINE$Whiles you are willing it shall come to note,$NEWLINE$What time we will our celebration keep$NEWLINE$According to my birth. What do you say?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$(to SEBASTIAN) Don’t be angry with me for acting so quickly. If your intentions toward me are honorable, come with me and this holy man into the chapel over there, where you can soothe all my worries by making your marriage vows to me. The priest will keep it secret until you’re ready to make the news public and we can throw a full marriage celebration that befits my social standing. What do you say?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I’ll follow this good man, and go with you;$NEWLINE$And, having sworn truth, ever will be true.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I’ll follow the priest and go with you; and after I’ve sworn to be faithful, I’ll be faithful forever.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Then lead the way, good father; and heavens so shine$NEWLINE$That they may fairly note this act of mine.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Then lead the way, father. I want the skies bright and shining to show its approval of our wedding.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FOOL and FABIAN$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$FABIAN
paragraphs.translated: The FOOL and FABIAN enter.$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$FABIAN

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Now, as thou lovest me, let me see his letter.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$If you’re my friend, you’ll let me see his letter.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Dear Mr. Fabian, do me another favor first.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Anything.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$Anything.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Do not desire to see this letter.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Don’t ask to see this letter.

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$This is, to give a dog and in recompense desire my dog again.
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$That’s like giving someone a dog as a present, and then asking for the dog back in return.

paragraphs.original: Enter ORSINO, VIOLA, CURIO, and lords$NEWLINE$ORSINO$NEWLINE$VIOLA$NEWLINE$CURIO
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO, VIOLA, CURIO, and lords enter.$NEWLINE$ORSINO$NEWLINE$VIOLA$NEWLINE$CURIO

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Belong you to the Lady Olivia, friends?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$My friends, are you all Lady Olivia’s servants?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Ay, sir, we are some of her trappings.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Yes, sir, we’re part of her entourage.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$I know thee well. How dost thou, my good fellow?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$I know you. How are you, my friend?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Truly, sir, the better for my foes and the worse for my friends.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I’m better off because of my enemies, and worse off because of my friends.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Just the contrary. The better for thy friends.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$You mean it the other way around. You’re better off because of your friends.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, sir, the worse.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, sir, worse off.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$How can that be?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$How can that be?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, they praise me and make an ass of me, now my foes tell me plainly I am an ass. So that by my foes, sir I profit in the knowledge of myself, and by my friends, I am abused. So that, conclusions to be as kisses, if your four negatives make your two affirmatives, why then the worse for my friends and the better for my foes.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well, my friends praise me and make me look like an idiot, while my enemies tell me straightforwardly that I am an idiot. My enemies help me understand myself better, which is an advantage, and my friends help me lie about myself, which is a disadvantage. So if four negatives make two affirmatives, I’m worse off because of my friends and better off because of my foes.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Why, this is excellent.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$That’s excellent.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$By my troth, sir, no—though it please you to be one of my friends.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Don’t say that—unless you want to be one of my friends.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$(giving a coin)$NEWLINE$(giving a coin)$NEWLINE$Thou shalt not be the worse for me: there’s gold.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$(he gives him a coin) You won’t be worse off because of me: here’s some money.$NEWLINE$(he gives him a coin)

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$But that it would be double-dealing, sir, I would you could make it another.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$That’s a nice hand you dealt me. But if it’s not double-dealing, sir, I wish you’d deal me another.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$O, you give me ill counsel.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Oh, you’re a naughty one, encouraging double-dealing.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Put your grace in your pocket, sir, for this once, and let your flesh and blood obey it.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Ignore your virtue and nobility just this once, sir, go ahead.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Well, I will be so much a sinner, to be a double-dealer.$NEWLINE$There’s another. (giving a coin)$NEWLINE$giving a coin
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Well, I’ll commit the sin of double-dealing, and deal you a second coin. Here it is. (he gives him another coin)$NEWLINE$(he gives him another coin)

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Primo, secundo, tertio is a good play, and the old saying is, the third pays for all. The triplex, sir, is a good tripping measure, or the bells of Saint Bennet, sir, may put you in mind—one, two, three.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$And maybe a third? You know, there’s a game called “third time’s the charm,” which is fun to play, and they always say that three’s a magic number. The three-beat rhythm is a good for dancing, and the church bells chime—one, two, three.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$You can fool no more money out of me at this throw. If you will let your lady know I am here to speak with her, and bring her along with you, it may awake my bounty further.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$You can’t get any more money out of me right now. If you tell your lady I’m here to speak with her, and bring her out with you when you come back, you might make me more generous.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, lullaby to your bounty till I come again. I go, sir, but I would not have you to think that my desire of having is the sin of covetousness. But, as you say, sir, let your bounty take a nap, I will awake it anon.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well then, sing a lullaby to your generosity: it’ll nap until I come back. But don’t think I’m doing this because I’m greedy. I’ll be back soon to wake up your generosity.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The FOOL exits.$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Here comes the man, sir, that did rescue me.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Here comes the man who rescued me, sir.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONIO and OFFICERS$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$OFFICERS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO and OFFICERS enter.$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$OFFICERS

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$That face of his I do remember well.$NEWLINE$Yet, when I saw it last, it was besmeared$NEWLINE$As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war.$NEWLINE$A baubling vessel was he captain of,$NEWLINE$For shallow draught and bulk unprizable,$NEWLINE$With which such scathful grapple did he make$NEWLINE$With the most noble bottom of our fleet,$NEWLINE$That very envy and the tongue of loss$NEWLINE$Cried fame and honor on him.—What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$I remember his face well. Though the last time I saw him it was black from the smoke of war. He was the captain of a flimsy boat that was practically worthless because it was so small. But with that tiny boat he fought such a fierce battle against the largest warship in our fleet that we had to admire his courage and skill even though he caused us a lot of damage.—What’s going on?

paragraphs.original: FIRST OFFICER$NEWLINE$Orsino, this is that Antonio$NEWLINE$That took the Phoenix and her fraught from Candy,$NEWLINE$Phoenix$NEWLINE$And this is he that did the Tiger board$NEWLINE$Tiger$NEWLINE$When your young nephew Titus lost his leg.$NEWLINE$Here in the streets, desperate of shame and state,$NEWLINE$In private brabble did we apprehend him.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST OFFICER$NEWLINE$Orsino, this is the same Antonio who took the Phoenix and her cargo from Crete and captured our ship the Tiger during the battle where your young nephew Titus lost his leg. We arrested him here for fighting in the streets. It’s as if he didn’t care we were on the lookout for him here.$NEWLINE$Phoenix$NEWLINE$Tiger

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$He did me kindness, sir, drew on my side,$NEWLINE$But in conclusion put strange speech upon me.$NEWLINE$I know not what ’twas but distraction.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$He was kind to me and took my side in the fight. But then he said strange things to me. He might be insane. I don’t know what else it could be.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Notable pirate! Thou saltwater thief,$NEWLINE$What foolish boldness brought thee to their mercies,$NEWLINE$Whom thou, in terms so bloody and so dear,$NEWLINE$Hast made thine enemies?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$But you’re a famous pirate! A master thief of the seas! What made you stupid and careless enough to come visit the people you robbed and slaughtered?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Orsino, noble sir,$NEWLINE$Be pleased that I shake off these names you give me.$NEWLINE$Antonio never yet was thief or pirate,$NEWLINE$Though, I confess, on base and ground enough,$NEWLINE$Orsino’s enemy. A witchcraft drew me hither.$NEWLINE$That most ingrateful boy there by your side$NEWLINE$From the rude sea’s enraged and foamy mouth$NEWLINE$Did I redeem. A wreck past hope he was.$NEWLINE$His life I gave him and did thereto add$NEWLINE$My love, without retention or restraint,$NEWLINE$All his in dedication. For his sake$NEWLINE$Did I expose myself, pure for his love,$NEWLINE$Into the danger of this adverse town,$NEWLINE$Drew to defend him when he was beset,$NEWLINE$Where being apprehended, his false cunning,$NEWLINE$(Not meaning to partake with me in danger)$NEWLINE$Taught him to face me out of his acquaintance,$NEWLINE$And grew a twenty-years-removed thing$NEWLINE$While one would wink, denied me mine own purse,$NEWLINE$Which I had recommended to his use$NEWLINE$Not half an hour before.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Orsino, sir, please don’t call me those names. I was never a thief or a pirate, though I admit I was your enemy for good reasons. I came here because someone put a spell on me. I rescued that ungrateful boy next to you from drowning. He was a wreck, almost past hope. I saved his life and gave him my love, without reservation. I dedicated myself to him. For his sake I ran the risk of revisiting this unfriendly town, and I drew my sword to defend him when he was in trouble. But when the police caught us, he was clever and treacherous enough to pretend he’d never met me before. He acted like someone who barely knew me. He refused to give me my own wallet, which I had lent him only half an hour before.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$How can this be?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$How is that possible?

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) When came he to this town?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) When did he come to town?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Today, my lord, and for three months before,$NEWLINE$No interim, not a minute’s vacancy,$NEWLINE$Both day and night did we keep company.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Today, my lord. And for three months before that, we spent every day and night together.

paragraphs.original: Enter OLIVIA and attendants$NEWLINE$OLIVIA
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA and attendants enter.$NEWLINE$OLIVIA

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Here comes the Countess. Now heaven walks on earth.$NEWLINE$But for thee, fellow. Fellow, thy words are madness:$NEWLINE$Three months this youth hath tended upon me;$NEWLINE$But more of that anon. (to an officer) Take him aside.$NEWLINE$(to an officer)
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Ah, the countess is coming! An angel is walking on earth. But as for you, mister, what you’re saying is insane. This young man has worked for me for three months; but more about that later. (to an officer) Take him away.$NEWLINE$(to an officer)

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What would my lord, but that he may not have,$NEWLINE$Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable?$NEWLINE$Cesario, you do not keep promise with me.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What can I give you that you want, my lord, except the one thing you can’t have? Cesario, you missed your appointment with me.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Madam?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Madam?

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Gracious Olivia—
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Dearest Olivia—

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What do you say, Cesario?—Good my lord—
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What do you have to say for yourself, Cesario?—My lord, please—

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$My lord would speak. My duty hushes me.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$My lord wants to speak. It’s my duty to be quiet.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$If it be aught to the old tune, my lord,$NEWLINE$It is as fat and fulsome to mine ear$NEWLINE$As howling after music.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$If what you have to say is anything like what you used to say, it’ll be as repulsive to my ears as wild screams after beautiful music.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Still so cruel?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Are you still so cruel?

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Still so constant, lord.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$I am still so faithful, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$What, to perverseness? You, uncivil lady,$NEWLINE$To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars$NEWLINE$My soul the faithfull’st off'rings have breathed out$NEWLINE$That e'er devotion tendered—what shall I do?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$What, faithful to being mean and nasty? You’re not polite! I breathed from my soul the most faithful offerings to your ungrateful altars that any devoted person has ever offered—what more am I supposed to do?

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Even what it please my lord that shall become him.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$You can do whatever you want as long as it’s socially appropriate.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Why should I not, had I the heart to do it,$NEWLINE$Like to the Egyptian thief at point of death,$NEWLINE$Kill what I love?—A savage jealousy$NEWLINE$That sometimes savors nobly. But hear me this:$NEWLINE$Since you to nonregardance cast my faith,$NEWLINE$And that I partly know the instrument$NEWLINE$That screws me from my true place in your favor,$NEWLINE$Live you the marble-breasted tyrant still.$NEWLINE$But this your minion, whom I know you love,$NEWLINE$And whom, by heaven I swear, I tender dearly,$NEWLINE$Him will I tear out of that cruel eye$NEWLINE$Where he sits crowned in his master’s spite.$NEWLINE$Come, boy, with me. My thoughts are ripe in mischief:$NEWLINE$I’ll sacrifice the lamb that I do love$NEWLINE$To spite a raven’s heart within a dove.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Maybe I should act like the Egyptian thief who kills the woman he loves before he dies? That kind of savage jealousy sometimes seems noble. But listen to me. Since you keep denying the love I feel for you, and since I know who’s stealing my place in your heart, you can go on being cold-hearted, but I’m going to take this boy from you. He knows his master loves you. I’m doing this, even though he’s dear to me, because I know you love him. Come with me, boy. I’m ready to do something extreme. I’ll sacrifice this boy I care for, just to spite a beautiful woman with a heart of stone.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$And I, most jocund, apt, and willingly,$NEWLINE$To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$And I would die a thousand deaths cheerfully, if it made your life easier.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Where goes Cesario?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Where’s Cesario going?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$After him I love$NEWLINE$More than I love these eyes, more than my life,$NEWLINE$More, by all mores, than e'er I shall love wife.$NEWLINE$If I do feign, you witnesses above,$NEWLINE$Punish my life for tainting of my love!
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Following the one I love more than my eyes or my life. More than I will ever love a wife. That’s the truth. The angels in heaven are my witnesses, and can see how pure my love is.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Ay me, detested! How am I beguiled!
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Ah, how awful, I feel so used! I’ve been tricked!

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Who does beguile you? Who does do you wrong?
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Who tricked you? Who treated you badly?

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Hast thou forgot thyself? Is it so long?—$NEWLINE$Call forth the holy father.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Have you completely forgotten? Has it been so long? Call the priest.

paragraphs.original: Exit an attendant
paragraphs.translated: An attendant exits.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Come, away!
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA) Come on, let’s go!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Whither, my lord?—Cesario, husband, stay.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Go where, my lord?—Cesario, my husband, stay here.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Husband?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Husband?

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Ay, husband. Can he that deny?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Yes, husband. Can he deny it?

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Her husband, sirrah?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Are you her husband, boy?

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$No, my lord, not I.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$No, my lord, not me.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Alas, it is the baseness of thy fear$NEWLINE$That makes thee strangle thy propriety.$NEWLINE$Fear not, Cesario. Take thy fortunes up.$NEWLINE$Be that thou know’st thou art, and then thou art$NEWLINE$As great as that thou fear’st.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$You’re afraid, so you hide your identity. But don’t be afraid, Cesario. Accept the good luck that’s come your way. Be the person you know you are, and you’ll be as powerful as this person you fear.

paragraphs.original: Enter PRIEST$NEWLINE$PRIEST
paragraphs.translated: The PRIEST enters.$NEWLINE$PRIEST

paragraphs.original: O, welcome, father!$NEWLINE$Father, I charge thee, by thy reverence,$NEWLINE$Here to unfold (though lately we intended$NEWLINE$To keep in darkness what occasion now$NEWLINE$Reveals before ’tis ripe) what thou dost know$NEWLINE$Hath newly passed between this youth and me.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, hello, father! Father, could I please ask you to tell these people what happened between me and this young man? (I know we wanted to hide it, but now the situation demands that we reveal everything.)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRIEST$NEWLINE$A contract of eternal bond of love,$NEWLINE$Confirmed by mutual joinder of your hands,$NEWLINE$Attested by the holy close of lips,$NEWLINE$Strengthened by interchangement of your rings,$NEWLINE$And all the ceremony of this compact$NEWLINE$Sealed in my function, by my testimony,$NEWLINE$Since when, my watch hath told me, toward my grave$NEWLINE$I have traveled but two hours.
paragraphs.translated: PRIEST$NEWLINE$They were joined in an eternal bond of love and matrimony, and it was confirmed by a holy kiss and an exchange of rings. I witnessed it all as priest. It took place just two hours ago.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$O thou dissembling cub! What wilt thou be$NEWLINE$When time hath sowed a grizzle on thy case?$NEWLINE$Or will not else thy craft so quickly grow$NEWLINE$That thine own trip shall be thine overthrow?$NEWLINE$Farewell, and take her; but direct thy feet$NEWLINE$Where thou and I henceforth may never meet.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA) Oh, you little liar! How much worse will you be when you’re older? Maybe you’ll get so good at deceit that your tricks will destroy you. Goodbye, and take her. Just never set foot in any place where you and I might happen to meet.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$My lord, I do protest—
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$My lord, I swear to you—

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$O, do not swear!$NEWLINE$Hold little faith, though thou hast too much fear.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Oh, don’t swear! Keep a little bit of honesty, even if you’re afraid.

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW enters.$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$For the love of God, a surgeon! Send one presently to Sir$NEWLINE$Toby.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$For the love of God, call a doctor! Sir Toby needs help right away.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$He has broke my head across and has given Sir Toby a bloody coxcomb too. For the love of God, your help! I had rather than forty pound I were at home.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$He cut my head and gave Sir Toby a bloody head, too. For the love of God, help us! I’d give forty pounds to be safe at home right now.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Who has done this, Sir Andrew?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Who did this, Sir Andrew?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$The Count’s gentleman, one Cesario. We took him for a coward, but he’s the very devil incardinate.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$The count’s messenger, Cesario. We thought he was a coward, but he fights like a devil.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$My gentleman, Cesario?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$My Cesario?

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$'Od’s lifelings, here he is!—You broke my head for nothing, and that that I did, I was set on to do ’t by Sir Toby.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$Oh, no, there he is! —You cut my head for no reason. Anything I did to you, I did it because Sir Toby made me.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Why do you speak to me? I never hurt you.$NEWLINE$You drew your sword upon me without cause,$NEWLINE$But I bespoke you fair and hurt you not.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Why are you talking like this? I never hurt you. You waved your sword at me for no reason, but I was nice to you. I didn’t hurt you.

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt, you have hurt me. I think you set nothing by a bloody coxcomb.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$If a bloody head counts as a hurt, then you hurt me. Apparently you think there’s nothing unusual about a bloody head.

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and FOOL$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH and the FOOL enter.$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: Here comes Sir Toby halting. You shall hear more. But if he had not been in drink, he would have tickled you othergates than he did.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes Sir Toby, limping. He’ll tell you more of the story. If he hadn’t been drunk, he would’ve really roughed you up.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$How now, gentleman? How is ’t with you?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Hello, sir! How are you?

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$That’s all one: has hurt me, and there’s the end on ’t. (to$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$FOOL) Sot, didst see Dick Surgeon, sot?$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$It doesn’t matter how I am: he hurt me, and that’s that. (to FOOL) Fool, have you seen Dick the surgeon?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Oh, he’s drunk, Sir Toby, an hour agone. His eyes were set at eight i' the morning.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Oh, he’s drunk, Sir Toby, for a whole hour now. His eyes started glazing over around eight in the morning.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Then he’s a rogue, and a passy-measures pavin. I hate a drunken rogue.
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Then he’s no good. I hate no-good drunks.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Away with him! Who hath made this havoc with them?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Take him away! Who did this to him?

paragraphs.original: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I’ll help you, Sir Toby, because we’ll be dressed together.
paragraphs.translated: SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$I’ll help you, Sir Toby. They’ll treat our wounds together.

paragraphs.original: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Will you help?—An ass-head, and a coxcomb, and a knave, a thin-faced knave, a gull!
paragraphs.translated: SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$Will you help me?—What an ass and a fool, a gullible no-good idiot!

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Get him to bed, and let his hurt be looked to.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Get him to bed and make sure his wounds are treated.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt FOOL, FABIAN, SIR TOBY BELCH, and SIR ANDREW$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$FABIAN$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated: The FOOL, FABIAN, SIR TOBY BELCH, and SIR ANDREW exit.$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$FABIAN$NEWLINE$SIR TOBY BELCH$NEWLINE$SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original: Enter SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN enters.$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I am sorry, madam, I have hurt your kinsman,$NEWLINE$But, had it been the brother of my blood,$NEWLINE$I must have done no less with wit and safety.$NEWLINE$You throw a strange regard upon me, and by that$NEWLINE$I do perceive it hath offended you.$NEWLINE$Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows$NEWLINE$We made each other but so late ago.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I’m sorry, madam. I wounded your relative. But I would’ve been forced to do the same thing to my brother, since my safety was at stake. You’re looking at me strangely, so I guess you’re offended. But please forgive me, darling, for the sake of the vows we made to each other so recently.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$One face, one voice, one habit, and two persons!$NEWLINE$A natural perspective, that is and is not!
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$One face, one voice, one way of dressing, but two people! It’s like an optical illusion. It is and isn’t the same person!

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Antonio, O my dear Antonio!$NEWLINE$How have the hours racked and tortured me$NEWLINE$Since I have lost thee!
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Antonio, oh my dear Antonio! I’ve been so tortured since I lost track of you!

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Sebastian are you?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Are you Sebastian?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Fear’st thou that, Antonio?
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Do you have any doubts, Antonio?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$How have you made division of yourself?$NEWLINE$An apple, cleft in two, is not more twin$NEWLINE$Than these two creatures. Which is Sebastian?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$How did you divide yourself in two? These two people are as identical as two halves of an apple. Which one is Sebastian?

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Most wonderful!
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$How unbelievable!

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(looking at VIOLA) Do I stand there? I never had a brother;$NEWLINE$(looking at$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Nor can there be that deity in my nature,$NEWLINE$Of here and everywhere. I had a sister,$NEWLINE$Whom the blind waves and surges have devoured.$NEWLINE$Of charity, what kin are you to me?$NEWLINE$What countryman? What name? What parentage?
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(looking at VIOLA) Is that me standing over there? I never had a brother, and I’m certainly not a god who can be in two places at once. I had a sister who drowned. Please tell me, how am I related to you? Are you from my country? What’s your name? Who are your parents?$NEWLINE$(looking at$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Of Messaline. Sebastian was my father;$NEWLINE$Such a Sebastian was my brother too,$NEWLINE$So went he suited to his watery tomb.$NEWLINE$If spirits can assume both form and suit$NEWLINE$You come to fright us.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$I’m from Messaline. Sebastian was my father’s name, and my brother was named Sebastian too. He was dressed just like you are when he drowned. If ghosts can take on someone’s body and clothes, you must be a spirit who’s come to frighten us.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$A spirit I am indeed,$NEWLINE$But am in that dimension grossly clad$NEWLINE$Which from the womb I did participate.$NEWLINE$Were you a woman, as the rest goes even,$NEWLINE$I should my tears let fall upon your cheek$NEWLINE$And say “Thrice-welcome, drownèd Viola!”
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I am a spirit, yes, since I have a soul. But my spirit has a body attached to it, one that I’ve carried since I was in the womb. If you were a woman, I’d hug you now and cry, and say “Welcome back, drowned Viola!”

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$My father had a mole upon his brow.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$My father had a mole on his forehead.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$And so had mine.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Mine did too.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$And died that day when Viola from her birth$NEWLINE$Had numbered thirteen years.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$He died on Viola’s thirteenth birthday.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, that record is lively in my soul!$NEWLINE$He finished indeed his mortal act$NEWLINE$That day that made my sister thirteen years.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, I remember that very clearly! It’s true, he died on the day my sister turned thirteen.

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$If nothing lets to make us happy both$NEWLINE$But this my masculine usurped attire,$NEWLINE$Do not embrace me till each circumstance$NEWLINE$Of place, time, fortune, do cohere and jump$NEWLINE$That I am Viola. Which to confirm,$NEWLINE$I’ll bring you to a captain in this town,$NEWLINE$Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help$NEWLINE$I was preserved to serve this noble count.$NEWLINE$All the occurrence of my fortune since$NEWLINE$Hath been between this lady and this lord.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$If the only thing keeping us from rejoicing is the fact that I’m wearing men’s clothes, then don’t hug me till I can prove beyond the shadow of a doubt that I’m Viola. I’ll take you to a sea captain here in town who’s got my women’s clothing in storage. He saved my life so I could serve this noble count. Everything that’s happened to me since then has involved my relationship with this lady and this lord.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(to OLIVIA) So comes it, lady, you have been mistook.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$But nature to her bias drew in that.$NEWLINE$You would have been contracted to a maid;$NEWLINE$Nor are you therein, by my life, deceived.$NEWLINE$You are betrothed both to a maid and man.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(to OLIVIA) So you got it wrong, my lady. But nature fixed everything, turning your love for my sister into a love for me. If you hadn’t, you would’ve married a maiden. But that’s not completely wrong. I’m still a virgin, so in a sense I’m a maiden too.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$(to OLIVIA) Be not amazed. Right noble is his blood.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$If this be so, as yet the glass seems true,$NEWLINE$I shall have share in this most happy wreck.$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA) Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$(to OLIVIA) Don’t be shocked. His blood is noble. If this is all as true as it seems to be, then I’m going to have a share in that lucky shipwreck. (to VIOLA) Boy, you told me a thousand times you’d never love a woman as much as you love me.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$And all those sayings will I overswear;$NEWLINE$And those swearings keep as true in soul$NEWLINE$As doth that orbèd continent the fire$NEWLINE$That severs day from night.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$Everything I said before I’ll say again. I swear I meant every word.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Give me thy hand,$NEWLINE$And let me see thee in thy woman’s weeds.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Give me your hand and let me see you dressed in woman’s clothing.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VIOLA$NEWLINE$The captain that did bring me first on shore$NEWLINE$Hath my maid’s garments. He, upon some action,$NEWLINE$Is now in durance at Malvolio’s suit,$NEWLINE$A gentleman and follower of my lady’s.
paragraphs.translated: VIOLA$NEWLINE$The captain who brought me to shore has my women’s clothes. For some reason he’s in prison now on some legal technicality, on Malvolio’s orders. Malvolio is a gentleman in my lady’s entourage.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$He shall enlarge him.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$He’ll release him.

paragraphs.original: Enter FOOL with a letter, and FABIAN$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$FABIAN
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN and the FOOL with a letter enter.$NEWLINE$FABIAN$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: Fetch Malvolio hither:$NEWLINE$And yet, alas, now I remember me,$NEWLINE$They say, poor gentleman, he’s much distract.$NEWLINE$A most extracting frenzy of mine own$NEWLINE$From my remembrance clearly banished his.$NEWLINE$(to FOOL) How does he, sirrah?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: Go and get Malvolio—But, oh no! Now I remember, they say the poor man is mentally ill. I was so crazy myself that I forgot all about him. (to the FOOL) How is Malvolio doing, do you know?$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Truly, madam, he holds Beelzebub at the staves' end as well as a man in his case may do. Has here writ a letter to you. I should have given ’t you today morning, but as a madman’s epistles are no gospels, so it skills not much when they are delivered.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well, he keeps the devil away as well as a man can in his situation. He’s written you a letter. I would’ve given it to you this morning, but a madman’s letters aren’t Gospel, so it doesn’t matter much if I’m a bit late.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Open ’t, and read it.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Open it and read it.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers the madman. (reads) “By the Lord, madam,”—$NEWLINE$(reads)
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$There’s a lot to learn when a fool recites the words of a madman. (he reads) “I swear to God, madam,”—$NEWLINE$(he reads)

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$How now? Art thou mad?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Why are you talking like that? Are you insane?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, madam, I do but read madness. An your ladyship will have it as it ought to be, you must allow vox.$NEWLINE$vox.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, madam, I’m just reading an insane letter. If you want things done in the right way, you’ll have to let me read a crazy letter in a crazy voice.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Prithee, read i' thy right wits.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$No, please, read it like a sane person.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$So I do, madonna. But to read his right wits is to read thus.$NEWLINE$Therefore perpend, my princess, and give ear.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I will, my lady, but a sane person reading this would make it sound crazy. So listen up, princess.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$(giving the letter to FABIAN) Read it you, sirrah.$NEWLINE$giving the letter to
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$(giving the letter to FABIAN) Oh, you read it, sir.$NEWLINE$(giving the letter to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“By the Lord, madam, you wrong me, and the world shall know it. Though you have put me into darkness and given your drunken cousin rule over me, yet have I the benefit of my senses as well as your Ladyship. I have your own letter that induced me to the semblance I put on, with the which I doubt not but to do myself much right or you much shame. Think of me as you please. I leave my duty a little unthought of and speak out of my injury. The madly used Malvolio.”
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$“I swear to God, madam, you’ve wronged me, and I’ll tell the whole world. You’ve shut me up in a dark room and given your drunken cousin authority over me, but I’m as sane as you are. I’ve got a letter from you encouraging me to act the way I did. If I didn’t have it, I couldn’t prove that I’m right and you’re wrong. I don’t care what you think of me. I’m going to forget my duties to you a little bit and complain about the injuries you’ve caused me. Signed,$NEWLINE$The poorly treated Malvolio.”

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Did he write this?
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Did he write this?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Ay, madam.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Yes, madam.

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$This savors not much of distraction.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$It doesn’t sound like an insane person’s letter.

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$See him delivered, Fabian; bring him hither.
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$Set him free. Fabian, bring him here.

paragraphs.original: Exit FABIAN$NEWLINE$FABIAN
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN exits.$NEWLINE$FABIAN

paragraphs.original: My lord so please you, these things further thought on,$NEWLINE$To think me as well a sister as a wife,$NEWLINE$One day shall crown the alliance on ’t, so please you,$NEWLINE$Here at my house and at my proper cost.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, I hope that after you think things over a bit you’ll come to like the idea of having me as a sister-in-law instead of a wife. We can have the weddings tomorrow if you want, here at my own house. I’ll pay for everything.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Madam, I am most apt to embrace your offer.$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Your master quits you, and for your service done him,$NEWLINE$So much against the mettle of your sex,$NEWLINE$So far beneath your soft and tender breeding,$NEWLINE$And since you called me “master” for so long,$NEWLINE$Here is my hand. You shall from this time be$NEWLINE$Your master’s mistress.
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$I accept that offer happily, madam. (to VIOLA) So you’re free now. I’m offering you my hand in marriage because of your loyal service to me, which was far from what any woman should be expected to do, especially a noble woman. You’ve called me “master” for so long. And now you’ll be your master’s mistress.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA)     A sister! You are she.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: OLIVIA$NEWLINE$(to VIOLA) You’ll be my sister-in-law!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Enter FABIAN, with MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$FABIAN$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated: FABIAN enters with MALVOLIO$NEWLINE$FABIAN$NEWLINE$MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Is this the madman?
paragraphs.translated: ORSINO$NEWLINE$Is this the madman?
